Feature Description: The Site is located in the town of Durham in Middlesex County, Connecticut. The outer limits of the Site are defined by the about-100-acre extent of the groundwater contamination. The Site is generally centered around DMC, a currently operating manufacturing facility at 201 Main Street, and the former location of MMC at 281 Main Street. DMC was established in 1922 at 201 and 203R Main Street in Durham.

Feature Name: Approximate Old Springfield Landfill Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 10-acre Site is located approximately 1 mile southeast of the center of the Town of Springfield, Windsor County, Vermont. Springfield is located in the Connecticut River Valley in the southeastern quadrant of Vermont, south of Hanover, New Hampshire and west of Interstate 91. The Villages of Goulds Mill and Hardscrabble Corner are located within a 1 mile radius of the Site. The Site is located on an upland plateau with slopes descending steeply to the north, east, and west. Seavers Brook runs west of the Site and the Black River runs to the east. Seavers Brook flows northward to the Black River, which flows south and discharges into the Connecticut River. Will Dean Road is located along the western side of the Site. Will Dean Road intersects Seavers Brook Road approximately 1,000 feet north of the Site entrance; Seavers Brook Road intersects Vermont Route 11 (aka Charlestown Road) approximately 1,800 feet north of the Site entrance. Route 11 runs along the eastern side of the Site.

Feature Name: Approximate Parker Sanitary Landfill Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Parker Sanitary Landfill site is located in Lyndonville, Vermont. A solid waste landfill operated on site from 1972 until 1992. Before 1983, a large amount of hazardous waste (liquids and sludge) was disposed of at this location and were poured/placed directly onto the ground. These activities led to groundwater contamination and affected private wells in the area. Following construction of the site’s remedy, operation and maintenance activities and groundwater treatment and monitoring are ongoing. This boundary includes the area that currently exceeds IGCLs and is managed by the LFG system.
Feature Source: U.S. EPA Region 1, 2021 Annual Monitoring Report, Figure 8, Page 86

Feature Name: Approximate Pine Street Canal Site Boundary
Feature Description: Pine Street Canal Superfund Site (sometimes referred to as the “Barge Canal”) is located in the south end of Burlington, VT, adjacent to Pine Street and Lake Champlain. The Site includes a historic canal and turning basin that were used for lumber storage and hauling activities and is surrounded by active commercial and industrial operations and some vacant properties along Pine Street. It is a PRP-lead cleanup that primarily includes the management of the migration of contaminants generated from the operation of a manufactured gas plant. This boundary includes all properties located within the site boundaries.

The proposed removal action additionally includes the adjacent Fimbel Door parcel and City Right-of-Way.

Feature Name: Approximate Cannon Engineering Corp. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The CEC Bridgewater Superfund Site is comprised of seven acres, located on First Street in a small industrial park in the western part of the Town of Bridgewater, Massachusetts. The Site contained a former facility to handle, store, and incinerate chemical wastes. The Site contains one Operable Unit – Site wide, which includes a Management of Migration component of the remedy for groundwater and also a Source Control component of the remedy for soil.

Feature Description: The Hocomonco Site is approximately 23-acre in size and is located off Otis Street, in the Town of Westborough, Worcester County, Massachusetts. Wood treating operations were conducted between 1928 and 1946 and Site activities consisted of saturating wood products, with creosote to preserve them.  The Site contains one Operable Unit (OU): Sitewide and this boundary consists of one Sitewide OU.

Feature Name: Approximate Linemaster Switch Corp. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Linemaster Switch site is a 45 acre parcel that operates as a 45,525 square foot facility where electrical power switches are produced. Prior to 1952 the site was used for residential purposes and small-scale farming. As part of the manufacturing operations, TCE was used between 1969 and 1979 as a parts degreaser. Other chemicals were used and some of these chemicals were reportedly released to a dry well located directly east of the production facility. The boundary includes the site and three additional parcels owned by the Linemaster facility.

Feature Name: Approximate Raymark Industries, Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description:
Raymark OU5 - Four acre area (within OU7) near the Housatonic Boat Club and the former Shakespeare Theater bordering on the Housatonic River.  Area was previously a wetland which was filled with contaminated material. 
Raymark OU7 - Area includes approx. 26 acres of wetlands, shoreline, and a small pond along the Housatonic River from the Broad Street bridge to the Harbour View docks.  Area has been impacted by shoreline filling and surface water transport of contaminated materials.

Feature Description: The 330-acre Wells G&H site is located in Woburn, Massachusetts. The site consists of two municipal wells, known as wells G & H, which were developed in 1964 and 1967 to supplement Woburn’s water supplies. In 1979, it was discovered that the wells had been contaminated by industrial waste from neighboring properties. Both wells were shut down in 1979, and a supplemental water supply was arranged for the city. EPA placed the site on the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 1983. Site cleanup is ongoing.

Feature Description: The O’Connor Site consists of approximately 23 acres within a 28-acre property owned by Central Maine Power (CMP) and is located on U.S. Route 17 on the eastern outskirts of Augusta, Maine. (Figure 1) The surrounding area is predominantly rural. The property is bordered on the east by Riggs Brook, a small northerly flowing tributary of the Kennebec River, on the north and northwest by woodlands, and on the south by Route 17. The property south of Route 17 is generally wooded. A residence abuts the CMP property along its western boundary and there are additional residential properties farther to the west all of which are served by public water supplies. The Site is located within a Rural Residential Zone. Properties to the northwest are located in a Regional Business Zone. The MEDEP-designated Hazardous Substance Site consists of the same 23 acres within the 28acre property.

Feature Name: Approximate Union Chemical Co., Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 12-acre Union Chemical Company, Inc. site is in Hope, Maine. The Union Chemical Company began operations on site in 1967 formulating paint and coating strippers. In 1969, the company expanded its operations and began handling and recovering petrochemical-based solvents. In 1976, the company received a state permit for an underground disposal system (a septic system) for its process wastewater.

Feature Name: Approximate W.R. Grace & Co., Inc. (Action Plant)
Feature Description: The W.R. Grace & Co., Inc. (Acton Plant) site is located in the towns of Acton and Concord in Massachusetts. The site was the former location of the American Cyanamid Co. and the Dewey & Almy Chemical Co. These companies produced sealants for rubber containers, latex products, plasticizers, resins and other products. W. R. Grace bought the properties and operations in 1954. The Grace operations included production of materials used to make concrete, container sealing compounds, latex products and paper and plastic battery separators. Effluent wastes were disposed of in several unlined lagoons; solid and hazardous wastes were placed into an on-site industrial landfill and several other disposal areas. In addition, byproducts of some chemical processes were also disposed of in an area called the Blowdown Pit. Grace stopped all discharges to the unlined pits in 1980.

Feature Name: Approximate Hatheway and Patterson Site Boundary

Feature Description: The Sullivan’s Ledge Superfund Site (Site) is located in New Bedford, Massachusetts, Bristol County, near the intersection of Route 195 and Hathaway Road . OU1 consists of a 12-acre historic disposal area and the adjacent Unnamed Stream. The capped historic disposal area and currently operating groundwater treatment plant are located within a fenced area with restricted access. A solar array was constructed on the cap in 2014. The disposal area is bounded on the south by the highway interchange with Route 140 and I-195, on the east and west by commercial establishments, and on the north by Hathaway Road. The Unnamed Stream flows from the Site underneath Hathaway Road into the Whaling City Golf Course, which is owned by the City of New Bedford. OU2 is located within the Whaling City Golf Course. OU2 includes a 13-acre wooded wetland called Middle Marsh, and a 1.5-acre wetland area bordering the Unnamed Stream (400 feet upstream of the Middle Marsh).

Feature Name: Approximate Nyanza Chemical Waste Dump Site Bounda
Feature Description: The Nyanza Chemical Waste Dump site is a 35-acre area next to an active industrial complex in Ashland, Massachusetts. From 1917 to 1978, facilities produced textile dyes, intermediates and other products on site. Nyanza Inc. operated on site from 1965 until 1978. Large volumes of industrial wastewater containing high levels of acids and numerous organic and inorganic chemicals, including mercury, were generated by these facilities, leading to soil and groundwater contamination. Over 45,000 tons of chemical sludges generated by Nyanza's wastewater treatment processes, along with spent solvents and other chemical wastes, were buried on site. The area that contained the largest amount of buried waste and exposed sludge is referred to as the Hill section. The current owner leases the old plant grounds to various businesses.

Feature Name: Approximate Beede Waste Oil Site Boundary
Feature Description:
The Beede Waste Oil Site property is located at 7 Kelley Road in Plaistow, New
Hampshire and occupies approximately 40.6 acres (comprised of two parcels. Parcel 1 (approximately 21.6 acres) used for pertroeul and oil storage/recycling and Parcel 2 (approximately 19 acres) used for sand and gravel operations and bounded by Kelley Brook.  Groundwater contamination extends into the nearby residential neighborhoods.  The cleanup is complrised of 5 OUs- OU1 Groundwater; OU2 Lagoon oils, OU3 UST/Lust oils; OU4 Lower Landfill and sedient and OU5 source control - soils ( rest of site).

Feature Name: Approximate Ottati and Goss/Kingston Steel Drum Si
Feature Description: The Ottati and Goss Site is comprosed of three areas:  5.88 acre Great Lakes Container Corp and Kingston Steel Drum; 29 acre area leased to Ottati and Goss; 23 acre Country Pond Marsh.  Steel drum reconditioning operations were performed on the GLCC/KSD portion however releases occurred on all areas of the site. Feature Description: The Site is located at 210 Piggy Lane in Coventry, Rhode Island. Located on a former pig farm, the unoccupied Site includes an approximately 10-acre former disposal area and approximately 35 acres of surrounding woodland and wetland areas, defined by the extent of the groundwater and surface water impacts. More than 10,000 drums of hazardous waste and an undetermined bulk volume of liquid chemicals were disposed of into several unlined trenches. Wastes disposed of at the Site included industrial solvents, oils, pesticides, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), paint sludges, resins, still bottoms, and other hazardous materials. The site was discovered in 1977, after a fire and an explosion. Removal of contaminated soil from trenches, removal of buried drums and waste material, and closure of the site have reduced potential exposures and risks. Long-term operation and maintenance activities and environmental monitoring are ongoing.

Site Name: WEST KINGSTON TOWN DUMP/URI DISPOSAL AREA
Feature Name: Approximate West Kingston Town Dump/URI Disposal A
Feature Description: The site contains three main disposal areas: the West Kingston Town Dump, located in the southern portion of the site; the URI Disposal Area, located north of the Town Dump; and the Former Drum Storage Area (FDSA), located uphill and east of the Town Dump and URI Disposal Areas. The remedy for the site included closure and capping of former waste disposal areas with a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) cover system, and treating the FDSA source area soil and groundwater using in situ chemical oxidation combined with monitored natural attenuation. The final remedy was selected 2006, with construction completed in 2009. In 2018 the construction of solar arrays was completed on approximately 22 acres of the capped landfill areas.

Feature Description: The 13-acre Winthrop Landfill site is in Winthrop, Maine. The area is located west of Lake Annabessacook and consists of two adjacent properties, the Winthrop Town Landfill and the privately owned Savage Landfill. A sand and gravel pit initially operated on site in the 1920s. In the 1930s, parts of the site received municipal, commercial, and industrial wastes. The site accepted hazardous substances between the early 1950s and mid-1970s.

Feature Name: Approximate Fletcher's Paint Works and Storage Sit
Feature Description: The Fletcher's Paint Works and Storage Facility Superfund Site is located in a densely populated area near downtown Milford, New Hampshire. Fletcher's Paint manufactured and sold paints and stains from 1949 until1991 and consisted of two areas: a manufacturing plant/retail outlet on Elm Street and a storage area on Mill Street. Years of storage and releases of scrap pyranol, which is a mixture of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and solvents, contaminated soil, groundwater, and nearby sediments in the Souhegan River. In 1984, an EPA investigation was prompted by the discovery of Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) contamination in the adjacent Keyes Municipal Water Supply Well. The Keyes well was removed from service. Remediation activities on site have included drum removal from the Elm Street Facility, soil excavation and on-site treatment of the excavated soil using thermal desorption technology, and sediment removal from the Souhegan River.

It includes a 120-acre property, about 75 acres of Goose Pond estuary and private properties that abut the former Callahan Mining Corporation property to the north, west and south.

Feature Name: Approximate Auburn Road Landfill Site Boundary
Feature Description:
The site is approximately bounded by Auburn Road to the west, Old Derry Road to the south, State Highway 28 Bypass to the east, and the Londonderry Auburn town line to the north. A number of houses surround the site. The site is located in a rural-residential area with approximately 300 homes and a trailer park
with approximately 260 units within 1 mile of the site. In response to an EPA Record of Decision, the Town of Londonderry installed a water main on Auburn
Road to provide municipal drinking water to potentially exposed residents and the trailer park. No one is drinking ground water contaminated by the site.  This boundary only includes Operable Unit 2 (Groundwater contamination) and Operable Unit 3 (capped former disposal areas). It does not include Operable Unit 1 (the extension of the municipal drinking water system).

Feature Description: The 2-acre Tibbetts Road site is located in Barrington, New Hampshire.  The property was the former home of Alexander Johnson and occupied much of the property along Tibbetts Road.  From 1944 until 1958, Mr. Johnson transported and stored solvent-containing drums near his home.  In the 1970’s Mr. Johnson began selling home lots from his property.  Several of the new residents noticed rusting drums that contained unknown liquids scattered over the property.  The New Hampshire Water Supply and Pollution Control Commission (now the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services, or NHDES) found that the drums were leaking, rusted, and contained thinners, solvents, antifreeze, kerosene, motor and transmission oil, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), grease and brake fluid.  EPA removed 337 drums in 1984.

Feature Name: Approximate Rose Disposal Pit Site Boundary
Feature Description: The F. T. Rose Disposal Pit Superfund Site is located on Balance Rock Road in Lanesborough, Massachusetts, and is approximately one-half mile from the town of Pittsfield, Massachusetts.  The property was used for the disposal of waste oils and solvents from General Electric Company (GE). The disposal area was formerly a trench where waste oils and solvents were dumped resulting in site contamination.  The site contamination primarily consists of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) in soils and groundwater, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in groundwater.

Feature Description: The Central Landfill site is a 154-acre active waste disposal facility in Johnston, Rhode Island. During the mid to late 1970s, a half-acre area (referred to as the “hot spot”) within the unlined Phase I landfill was used for disposal of large volumes of liquid industrial waste, resulting in soil and groundwater contamination. Following construction of the site’s remedy, groundwater treatment and operation and maintenance activities are ongoing.

Feature Description: The 7-acre Keefe Environmental Services (KES) site is located in Rockingham County, New Hampshire. A chemical waste storage facility operated on site from 1978 until 1981, when the company filed for bankruptcy. Waste storage containers on site at that time included 4,100 drums, four 5,000-gallon and four 10,000-gallon aboveground storage tanks, and a 400,000-gallon synthetically lined lagoon. Solvents, acids, caustics, heavy metals, paint sludges, waste oils and organic chemicals were disposed of at the site. Facility operations led to soil and groundwater contamination on and off the site. The site is located in a state-protected watershed with wetland areas draining to the Piscassic and Fresh Rivers. Following construction of the site’s remedy, groundwater extraction and treatment operated from 1993 through 2011 and environmental monitoring is ongoing.
Feature Source: U.S. EPA Region 1, 2017 AROD, Figure 3, Conceptual Site model and Figure 8 extent of contamination

Feature Description: The 500-acre Peterson/Puritan, Inc. Site encompasses over two miles of industrial and residential property in the towns of Cumberland and Lincoln in north-central Rhode Island. The Site "study area" encompasses a wide variety of land uses, including former and active industrial and commercial areas, state and local recreational areas, the Blackstone River, and a former landfill. The Site also includes interspersed areas of undeveloped land, floodplain and wetlands. The Site covers about two miles between the Ashton Dam to the north and the Pratt Dam to the south. The Blackstone River extends along the western and southern sides of the Site.

Feature Name: Approximate Pike Hill Copper Mine Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Pike Hill Copper Mine Superfund Site is an abandoned copper mine located in the Town of Corinth, Orange County, Vermont. It includes the Union, Eureka (also known as Corinth), and Smith (also known as Bicknell) mines. The entire Site encompasses about 216 acres and contains approximately 50,000-100,000 tons of waste rock and tailings that are acting as a continuing source of contamination for the surface water of Pike Hill Brook, a tributary to Cookville Brook, and the groundwater. The mine waste generates a low pH leachate with elevated metals, particularly aluminum, copper, iron and zinc

Feature Name: Approximate Somersworth Sanitary Landfill Site Bou
Feature Description:
The Site is located on Blackwater Road, about 1 mile southwest of the center of the city of Somersworth in
Strafford County, New Hampshire. The Site is the location of a former sanitary landfill that accepted
municipal and industrial wastes from the mid-1930s to 1981. Waste-burning activities also occurred on Site until 1958. The 26-acre landfill is located north of Blackwater Road and drains west to Peters Marsh Brook and an adjacent wetland. Waste disposal activities at the landfill resulted in contamination of groundwater with volatile organic compounds (VOCs), including chlorinated ethenes. This is a single Operable Unit (OU) Site.

Feature Name: Approximate Cheshire Ground Water Contamination Si
Feature Description: The 15-acre Cheshire Ground Water Contamination site is located in Cheshire, Connecticut. The site consists of a plume of contaminated groundwater; several tenants have conducted various manufacturing processes on site. After a successful cleanup, which included removing soil and providing municipal water to residents, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 1997.  The boundary includes the entire study area.

Feature Description:
The Site is located in the towns of Strafford and Thetford in east-central Vermont, approximately two miles southeast of the village of South Strafford, on the eastern flank of Copperas Hill. It is approximately 15 miles north of White River Junction and 9 miles west of the Connecticut River. 

The primary physical features that were present when EPA began work at the Site in 2000 include: three open rock cuts (the North Open Cut, the South Open Cut, and the South Mine); two pit lakes (located at the South Open Cut and South Mine); a two-tiered tailing impoundment with a tailing dam (designated Tailing Pile-1 [TP-1]) and Tailing Pile-2 (TP-2); waste ore and waste rock piles (including the waste rock areas designated Tailing Pile 3 [TP-3] and Tailing Pile 4 [TP-4]); a series of World War II (WWII)-era mine support buildings; and underground mine workings, including adits and shafts that connect to the surface.

Feature Name: Approximate Rose Hill Regional Landfill Site Bound
Feature Description: The Site is located within the Town of South Kingstown, Rhode Island. The Site encompasses approximately 70 acres, and includes an active solid waste transfer facility. From 1967 to 1983, the Town of South Kingstown leased the site property for use as a domestic and industrial waste disposal facility. The site was placed on the National Priorities List (NPL) in October 1989. Landfill cleanup activities included the consolidation of landfill areas, addition of a landfill cap, installation of a landfill gas destruction system, monitoring of surface water, landfill gas and groundwater, and groundwater and land use restrictions. Site cleanup finished in 2008. The Site is presently utilized as an active solar farm and an emergency staging area for collected debris from municipal cleanup activities related to hurricane or natural disaster damage, as needed.

Feature Name: Approximate Atlas Tack Corp. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Site is located at 83 Pleasant Street in Fairhaven, Bristol County, Massachusetts.  The Site is approximately 48 acres and is located about 0.5 mile from Fairhaven Center in a predominantly residential area.  It is bounded by a bicycle path, residences and a few commercial/light industrial businesses to the north, a tidal marsh to the east and south, a former elementary school about 200 feet to the northwest, and residences immediately to the south.  The Site includes property owned by the Atlas Tack Corporation (“Atlas Tack”), a property at the end of Church Street owned by the Hathaway-Braley Wharf Company, Inc. (“Hathaway-Braley”), and portions of Boys Creek and the adjacent saltwater tidal marsh extending to Buzzards Bay.  A hurricane dike (also referred to as “barrier”), built in the early 1960s, runs northeasterly through the marsh area of the Site. The Site consists of one Operable Unit (OU).

Feature Description: The CEC site consists of approximately 2.6 acres of land which contained three above-ground storage tanks, which were used from 1976 until 1980, for the storage of motor oils, solvents, lacquers, organic and inorganic chemicals, cyanide and plating waste, clay and filter media containing chemicals, plating sludge, oil solids, and pesticides. The Site contains two Operable Units (OUs): OU1 – tanks and OU2 – remedy.  This boundary includes the boundaries of both OUs.

Site Name: SOLVENTS RECOVERY SERVICE OF NEW ENGLAND
Feature Name: Approximate Solvents Recovery Service of New Engla
Feature Description: The Solvents Recovery Service of New England site is located in Southington, Connecticut. Solvents Recovery Service operated a hazardous waste treatment and storage facility and received waste industrial solvents on site. Sludge were disposed of in two unlined lagoons from 1957 to 1967, when lagoons were drained and covered with fill. After the lagoons closed, wastes were burned in an open pit on site or disposed of off-site. In the 1970s, the state ordered the end of incineration activities.

Feature Name: Approximate Nutmeg Valley Road Site Boundary
Feature Description:
In 1992, EPA conducted an emergency response action at the PAR Finishing facility. Approximately 1,150 tons of sludge waste and contaminated soil were
removed from two unlined lagoons and shipped to an off-site disposal facility. This
action addressed threats posed by the electroplating wastes in surface soils, and removed a potential source of groundwater contamination. The study area was reduced to 28 acres when regional groundwater studies conducted by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) concluded that there was no evidence of a wide-spread contamination plume. In addition, the levels of contaminants in much of the area were decreasing over time through natural degradation processes. This boundary includes the study area.
Feature Source: U.S. EPA Region 1 - Site Reuse Profile, Exhibit 1, pg. 2

Feature Name: Approximate Western Sand & Gravel Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 25-acre Site is located in a rural area on the boundary of Burrillville and North Smithfield in Rhode Island. The area was the location of a sand and gravel quarry operation from 1953 until 1975. The site contains three operable units: OU-1 (waterline), OU-2 (cap), and OU-3 (off-site groundwater).

Feature Name: Approximate Yaworski Waste Lagoon Site Boundary
Feature Description:
The Yaworski Waste Lagoon Superfund Site received contaminated liquid wastes in bulk. 
 It is located on approximately 5 acres of land between Route 169 and Packer Road in the Town of Canterbury, Windham County, Connecticut.  The Site is bordered by the Quinebaug River on the north, west, and south, and by the State-regulated Yaworski/Packer Road Landfill to the east.

Feature Description:
The Stamina Mills Superfund Site (the Site), a former textile
weaving and finishing mill, is located in the Town of North
Smithfield, Providence County, Rhode Island. The Site is
located approximately one-half mile southwest of the
intersection of Highway 146 and 146A and is approximately 14 miles northwest of Providence, Rhode Island.

The Site, comprising approximately 5 acres, is bounded to the
south by the Branch River. A dam constructed immediately
adjacent to the Site forms the Forestdale Pond. The pond
forms the western boundary of the Site. The land to the north and east of the Site is largely residential with some commercial use.

Feature Name: Approximate Beacon Heights Landfill Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Beacon Heights Landfill site occupies about 34 acres and sits atop a ridge southeast of the intersection of Blackberry Hill and Skokorat Roads. The site operated as a dump from the 1920s until 1970. It consisted of approximately six acres of active dumping and open burning of both municipal refuse and industrial waste. The boundary includes the approximate area of the landfill.

Feature Name: Approximate Town Garage/Radio Beacon Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Town Garage/Radio Beacon site is located in Londonderry, New Hampshire. The area includes the Holton Circle neighborhood, the Town Garage property on High Range Road, a development of 20 homes called Saddlebrook and a wetland area. The site includes a series of residential wells and one commercial well, known as the Town Garage Well. Following extension of public water supplies to affected areas, ground water cleanup levels were attained and the site was deleted from the NPL in July 2014.

Feature Name: Approximate Nuclear Metals, Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Nuclear Metals, Inc. SIte -- also known as the Starmet Corporation Site -- is located on a 46-acre parcel in Concord, Massachusetts. Nuclear Metals made depleted uranium products, primarily for armor-piercing ammunition. It also manufactured metal powders for medical applications, photocopiers, and specialty metal products such as beryllium tubing used in the aerospace industry.

Feature Name: Approximate Laurel Park, Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Laurel Park, Inc. site is located in Naugatuck Borough, Connecticut. A landfill occupies about 20 acres of a 35-acre parcel of land. The landfill has been in existence since the late 1940s. Several industries disposed of solvents, oils, hydrocarbons, chemical and liquid sludge, chemical solids, tires and rubber products there. Facility operations led to soil, surface water and groundwater contamination.

Feature Description: The Microfab, Inc. (Former) Site is a 14-acre property in a mixed commercial and residential area of Amesbury, MA.  The  property includes a large 100,000 sq. ft. former factory building, a detached former wastewater treatment building, paved parking areas, undeveloped woods and wetlands.  The property has been unoccupied and the buildings abandoned since 1987.  Industrial operations were conducted between 1950 and 1987, and included metal parts manufacturing, printed circuit board production, electroplating, and other associated metal finishing.

Feature Description: The Barkhamsted-New Hartford Landfill site is located near the Barkhamsted-New Hartford town line in northwest Connecticut. The 98-acre area was an unlined landfill that leaked hazardous solvents and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the underlying groundwater. The landfill was capped in 1999. Groundwater is now being cleaned and monitored .

Feature Name: Approximate Walton & Lonsbury Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description:
The Walton & Lonsbury (“W&L) Superfund Site (the “Site”) is a former electroplating facility that operated from 1940 to 2007.  Untreated waste streams from the facility were discharged into the wetlands south of the property. Additionally, a batch wastewater treatment system for removal of metals and pH adjustment and the discharge of treated wastewater to a surface impoundment located west of the facility building. 
 Also, wastewater was discharged from the surface impoundment to a storm water trench and through the wetland area and ultimately into the Ten Mile River. 
As a result of these releases, contaminated groundwater plumes of trichloroethylene (TCE) and hexavalent chromium from the source area that is the former facility are migrating off site through a residential neighborhood to the east, and into the Bungay River.

Feature Description: The BJAT Superfund Site is located at 300 Fisher Street in Franklin, Norfolk County, Massachusetts. The BJAT property is approximately 18.3 acres. It is bounded to the northeast by commercial properties including the Town of Franklin Department of Public Works (DPW) facility; to the east and southeast by railroad tracks and residential properties; to the southwest by Interstate (I)-495; and to the northwest by several parcels owned by the Town of Franklin, consisting of open water, wetlands, woodland, and recreational areas. Public drinking water supply wells are located a little over a quarter mile to the northwest, there is also a town beach within one mile, and the closest school is located one-half a mile to the southwest of the property.

Feature Name: Approximate Jard Company, Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Jard Company property is located along Bowen Road in Bennington, Bennington County, Vermont. The 34-acre property was formerly occupied by a manufacturing facility that was demolished in 2005. The property is bordered to the north by industrial properties, to the south by the Roaring Branch of the Walloomsac River, to the east by woodlands and a Vermont Agency of Transportation district garage, and to the west by baseball fields and residences.

Feature Name: Approximate Troy Mills Landfill Site Boundary
Feature Description:
The Troy Mills Landfill Superfund Site (the Site) is a two-acre former drum disposal area
located approximately 1.5 miles south of the center of Troy, New Hampshire. The two acre Site is located in the southeastern corner of a larger 270-acre parcel. The Site was used by Troy Mills, Inc. to dispose of drums of hazardous substances that were generated at its manufacturing facility in the center of town. Immediately to the north of the Site is a
separate eight-acre solid waste landfill, regulated by the NHDES, which was used for the disposal of waste fabric scraps and other miscellaneous solid waste. The solid waste landfill is not considered part of the Site.  This is a single OU Site.
Feature Source: U.S. EPA Region 1 March 2014 ESD, page 3

Feature Description: The 92-acre Site is located in the towns of Greenland and North Hampton, Rockingham County, in New Hampshire. The Site is located about 400 to 800 feet west of Lafayette Road (U.S. Route 1), directly south of Breakfast Hill Road and about 2.5 miles northeast of the center of the town of North Hampton. The landfill covers about 27 acres in the southern part of the Site. The landfill borders undeveloped woodlands and wetlands to the north and west and commercial and residential properties to the east and south.

Feature Description: The McKin Company site is a 7 acre parcel that was formerly a gravel pit but later operated as a transfer station and disposal facility for waste oil and industrial process waste. The facility was expanded with the addition of an asphalt lined lagoon and incinerator to process a large volume of oily waste from an oil spill in Hussey Sound. This boundary includes around 600 acres which provides the Institutional Control Zone boundary for neighboring properties.

Feature Description: The Groveland Wells Nos. 1 & 2 Superfund Site is approximately 850-acres and is located in Groveland, Massachusetts and contained the Valley Manufacturing Products Company, which machined, degreased and finished metal parts and screws. The site contains two Operable Units (OUs): OU1 – Management of Migration, OU2 – Source Control. This boundary includes the current boundaries of both OUs.

Feature Name: Approximate Silresim Chemical Corp. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Silresim Chemical Corp. site is located at 86 Tanner Street in Lowell, Massachusetts. The site consists of the 4.5-acre Silresim property and soil and groundwater contamination that extends to other nearby properties. Starting in 1971, Silresim began reclaiming a variety of chemical wastes, waste oil, solvents and sludges containing heavy metals on site. In 1977, Silresim declared bankruptcy and abandoned the property, leaving behind 30,000 decaying drums and several large storage tanks. The state began to clean up the Site in 1978. Following construction of the site’s long-term remedy, groundwater treatment, operations and maintenance activities, and monitoring are ongoing.
Feature Source: U.S. EPA Region 1, Fifth Five Year Review, dated 2019, Figure 2A, page 29

Feature Name: Approximate Ely Copper Mine Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Ely Copper Mine Superfund Site (the Site) is an abandoned copper mine located in Vershire, Orange County, Vermont and encompasses approximately 350 acres where historic mining activities took place, including about 30 acres of waste material containing an estimated 172,000 tons of waste rock, tailings, ore roast beds, slag heaps, and smelter wastes.  The Site also includes over 3,000 linear feet of Underground Mine Workings along with the associated shafts and adits.

Feature Name: Approximate Savage Municipal Water Supply Site Bou
Feature Description: The Site includes a volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and metals groundwater plume that generally extends from the intersection of Route 101 and Elm Street eastward approximately 6,000 feet (ft). It is roughly bounded on the north and east by the Souhegan River and on the south by Elm Street and Tucker Brook. Operable Unit 1 (OU1), the OK Tool Source Area, is the portion of the plume where levels of groundwater contamination are the highest. Operable Unit 2 (OU2) is the extended plume. OU1 is fund-lead and managed by EPA and NHDES while the settling defendants (SDs) are responsible for the remedy in OU2.

Feature Name: Approximate Creese and Cook Tannery (Former) Site
Feature Description:
The Creese & Cook Tannery (Former) Site was the former location of leather tannery facilities that operated from the 1870’s until the early 1980’s on the east and west sides of the Crane River and used raw animal hides to produce leather shoes, handbags, gloves, and garment leather. 
The Site, contains three Operable Units (OUs): OU1 – the East Study Area, OU2 – the West Study Area, OU3 - the Crane River.  This boundary includes all three OUs and consists of nine properties: 33 Water Street, 35 Water Street, 45 Water Street, 12 Cheever Street, 20 Cheever Street, and the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) Right of Way (ROW), 27 Clinton Avenue, 55 Clinton Avenue, and 15 Pleasant Street.
Feature Source: U.S. EPA Region 1, Record of Decision, 2019

Feature Name: Approxmate Darling Hill Dump Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Darling Hill Dump site is an inactive dump on about 3.5 acres at the top of a steep hill along Darling Hill Road in rural Lyndon, Vermont. From 1952 to 1989, the dump was used for the disposal of municipal and industrial wastes, including metal plating rinse waters, alkali degreasers and organic solvents. The investigation of the site revealed only low levels of contamination in the ground water. Carbon filters were installed on the public water supply to remove the low-level contamination. EPA determined that no cleanup action was necessary and took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 1999.

Feature Description: The 58-acre Davis (GSR) Landfill site includes a 21-acre inactive landfill located in the Towns of Glocester and Smithfield, RI. Between 1974 and 1976, the landfill, which was privately owned and licensed by the State to accept municipal wastes, accepted wastes from Glocester, Smithfield, Warwick, and Providence. Site contains only OU1, the landfill.

Feature Name: Approximate Blackburn and Union Privileges Site
Feature Description: The Blackburn and Union Privileges Superfund Site is located approximately one-half mile south-southeast of the center of Walpole, Massachusetts. Industrial and commercial processes on the Site date back to the 1600s.  At various points, the Site was used for manufacturing tires, rubber goods, cotton products, and insulating materials - including the crushing of raw asbestos in the manufacture of brake and clutch linings. As a result of these industrial operations, soil, sediment and groundwater are contaminated with inorganic chemicals (including asbestos and metals), VOCs, PAHs, and highly alkaline compounds.

Feature Name: Approximate Kearsarge Metallurgical Corp. Site Bou
Feature Description: The 9-acre Kearsarge Metallurgical Corporation (KMC) is located in Conway, New Hampshire on the north shore of Pequawket Pond. KMC made precision stainless steel castings on site from 1964 until the company went out of business in 1982. The manufacturing process produced castings using the lost-wax process. That process created waste casting sands, wax and solvents that KMC dumped in a wooded wetland just east of the facility.

Feature Description: The 41-acre sitee in Berlin, New Hampshire lies on the east bank of the Androscoggin River bounded to the north by Bridge Street and Sawmill Dam, to the east by Hutchins Street, and to the south by the remainder of the former paper plant, now a biomass energy facility.  The Site includes a 4.6-acre landfill containing construction debris, capped by a low-permeability membrane and 2-feet of woodchips.  The remainder of the Site is vacant with shrubs and successional trees interspersed with wetlands, dirt roads, and isolated industrial debris.

Feature Name: Approximate Iron Horse Park Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 553-acre Iron Horse Park Superfund Site is located in North Billerica, Massachusetts. It is an industrial complex that includes manufacturing and rail yard maintenance facilities, open storage areas, landfills, and wastewater lagoons. A long history of industrial activities at the Site, beginning in 1913, has resulted in the contamination of soil, groundwater, sediment, and surface water. Contaminants of concern are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, volatile organic compounds, and metals. The site contains four operable units (OUs): OU1 – B&M Waste Water Lagoons, OU2 - Shaffer Landfill, OU3 - Source Control, and OU4 - Sitewide Sediment and Groundwater. This boundary includes the boundaries of all four OUs.

Feature Description: The Keddy Mill site (the “Site”) is located at 7 Depot Street in the Little Falls portion of Windham, Maine. The Site consists of approximately 6.93 acres and is located in a mixed commercial/residential area. It is bounded by Depot Street to the north, a former Maine Central Railroad right-of-way to the east, undeveloped property and the Presumpscot River to the south, and by Route 202/Main Street and an operational hydroelectric facility to the west. The Site is currently vacant and is largely covered with a two-story concrete/brick industrial mill building constructed on a concrete/soil foundation with a full basement level. This building was reportedly constructed in the early 1900s. The Site formerly contained several other industrial buildings which have since been demolished. The Site is currently fenced and there are no known private drinking water sources (i.e.; drilled water supply wells) located at or in close proximity to the Site.

Feature Name: Approximate New London Submarine Base Site Boundar
Feature Description:
Naval Submarine Base New London (NSB NLON) is located in southeastern Connecticut in the Towns of Ledyard and Groton and is situated on the eastern bank of the Thames River, approximately 6 miles north of Long Island Sound. NSB NLON provides base operations support for Navy submarine forces and other Naval organizations and tenants, accommodating submarine training facilities, military offices, medical facilities, and facilities for submarine maintenance, repair, and overhaul, as well as housing and support services for Navy personnel.
NSB NLON consists of approximately 200 buildings on 687 acres, and several environmental sites comprising 12 Operable Units. NSB NLON is surrounded by fencing, and access is controlled via gates with armed guards. Industrial, administrative, and training activities occur in the southern portion of NSB NLON (southern valley) and along the Thames River. In the northern portion of NSB NLON (northern valley) are streams, a wetland, and a golf course.
Feature Source: Contractor, but also in Final Fifth Five-Year Review Report dated Dec. 2021

Feature Description: Army Materials Technology Laboratory (AMTL) Site consists of 48 acres of land located in Watertown, MA. Established in 1816, AMTL was originally used for the storage, cleaning, and issuance of small arms, but later expanded to include ammunition and pyrotechnics production. Arms manufacturing continued until a phase down in 1967. The Site was placed on the National Priority List in May 1994. Also in 1994, AMTL was placed on the Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC94) list. There were a total of 3 Operable Units at the Site including: OU1 Zones 1-4 (AMTL industrial Site) and Zone 5 (Charles River Park) and adjacent Watertown Yacht Club, OU2, which is the Charles River, and OU3, which is within the areal boundary of Zones 1-4 but is designated for residential use. At the time of the last FYR only OU1 Zones 1-5 remain unsuitable for unlimited use and unrestricted exposure and are subject to institutional controls.

Site Name: NATICK LABORATORY ARMY RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, AND ENGINEERING CENTER
Feature Name: Approximate Natick Laboratory Army Research, Devel
Feature Description:
U.S. Army Natick Soldier
Systems Center (NSSC) is an active U.S. Army research and testing facility located approximately 17 miles west-southwest of Boston. The facility was formerly called the Quartermaster Research and Engineering Command and subsequently the U.S. Army Natick Research and Development Command. It has been a permanent U.S. Army installation since October 1954. NSSC’s
mission includes research and development activities in food service and food, clothing, equipment, materials, and aero-mechanical engineering. Environmental investigations began at NSSC in the 1980s. NSSC was added to the National Priorities list in May 1994 due to groundwater contamination found in the T-25 area and its location relative to the Natick Springvale Municipal Water Supply Well Field, which is located 2,500 feet (ft) to the northwest.  Groundwater extraction and treatment from the T-25 area and others is ongoing.

Feature Name: Approximate Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant
Feature Description: The Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant, Bedford Site (NWIRP) is located in eastern Massachusetts in the Town of Bedford, in Middlesex County, Massachusetts. The property, which is in the southwest portion of Bedford, is approximately 14 miles northwest of downtown Boston. It is bounded by the Lawrence G. Hanscom Field (Hanscom Field) and Hanscom Air Force Base (HAFB) to the south; by Raytheon Electronic Systems Facility, a Patriot Integration Test Facility, wetlands, and residences to the west; by woods and wetlands to the north; and by woods, residences, and wetlands to the east.  NWIRP’s mission was to design, fabricate, and test prototype equipment for missile guidance and control systems.

Feature Name: Approximate Fort Devens-Sudbury Training Annex Sit
Feature Description: The former Fort Devens Sudbury Training Annex site is located in the towns of Hudson, Stowe, Maynard, and Sudbury in eastern Massachusetts. The area was an active facility until it closed under the Defense Base Realignment and Closure Act of 1995. Wastes generated by the facility while it was operating contaminated soil and groundwater. After cleanup, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2002. Ownership of most of the site property transferred to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service as the Assabet River National Wildlife Refuge in 2005.

Feature Description: EPA placed the site on the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 1987.? The former Brunswick Naval Air Station in Brunswick, Maine, closed in May 2011 under the federal Defense Base Realignment and Closure Act of 2005. Wastes generated by the U.S. Navy when the base was an active military installation have contaminated soil and ground water across portions of the former air station. An October 1990 agreement established the responsibilities of the Navy, the Maine Department of Environmental Protection and EPA in studying contamination at the site and cleaning the former base’s roughly 3,100 acres?, and the Navy continues to conduct site contaminant investigations and cleanup activities.

Feature Name: Approximate Loring Air Force Base Site Boundary
Feature Description: The former Loring Air Force Base is located in the town of Limestone in northern Aroostook County, Maine. EPA added the site to the National Priorities List in 1990 due to contamination from waste oils, fuels cleaned from aircraft and vehicles, spent solvents, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), pesticides and three on-site landfills. ? The facility officially closed in September 1994 under the Defense Base Realignment and Closure Act of 1991. Wastes generated by the U.S. Air Force when the facility was an active military installation contaminated soil, groundwater, surface water and sediment at a number of areas across the former base. Despite its closure as an active base, the Air Force is doing the cleanup needed until cleanup goals have been achieved.

Feature Name: Approximate Pease Air Force Base Site Boundary
Feature Description: The former Pease Air Force Base is located in Portsmouth and Newington, New Hampshire. The facility officially closed in April 1991 under the Defense Base Realignment and Closure Act of 1988. Wastes generated by the U.S. Air Force when the facility was active have contaminated soil, groundwater, surface water and sediment across the former base. A Federal Facility Agreement finalized in April 1991 established the responsibilities of the Air Force, the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES) and EPA for cleanup at the 4,365-acre site. EPA issued an Administrative Order under the Safe Drinking Water Act requiring the design and construction of two treatment systems to address groundwater contamination that continues to threaten drinking water supplies while also expediting the investigation and cleanup of the emerging contaminants PFOA and PFOS in the aquifer.  Both groundwater treatment systems are operational and removing PFAS from extracted groundwater.

Feature Name: Approximate Davis Liquid Waste Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Davis Liquid Waste Superfund Site lies between Tarkiln and Log Roads in the northwest section of Smithfield, Rhode Island and consists of a 7-acre source area bounded to the east and west by forested wetlands and the north and south by wetlands. Surface water drains into Latham Brook and eventually enters Stillwater Reservoir, a tributary to the Woonasquatucket River. Throughout the 1970s, the owner disposed of a variety of liquid and solid wastes containing hazardous substances.

Feature Name: Approximate GE - Housatonic River Site Boundary
Feature Description: Since the early 1900s, GE operated a large-scale industrial facility including the manufacturing and servicing of power transformers, defense and aerospace, and plastics, and used numerous industrial chemicals at its Pittsfield facility - including the manufacture and servicing of electrical transformers containing PCBs. Years of PCB and industrial chemical use, and improper disposal, led to extensive contamination around Pittsfield, MA as well as down the entire length of the Housatonic River.

Feature Name: Approximate Kellogg-Deering Well Field Site Bounda
Feature Description: The Kellogg-Deering Well Field site is in Norwalk, Connecticut. It consists of a 10-acre municipal well field and adjacent areas that contributed to the well field contamination. Groundwater sampling identified a significant source of contamination below the Elinco/Pitney Bowes/Matheis Court Complex at the eastern edge of the site. Following construction of the site’s long-term remedy, groundwater treatment and environmental monitoring are ongoing. The site boundary is inclusive of existing and potential Operational Units.

Feature Name: Approximate Dover Municipal Landfill Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Dover Municipal Landfill Superfund Site is located to the west of Tolend Road in the western corner of the City of Dover, New Hampshire. The Site is bordered by rural, residential properties along Tolend Road to the north and undeveloped forested wetlands to the south, east, and west. The Cocheco River and Bellamy Reservoir are located approximately 600 feet northeast and 1,500 feet south of the Site, respectively. The landfill covers approximately 50 acres and, contrary to typical landfill profiles, is quite flat and covered mostly in grasses, but has stands of poplar trees on the older portions of the landfill. A detailed description of the Site is contained in the 2004 AROD. This is a single Operable Unit (OU) Site and this boundary includes the former landfill plus the extent of the groundwater contamination as defined by the NHDES GMZ from the September 2014 NHDES Groundwater Management Permit.

Feature Description: The Saco Municipal Landfill site includes four separate landfill areas the cover approximately 30 acres. Wastes disposed of in the landfills included municipal, industrial and construction waste, and sludge from a nearby former tannery wastewater treatment system. This boundary includes the approximate full parcel with the four separate landfill areas.

Feature Name: Site Boundary of Lehigh Valley Railroad - OU1 and OU2
Feature Description: The Lehigh Valley Railroad site is the location of a chemical spill that resulted from a train derailment in 1970. About 1 ton of cyanide crystals and around 30,000 to 35,000 gallons of trichloroethene (TCE) spilled onto the ground, contaminating soil and groundwater. The Site consists of OU1 and OU2.

Feature Description: The Rockaway Borough Wellfield Superfund site includes three municipal water supply wells (numbered as 1, 5, and 6), which are located off of Union Street in the eastern section of Rockaway Borough. The groundwater at the municipal water supply wells was impacted primarily with tetrachloroethene (PCE) and trichloroethene (TCE). Based on early site investigations, the suspected sources of the TCE and PCE contamination included industrial and commercial operations within Rockaway Borough, including the K&K facility and the WS/EM area.

Feature Description: The Burnt Fly Bog site is in a semi-rural area located near the intersection of Texas and Spring Valley Roads in Marlboro Township, Monmouth County, New Jersey. A portion of the site is also in Old Bridge Township, Middlesex County. The site area includes approximately 60 acres affected by lead, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and Extractable Petroleum Hydrocarbon (EPH) contamination and is part of a larger area, composed mostly of wetlands, known as Burnt Fly Bog. The site contains three operable units (OUs): OU1- Uplands Area, OU2- Westerly Wetlands and Downstream Area, and OU3- Westerly Wetlands, Tar Patch Area, and Northerly Wetlands. This boundary includes the boundaries of all four OUs

Feature Description: The Metaltec/Aerosystems Site (Site) is located on a 15 1/2 -acre property in a rural/residential area. The Site consists of two Operable Units (OUs). OU1 addressed contaminated soils that presented an unacceptable risk and/or a source of contamination to the groundwater. OU2 addressed contaminated groundwater. The OU1 remedy has been completed and soils have been remediated to levels that allow for unrestricted use. The OU2 groundwater restoration remedy is ongoing and is is currently operated by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection.

Feature Description: The Site is located in Shamong Township, Burlington County, New Jersey, off Tuckerton Road, near Route 206. The Site is shown on the Shamong Township tax map as Block 23, Lots 31.01 and 32.02. The Site is 43 acres, of which nine acres are fenced. The original bulk disposal-site area, known as Area A, is roughly four acres. The property that constitutes the Site is privately owned. In June 2011, the owner conveyed a Deed of Conservation Easement for the property to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (NJDEP). The Conservation Easement will assure that the conservation value of the property will be conserved and maintained in perpetuity. This Site is located within the Central Pine Barrens Preservation Area of the New Jersey Pinelands, and is viewed as an ecologically sensitive area.

Feature Description: The Marathon Battery Company Superfund site is located in Cold Spring, New York. The 70-acre site includes a now-demolished nickel-cadmium battery plant and 11 surrounding acres, the Hudson River in the vicinity of the Cold Spring pier and a series of river backwater areas known as Foundry Cove and Constitution Marsh. East Foundry Cove and Marsh and the former factory grounds are subject to Five Year Reviews.

Feature Description: The Site is in Marlboro Township, Monmouth County, New Jersey in a predominantly residential area. It is in two parts. At the facility, various chemical were processed. Two areas, known as Off-Site areas 1&2, are located approximately 220 feet and 700 feet northwest of the facility, respectively. The Site consists of three operable units (OUs). OU1 addresses off-Site areas of contamination including contaminated soil and sediment in and adjacent to wetlands, the Birch Swamp Brook and its floodplain, and contaminated soil located on six residential properties near the former facility. The remedial action for OU1 has been completed. OU2 addresses contaminated groundwater through monitored natural attenuation after the source of contamination was removed during OU3. This in ongoing. OU3 addressed contaminated soil and other materials through removal and was completed in January 2012.
Feature Info URL Description: Each of the 3 OUs have their own Remedial Investigation Reports

Feature Description: The Site is in Logan Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey, approximately 1 mile east of Bridgeport, New Jersey (Figure 1). The CLTL property encompasses approximately 31.4 acres of former farmland and wetlands with an active tank-washing terminal area occupying 14.1 acres. The Site is situated at the intersection of Cedar Swamp Road and Oak Grove Road. Portions of Cedar Swamp lie adjacent to the CLTL facility to the east, southeast, and northeast. A Conrail railroad line borders the Site to the north and separates it from several private residences along Route 44. The CLTL terminal property is zoned for industrial use. The Site contains three operable unit, all of which are included in this boundary.

Feature Description: The Site is a 24-acre, former scrap iron and metal reclamation facility on Cape Road, a.k.a., Cape Avenue, in the Village of Ellenville, Town of Wawarsing, Ulster County, New York. The Site also includes select residential properties in the vicinity, located on Cape Road and River Street. The Site is bound to the north by Cape Road; to the south and west by the Beer Kill, a.k.a., Beer Kill Creek, and forested lands; and, to the east by residential properties. Approximately 10 acres of the Site had been used for a variety of scrap metal operations and, while operational, were also used for battery reclamation.

Feature Description: The Brick Township Landfill, aka McCormick's Dump (1940-1968) and French's Landfill (1969-1973), is located in the Herbertsville section of the Township of Brick, between the Garden State Parkway and Sally Ike Road. The Site is approximately 40.7 acres in size and currently consists of mostly vegetated land. The Landfill is bound to the north, southwest, and east by residential single family homes and condominium units; to the south/southeast by Sally Ike Road with school athletic fields beyond. The vegetated former landfill rises about 40 feet above its surroundings, and is terraced to facilitate vehicular access. The vertical separation between the waste and the groundwater surface ranges between 10 and 20 feet. Contaminated groundwater extends out from the Landfill to the southeast. Discontinuous and sporadic site related groundwater contamination occurs in an area of roughly 470 acres. There are no known operating drinking water wells within the area of groundwater contamination.

Feature Description: The Ringwood Mines/Landfill Site includes 500 acres in Upper Ringwood which were owned by the Ford Motor Company during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Waste from Ford's former Mahwah facility were disposed of in two large mine pits, a former mine tailings disposal area, as well as along roadsides in this area. The site contains three operable units (OUs): OU1 - Comprehensive Cleanup, OU2 - Peters Mine Pit, Cannon Mine Pit and the O'Connor Disposal Area and OU3 - Groundwater and Mine Water.
Feature Source: The original boundary of 2007 Workforce Support Study was updated per RPM's directions.

Feature Description: The GSC site is located on Summer Roadin Minotola, Buena Borough, New Jersey, approximately 30 miles southeast of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The land hydraulically downgradient of the Sites is occupied primarily by residences and small businesses. A recreational area lies adjacent to the Cleary Junior High School (Cleary School), located approximately 2,000 feet south of the Sites. The land surrounding Buena Borough is primarily agricultural. Buena Borough is one of 56 municipalities within the New Jersey Pinelands National Reserve. GSC operated a dry-cleaning business from 1966 until 2011 on the property. The GSC building was demolished in 2011 and the property is vacant. The GSC property occupies an area of approximately 3,000 square feet.

Feature Description: Radiation Technology, Inc. (RTI) is a 263-acre site near Lake Denmark in Rockaway Township, New Jersey. Improper storage and disposal of waste drums containing solvents and other organic chemicals at the site contaminated soil, sediment, and groundwater with hazardous substances. Since 1972, operations on site have included radiation sterilization, producing architectural products, and producing and finishing hardwood flooring. From November 1980 to May 1981, NJDEP and the Rockaway Township Health Department conducted investigations at the site. Cleanup of contamination at the site has been divided into three distinct areas –groundwater, the drum material and soil, and the buildings and structures. EPA placed the site on the Superfund National Priorities List (NPL) in September 1984.

Feature Description: The Site, owned by Republic Services, Inc. (Republic), is located along New Road about one half mile northwest of U.S. Route 1 in South Brunswick, Middlesex County, New Jersey. The Site occupies an area of approximately 68 acres. SBLF was placed on the National Priorities List (NPL) in December 1982. A cleanup action was initiated in May 1983 and was completed by May 1985 and consisted of installation of a low permeability soil cap, a leachate collection system, a low permeability slurry wall around the perimeter of the waste disposal area, a passive landfill gas venting system, and a security fence around the perimeter of the property. In 2018, a commercial solar power project was developed on the landfill and involved the installation of 40,000 solar panels across the landfill surface. Development, operation, and maintenance of this project is conducted by New Jersey Resources (NJR) and Clean Energy Ventures (CEV). The project was fully completed and generating power by July 2018.

Feature Name: Approximate extend of the contamination at the Lawrence Aviation Industries Superfund site.
Feature Description: The Lawrence Aviation Industries Superfund Site manufactured titanium sheet metal for the aeronautics industry and consumer products such as golf clubs. The 42-acre LAI industrial facility ceased operations in 2003. Past disposal practices have resulted in releases of various contaminants including trichloroethene (TCE), tetrachloroethene (PCE), acid wastes, oils, sludge, heavy metals, and other industrial plant wastes. The Site consists of one OU, which addresses contaminated source areas and groundwater contamination.

Feature Name: Applied Environmental Service/Shore Realty Site Boundary
Feature Description: The AES/Shore Realty Site is an approximately 3.2 acre former petroleum terminal and waste solvent storage and recycling facility. The Shore Realty property was first used for fuel storage purposes in 1939 by Texaco Oil Company. Starting in 1974, the Site was used for the storage and distribution of chemical solvents by Mattiace Petrochemical Company. Numerous spills of organic chemicals reportedly occurred during this period.

Feature Description: The BROS Superfund site is a 30-acre property in Logan Township, New Jersey. From 1960 to 1981, the site was a waste oil storage and recovery facility that included a waste lagoon and tank farm. The vessels and tanks stored 2.5 million gallons of oil contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-contaminated sediments and sludge, and 70 million gallons of contaminated wastewater. Groundwater underlying the site and extending about 6,000 feet from the lagoon was contaminated with PCBs and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

Feature Description: The SJCC site is a 1.2-acre property located on the northwest corner of Central and Atlantic Avenues in Minotola, Buena Borough, New Jersey, approximately 30 miles southeast of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The land hydraulically downgradient of the Sites is occupied primarily by residences and small businesses. The land surrounding Buena Borough is primarily agricultural. Buena Borough is one of 56 municipalities within the New Jersey Pinelands National Reserve. SJCC was a dry cleaner that operated from the 1940s to the 1980s and is now defunct. A line of the Central Railroad of New Jersey runs adjacent to the northwest property boundary of SJCC.

Feature Description: The Helen Kramer Landfill site, located in Mantua Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey, encompassed a 66-acre refuse area, and an 11-acre area between the eastern limit of the refuse and Edwards Run that had contained stressed vegetation prior to EPA’s remedial action. Edwards Run is a surface water tributary to Mantua Creek and the Delaware River. The site is near Mantua's border with East Greenwich Township.

Feature Description: The Kin-Buc Landfill site is an inactive, closed municipal solid and industrial waste landfill located at 383 Meadow Road in Edison Township, Middlesex County, New Jersey. The site occupies approximately 220 acres and is bounded to the north by an industrial park, to the west by the Raritan River, and to the east by Edmonds Creek, which drains to a tidal wetland area before discharging to the Raritan River. The Edison Township Municipal Landfill is approximately 600 feet to the south, and the closed ILR Landfill is approximately one mile to the east. The northernmost boundary of Edgeboro Landfill is located approximately one half mile southwest of the site on the opposite side of the Raritan River. This boundary includes the boundaries of both Operable Units (OUs).
Feature Source: Tetra Tech; 2013 Annual Monitoring Report, Kin-Buc Landfill OUs 1 and 2, Fig. 2, pg. 20

Feature Description: The North Sea Landfill site is a 131-acre parcel that was constructed in 1963 for the disposal of municipal solid waste, refuse and septic system waste. The landfill accepted waste from residential, industrial and commercial sources and comprised of three landfill cells and sludge lagoons. The site contains two operable units (OUs): OU1 - contamination of Cell #1, the former sludge lagoons and on-site groundwater and OU2 - off-site groundwater and Fish Cove (no action). The site boundary includes the landfill parcel and associated groundwater contamination plume.

Feature Description: The Wolff-Alport Chemical Company (WACC) site (Site) comprises an area of radiological contamination at 1127 Irving Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, New York on the border of Bushwick, Brooklyn. The Site includes the former WACC property, a roughly triangular area of approximately 0.75 acres that is now subdivided into several commercial properties, as well as adjacent areas including streets, sidewalks, commercial and residential properties, and the sewer system where contaminants have migrated or have the potential to migrate in the future.

Feature Name: Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics OU1 McCaffrey Street Site Approximate Property Boundary
Feature Description: The Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics site is in Hoosick Falls, New York. The Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics facility continues to operate at 14 McCaffrey Street. The McCaffrey Street facility, built in 1961, manufactured circuit board laminates, polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-coated fiberglass and other PTFE products. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics purchased the facility in 1999 and began manufacturing operations that used perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA).
Feature Source: 2019 C.T. MALE ASSOCIATES IRM Work Plan-Groundwater Capture and Treatment, Figure 2 Site Layout Map

Feature Description: The Dewey Loeffel Landfill site consists of an approximately 19-acre landfill (former waste disposal area), as well as the associated groundwater and drainageways (surface water bodies). The site contains four operable units (OUs): OU00 - Groundwater Extraction and Treatment System, OU01 - Landfill/Groundwater, OU02 - Drainageways, and OU03 - Tributary T11A. This boundary includes the boundary of the landfill proper, but does not include groundwater and drainageways associated with the site.

Feature Description: The SCCC Site consists of approximately 42 acres in an industrial area of the Town of Kearny, Hudson County, New Jersey. It includes the 25-acre former SCCC property located at 1025-1035 Belleville Turnpike and a 13-acre portion of the adjacent property commonly referred to as the Seaboard property. Together, the SCCC property and 13-acre portion of the Seaboard property are designated as Area 1 of the SCCC Site. The SCCC Site also includes 3.8 acres that consist primarily of the Belleville Turnpike, Newark Turnpike, and associated right-of-ways and steep embankments, which are designated as Area 2 of the SCCC Site.
Feature Source: SCCC Site Performing Parties Group, Final 100% Remedial Design, June 2020, Figure C-003

Feature Description: The Matteo & Sons, Inc. Superfund site is located in West Deptford, NJ. Site Name: ICELAND COIN LAUNDRY AREA GW PLUME
Feature Description: The site consist of the former Iceland Coin Laundry and Dry Cleaner facility and associated with the volatile organic compounds (VOC)-contaminated groundwater plume. The facility consists of a 1,700-square foot building and adjacent parking areas on approximately 1.4 acres. The facility was operated as a dry cleaner from about 1953 until at least 1971 where four coin-operated dry cleaning units of 8 pound capacity were present, each using 4 gallons of tetrachloroethene (PCE). The plume extends from the facility approximately 8,500 feet to the southwest beneath numerous properties to the banks of the Maurice River. The plume is based on sampling data and fate and transport modeling.

Feature Name: White Chemical Corp. Superfund Site Boundary
Feature Description: The White Chemical Corporation Superfund Site (the Site) is approximately 4.4 acres in size, and is located at 660 Frelinghuysen Avenue, in the City of Newark, Essex County, New Jersey. The Site is bounded by the Conrail and New Jersey Transit rail lines to the east, and manufacturing facilities to the north, south, and west. It is one-half mile from the Newark International Airport. This boundary includes the boundaries of all three Operable Units (OUs).

Feature Name: Caldwell Trucking OUs 1 and 2 boundary; Classification Exception Area boundary
Feature Description: The site property and source area consists of Lot 17 of Block 2201 and Lots 7, 18, and 20 of Block 2302 in the Township of Fairfield, Essex County, New Jersey. The 11.25-acre property is located in the eastern portion of the Township, between O’Connor Drive and Sherwood Lane, immediately east of Passaic Avenue. The site contains two operable units (OUs). The site has a Classification Exception Area (CEA) that prevents groundwater consumption within the area of the plume. This boundary includes the boundaries of both OUs and the CEA.

Feature Name: Diamond Head Oil Refinery Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Diamond Head Oil Refinery Site, located in Kearny, New Jersey, is characterized by contamination from a former waste oil reprocessing facility and is comprised of approximately 40 acres, identified as Areas A, B, and C. Area A consists of a 15-acre unoccupied parcel that includes the remnants of the former Diamond Head Oil Refinery facility on the eastern portion of the parcel, wetland areas, a drainage ditch, a small wetland/pond, and a vegetated landfill area along the western border of the parcel (also referred to as the Diamond Head property). Areas B and C include contamination identified on approximately 25 acres of land outside of the former Diamond Head property, and consist of Interstate Highway 280 (I-280) rights-of-way (ROWs) and exit ramp cloverleaf interchanges. This boundary includes two Operable Units (OUs), OU1 and OU2.
Feature Source: Jacobs Engineering Group Inc.; 2020 Final Pre-Design Investigation Report, Fig. 2-8, pg. 90

Feature Name: Facet Enterprises, Inc. Superfund Site OUs 1, 2 and 3 boundary
Feature Description: The site is located in the Village of Elmira Heights, Chemung County, New York. The Facility is bounded to the north by a municipal golf course, to the east by New York State Route 14, to the south by 18th Street, and to the west by residential properties. The site includes a 31-acre parcel of land, which was extensively used for various manufacturing purposes in the past. The site is being addressed in three remedial phases, or operable units (OUs). Operable Unit One (OU1) addresses contaminated soil, sediment, and groundwater at the Facet Enterprises, Inc. facility (the Facility). OU2 is intended to address contaminated groundwater that extends downgradient from the Facility. OU3 addresses vapor intrusion at residential and commercial properties within the vapor intrusion study area in Elmira Heights, New York. The Village of Elmira Heights is a mixture of residential, commercial and industrial development and wooded land.
Feature Source: OU1 Source: EPA Facet Five-Year Review, 2012. OU2 Source: PRP. OU3 Source: recently created

Feature Description: The Rolling Knolls Superfund Site is a former landfill located in Chatham Township, NJ. The landfill covers approximately 170 acres, including 140 acres characterized by a relatively thin (18 feet or less) layer of waste material overlying native soil and 30 acres with isolated areas of debris on the surface. The majority of the site (approximately 140 acres) is owned by a private party and approximately 30 acres of the site are owned by the U.S. Department of Interior (DOI) and managed by the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) as part of the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge.

Feature Description: Naval Weapons Station Earle is located in Colts Neck (10,248 acres) and in Middletown (706 aces). Since the early 1940s, the U.S. Navy has renovated, stored and maintained munitions at the station. These operations involve preserving and maintaining ammunition, missile components and explosives. The site is comprised of approximately 21 smaller sites which are at different stages of the remedial process and are grouped into Operable Units (OU). This boundary includes boundaries for all the sites within the OUs.

Feature Name: Global Sanitary Landfill OUs 1 and 2 boundary; Classification Exception Area
Feature Description: The Global Sanitary Landfill site is approximately 60 acres in size. The northeastern property line is also the municipal boundary between Old Bridge Township and the Borough of Sayreville. The site is bordered by wetlands to the northeast, southeast, and southwest and is in the drainage basin of Cheesequake Creek. The site contains two operable units (OUs). OU1 addresses slope stabilization; landfill capping; gas, storm water and leachate management; perimeter security fence; and implementation of a monitoring program. OU2 addresses contaminant migration from the landfill into groundwater, surface water, sediment, soil, and wetlands. The site also has a Classification Exception Area (CEA) which prevents groundwater use. This boundary includes the boundaries of both OUs and the CEA.

Feature Description: MSP was added to the Superfund National Priority List in 1999. Under Superfund, the site is being addressed by two Operable Units (OUs). The first OU addressed the on-site and off-site soil contamination, and the cleanup was completed in 2010. OU2 addresses groundwater contamination which is present on-site and extends off-site. The cleanup design is being prepared and is expected to be implemented in the future. This boundary represents the boundaries of the MSP property and does not include off-site groundwater contamination or off-site soil contamination, regardless of its cleanup status.
Feature Source: Shapefiles from U.S. Army Corps of Engineers

Feature Name: This is the approximately site boundary for the Claremont Polychemical site OU1-OU6.
Feature Description: The Claremont Polychemical site was a former manufacturer of pigments for plastics and inks, coated metal flakes, and vinyl stabilizers that operated from 1966 to 1980. During its operation, the owner disposed of liquid waste in three leaching basins and deposited solid wastes and treatment sludges in drums or in old, aboveground metal tanks. The site consists of 6 OUs. The Site is located in a commercial/industrial area and at least three other known sources of groundwater contamination are located nearby to the east and upgradient of the Claremont Polychemical site.
Feature Source: Report.HW.130015.2021-11-02.Quarterly GW Report Q3-2021, Fig 31, page 59

Feature Name: Carroll and Dubies Sewage Disposal site approximately boundary of OU1 and OU2
Feature Description: The Site consists of OU1 and OU2. The Site was used as a disposal facility consisting of a series of lagoons. The majority of wastes disposed in the lagoons were septic waste, municipal sewage sludge, solid waste, as well as liquid industrial wastes, primarily from the cosmetic industry. OU1 addresses the lagoon area and OU2 addresses the groundwater contamination.

Feature Description: LCP Chemicals, Inc., a division of the Hanlin Group, Inc., purchased the 26-acre chlorine production facility in 1972 from GAF Corporation, which owned and operated the facility since 1942. LCP operated the facility from 1972 through 1985, when it ceased operations. Sludge containing mercury from the chlorine production was discharged to lagoons. In 1972, 1974 and 1979, the State of New Jersey documented releases from the brine sludge lagoon into South Branch Creek. Over the years, portions of the site and buildings were leased to other companies, including Union Carbide, Microcell Technologies and Kuehne Chemical Company. In July 1991, Hanlin Group, Inc. filed for bankruptcy. Following investigations, EPA placed the site on the Superfund program’s National Priorities List in July 1998. The 26-acre LCP Chemicals, Inc. site is located in an industrial area on the Tremley Point peninsula next to the Arthur Kill in Linden.
Feature Source: EPA Region 2 - 2014 Record of Decision and RPM instruction.
