Feature Name: Cayuga County Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site Areas 1, 2, and 3
Feature Description: The Cayuga Groundwater Contamination site includes contaminated groundwater that covers about 4.8 square miles from Auburn to Union Springs, New York. The site contains mostly residential properties mixed with farmland, woodlands and commercial areas. The plume extends from the Powerex facility in Auburn to the Village of Union Springs a distance of seven miles. The site includes two operable units, consisting of three Areas (Area 1, Area 2, and Area 3). Area 1 consists of the impacted area immediately south of the Powerex facility a facility formerly operated by Powerex, Inc., in the City of Auburn, New York, which is a major source of groundwater contamination and extends approximately 700 to 900 feet south of West Genesee Street. Area 2 consists of the impacted area immediately south-southwest of Area 1, and extends southwest to the Town of Aurelius. Area 3 consists of the impacted area immediately south and southwest of Area 2, extending to, and including Union Springs Village.

Feature Name: Woodbrook Road Dump Site OU1; Block 388, Lots 1 and 26. A portion of the contamination extends into Block 388,Lot 1.01 owned by South Plainfield.
Feature Description: The Woodbrook Road Dump Site is located primarily on two properties in South Plainfield identified as Block 388, Lots 1 and 26 in Middlesex County, New Jersey. The two properties cover approximately 70 acres of heavily wooded and undeveloped land within the vicinity of the Dismal Swamp. Dumps were operated on the two properties by previous owners during the 1940s and 1950s, accepting household and industrial wastes until shut down by the State of New Jersey in 1958. Texas Eastern Terminal Company (TETC) acquired the properties in 1972. The Site is transected by the northwest-flowing Bound Brook, which forms the boundary between Lot 1 on the east and Lot 26 on the west. A portion of the Site, Lot 1.01 of Block 388, is owned by the Borough of South Plainfield. The boundary includes Lots 1 and 26 owned by TETC only which make up OU1, the only OU for the site.

Feature Name: Ciba Geigy Chemical Corporation Superfund Site; Site property boundary includes OU1, does not include extent of groundwater contamination, OU2.
Feature Description: The Ciba-Geigy Chemical Corporation Site is located in Toms River, Dover Township, New Jersey on approximately 1,350 acres of land and is bordered on the east by the Toms River. Approximately 320 of the acres were developed and used for manufacturing operations, waste treatment, disposal activities, and administrative and laboratory facilities. Residential neighborhoods, recreational areas, small commercial establishments, and light industrial complexes are present near the Site. The commercial areas are situated primarily southwest of the Site. The area to the west is zoned for industrial use, light manufacturing, and warehousing operations. A large recreational area, which includes several parks, is east of the Site. This boundary includes all OU2, the source areas, however it does not include the extent of groundwater contamination, OU1.

Feature Description: The Mattiace Petrochemical Site consists of the 1.9 acre former Mattiace Property and a groundwater plume that is contaminated with volatile organic compounds (VOCs) extending approximately 700 feet northwest from the former Mattiace Property. Mattiace Petrochemical Company operations included storing, blending, and repackaging of organic solvents in 55-gallon drums for sale. The cleanup work at the Site has been organized into six operable units (OUs),all included in this boundary, to facilitate implementation, as follows: OU 1 -Excavation of pesticide hot spot; OU 2 -Excavation and off-site disposal of drums and contaminated soils; OU 3 - extraction and treatment of contaminated groundwater; OU 4 -In-situ vapor extraction of residually contaminated soil; OU 5 -Demolition and disposal of existing Site structures; and OU 6 -Pumping/disposal of floating product layer of light non-aqueous phase liquid (LNAPL).

Feature Name: GCL Tie and Treating Site Boundary
Feature Description: The GCL Tie and Treating site is approximately 60 acres located in an industrial/commercial area and is divided into two major parcels, generally referred to as the "GCL Property" and non-GCL Property." The GCL property is approximately a 26-acre parcel where the majority of Site operations were conducted. The former GCL property consisted of a sawmill, wood-treating facility, and a former light manufacturing company. The site contains three operable units (OUs): OU1 - soil contamination, OU2 - groundwater contamination and OU3 - source area contamination (NAPL). This boundary includes all three OUs.

Site Address: Route 370 (Intersection of County Route 129/Conquest-Victory Town Line Road)

Feature Description: The Vineland Chemical Company Superfund Site is located in a mixed residential / industrial area in the northwest corner of the City of Vineland in Cumberland County, New Jersey. The Vineland Chemical Company operated from 1949 to 1994 producing arsenical herbicides and fungicides. The Site was added to the National Priorities List in 1984 and work at the Site is being performed under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act. A RI/FS was completed in 1989 to identify the types, quantities, and locations of contaminants and to develop remedial solutions. USEPA issued a ROD in September 1989 for the entire Site. The ROD divided the Site into four OU: • OU1 (Plant Site - Source Control) • OU2 (Plant Site Management of Migration - Groundwater) • OU3 (Maurice River, BWB, and associated floodplains) • OU4 (Union Lake - Sediment) OU5 (On site Buildings) OU6 (Soil/Sediment/Groundwater) The boundary includes OUs 1-6

Feature Description: The JIS Landfill Site covers approximately 24 acres, which includes a 7.8 acre landfill and the former JIS facility and waste transfer operation and a downgradient plume. The Site includes a landfill, an inactive borrow pit and a solid waste recycling facility. Landfilling at the Site began in 1955. The JIS facility accepted a wide variety of chemical, municipal and industrial wastes which allegedly contained hazardous substances. The Site contains one operable unit (OU): OU1 - groundwater contamination.

Feature Name: LOWER HACKENSACK RIVER Approximate Site Boundary

Feature Description: The main site is surrounded by a chain-link fence to restrict access. Prior to the removal action, there were seven structures and twenty-two bulk oil tanks and numerous underground pipelines. The site is overgrown yearly with native grasses and weeds. There may be residual groundwater contamination on the property.

Feature Name: Ford Road Industrial Landfill Site Area
Feature Description: The Ford Road Industrial Landfill site an inactive facility. The northern, eastern, and southern flanks of the landfill slope steeply down to the 100-year floodplain of the Black River at an elevation of approximately 610.9 feet amsl. A swale, oriented approximately north-south, was constructed along the western edge of the landfill.

Feature Name: Lower Ecorse Creek Dump Site Boundary
Feature Description: The site included six residential blocks centered on the 400 block of North Drive. The park about one acre in size and has a small playground equipment area, swing set, pavilion, and basketball court, but most of it is grass-covered and is of general recreational use.

The Detroit and Toledo Railroad tracks are located east of the residential area.

Feature Name: Clare Water Supply IC-Wellfield Protection Area
Feature Description: The Clare Water Supply site covers most of downtown Clare, Michigan and includes the city's Municipal Wellfield. The site consists of four production wells (numbers 6, 7, 8 and 9) and their related water treatment and storage facilities.

Feature Name: US Coast Guard Air Station Site and Plume
Feature Description: The Avenue E Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site was a groundwater contamination plume located in East Bay Township in Traverse County, Traverse City, Michigan. The source of the contamination was located on the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) Air Station. The plume was located west of the intersection of Parsons Road and Aero Park Drive. It was traced to the northwest corner of an industrial park back lot located southwest of Nish-Nah-Bee Industries. The plume eventually extended to the East Arm of the Grand Traverse Bay.

Feature Name: Kent City Mobile Home Park Superfund Site
Feature Description: The 2-acre Kent City Mobile Home Park Site is located in Kent City, Michigan. Today, around 75 mobile homes are located on the site. A buried 55-gallon drum contaminated soil and groundwater at the site, resulting in contamination of a well serving the mobile homes. This drum collected floor drainage from a dry cleaning facility that once operated on the property.

Feature Name: Reilly Tar Chemical Corp. Vertellus Property
Feature Description: The 120-acre Reilly Tar & Chemical (Indianapolis Plant) site is a former coal tar refinery and creosote wood treatment plant located in Indianapolis, Indiana. Now owned by Vertellus, the site is divided into the Oak Park property, occupying approximately 40 acres, is located north of Minnesota and the Maywood property, occupying approximately 80 acres, is located south of Minnesota Street. The site is fenced. The Oak Park property contains the majority of the operating facilities, including above-ground storage tanks, distillation towers, and above-ground and underground utilities. There are 5 source areas on site including the lime pond, the railway trench, the sludge treatment pit, the drainage ditch and the south Iandfill/fire pond.

Feature Name: UM Rosemount Research Center Property Boundary
Feature Description: The site was previously used as an agricultural research station and for a variety of industrial uses. The site consists of four former waste disposal areas located within the boundaries of UMore Park. 3 of these areas, known as the George's Used Equipment (GUE), the Porter Electric and Machine Company (PBM) and the U.S. Transformer (USTrans), were used by former University of Minnesota at Rosemount (University) tenants prior to 1980 for recycling electric transformers. The fourth area was a bum pit (Bum Pit) used by the University in the 1960s and early 1970s for disposal of University chemical and laboratory waste. These four areas comprise a total of approximately 10 acres.

Feature Description: The Shiawassee River Site (Site) includes the former Cast Forge Company facility (CFC) in Howell, Livingston County, Michigan, and approximately eight miles of the Shiawassee River downstream to the Steinacker Road area. This boundary includes the former CFC property and covers about 51 acres. There are areas on the former CFC property that were historically associated with various waste handling and disposal processes. These areas include: an initial unlined lagoon; a former settling tank and discharge pipe; a former lined lagoon, overflow ditch, and overflow lagoon; and a former discharge area.

Feature Description: The Lower Fox River, located in northeastern Wisconsin, begins at the Menasha and Neenah channels leading from Lake Winnebago and flows northeast for 39 miles where it discharges into Green Bay and Lake Michigan. Approximately 270,000 people live in the communities along the river. The river has 12 dams and includes the highest concentration of pulp and paper mills in the world. During the 1950s and 1960s, these mills routinely used PCBs in their operations which ultimately contaminated the river.

Feature Name: Organic Chemicals Inc. Superfund Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 5-acre Site is located in the southeast quarter of Section 8, Township 6 North, Range 12 West, Walker Township, at 3291 Chicago Drive, S.W. in Grandville, Kent County, Michigan (See Figures 1 and 2). The Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, which runs southeast of the Site and along the north side of Chicago Drive, has an elevated rail bed acting as a barrier to surface drainage that would otherwise leave the Site. There is no visible surface drainage linking the Site and the Grand River, located about 0.95 miles to the north. The Site property is bordered by industrial tenants on the north, east, and west. These properties and others comprise an industrial and commercial park which extends north to Interstate-196, approximately 2,000 feet north of the Site. Residential areas are approximately 200 feet southeast of the Site and 1,700 feet to the southwest. Across Interstate-196 (north of the Site) is a wetland area that extends north to the Grand River. I-196 transects the wetland area and the industrial park/commercial park. There are no natural resource areas at or near the Site, which is located in an industrial/commercial park.

Feature Description: The site contains the former Prestolite Battery Division facility, which operated from 1945 to 1985 as a manufacturer of lead-acid batteries, primarily for use in cars and trucks. During plant operations, manufacturing process wastes and wastewater containing heavy metals and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) were discharged to the facility’s sewer system, which leaked into soil and groundwater. Lead dust was released from the plant's ventilation system, contaminating surface soils in the vicinity. The current use of the Site is commercial. Since the completion of cleanup activities, extensive redevelopment of the Site has occurred, including the construction of a Lowe’s Home Improvement store, Holiday Inn Express, two banks, a gasoline station, and several restaurants.

Site Address Comment: Five residences are situated on North Second Street immediately north of the Site, and two residences are located on North Sixth Street immediately south of the Site. The Site is bordered on the west by an Indiana State Highway property, and to the east of the Site is a local inn. A 5-acre pond (Northwest Pond) and associated wetland complex and an auto salvage yard lie immediately northwest of the Site. The city limits of Vincennes lie approximately 500 feet to the west of the Site.

Feature Name: South Andover Approximate Superfund Site Boundary
Feature Description: The site is in a commercial zone and is intersected by several roadways including Station Parkway NW and Martin Street NW. The site contains apartements, a Target, several other businesses and parking lots.

Site Address Comment: The site borders Bunker Lake Boulevard NW's south side and is bounded by Thrush Street NW, Station Parkway NW, and Jay Street NW.

Feature Description: The site contains OU1 and OU2, the former located in the northern half of the site boundary shown starting just above the holding pond in the southwest portion of the site. OU2 makes up the southern remainder of the site, beginning at the top of the aforementioned holding pond.

Feature Description: The site consists of two Operable Units (OUs). The Tar Lake site is mostly vacant and heavily vegetated. Two lakes, Peckham Lake and the western part of Nelson Lake, are located on the site. The Township of Mancelona owns part of the site property and uses the southern part of their 7.9-acre property to store wood chips and manage wood and brush waste. The township’s former landfill/dump occupies about two acres of the northern part of this parcel

Site Address Comment: The site is a rural plot of land and is bounded by North Front Street to the west, Darragh Road to the east, Musser Road to the south, and Palmer Park Road to the north.

Feature Description: The site is used as a parking lot for fairgrounds activities consistent with exposure assumptions and use restrictions.

Site Address Comment: Grassman Street and a residential area border the site to the north. Fair Street runs the eastern border, angles across the southeast comer ofthe site and also borders the fairgrounds along its south aspect. Open fields and homes are located to the south and southwest. An open field is west ofthe site. The actual site is within the larger fairgrounds parcel, is unfenced, and site access is unrestricted.

Feature Description: The Kerr-McGee (Residential Areas) Site is located in suburbs in and around West Chicago, DuPage County, Illinois, approximately 30 miles west of downtown Chicago. Feature Description: The Kerr-McGee (Residential Areas) Site is located in suburbs in and around West Chicago, DuPage County, Illinois, approximately 30 miles west of downtown Chicago. The Residential Areas Site is comprised of residential, institutional, commercial, industrial and municipal properties in the West Chicago area that were contaminated with radioactive waste materials that originated from the West Chicago Rare Earths Facility (REF), a facility that conducted thorium milling operations.

Feature Name: McGraw Edison Corp. Site NPL Boundary
Feature Description: The former McGraw-Edison facility is located in Albion, Michigan. The site occupies approximately 24 acres and includes the former air conditioning manufacturing facility. It is currently being reused. This boundary does not include the resultant groundwater plume or residential properties effected by the plume.
Feature Source: EPA Region 5; depicted in 2004 FYR, Fig. X, pg. 34

Feature Description: The Beck’s Lake site consists of a landfill and contaminated soil located at and near the intersection of Washington and Falcon Streets and adjacent to LaSalle Park on the northwest side of South Bend, Indiana. Portions of the current LaSalle Park were used as a dump and landfill from approximately 1938 through the mid-1950s. The area of concern includes the dump area and the area immediately surrounding LaSalle Park to the west and south-southwest where levels of lead elevated above background levels were identified in 1996 and 2001.
Feature Source: 2013 Support Document for the Revised NPL Final Rule, Fig. 1 p. 11

Site Address: INTERSECTION OF WASHINGTON AND FALCON STREETS
Site Address Comment: The Site is bordered to the west by N Falcon St, to the north by Linden Ave, to the south by W Washington St, and to the east by N Kaley St.

Feature Name: North Shore Gas South Plant Site Property Boundary
Feature Description: The nearly 23-acre NSG South Plant MGP site includes the 1.9-acre former South Plant MGP facility property located at 2 North Pershing Road and 1 South Pershing Road in Waukegan and several adjacent properties where MGP-derived contaminants have been found. This includes: The Waukegan Port District (WPD)-owned property located to die east of the former MGP parcel on Lake Michigan. The 13.1-acre WPD parcel includes a marina, a visitor center/administration building, a maintenance building, and asphalt-paved parking lots. The Akzo Nobel Aerospace Coatings, Inc. (Akzo) parcel located east/southeast of the former MGP and adjacent to Lake Michigan. The 6.2-acre property consists of buildings used for manufacturing paints and coatings and asphalt-paved parking lots. The Elgin, Joliet and Eastern (EJ&E) Railroad tracks and right-of-way located east and at die south end of the former MGP property. This parcel is approximately 0.7 acres. The City of Waukegan-owned parcels located southeast of the former MGP site between the EJ&E, Akzo, and WPD properties. One parcel is a vacated former city street that abuts a Commonwealth Edison substation and others include nearby roads and associated right-of-ways, totaling 0.5 acres.
Data Disclaimer: The Agency is providing this geospatial information as a public service and does not vouch for the accuracy, completeness, or currency of data. Data provided by external parties is not independently verified by EPA. This data is made available to the public strictly for informational purposes. Data does not represent EPA's official position, viewpoint, or opinion, express or implied. This information is not intended for use in establishing liability or calculating Cost Recovery Statutes of Limitations and cannot be relied upon to create any rights, substantive or procedural, enforceable by any party in litigation with the United States or third parties. EPA reserves the right to change these data at any time without public notice.
Site Address Comment: The site is located at 2 North Pershing Road and 1 South Pershing Road in Waukegan, Illinois. The South Plant MGP property is bounded to the north by a city-owned parking lot and to the west by a Union Pacific Railroad train yard. South Waukegan Harbor and Lake Michigan are located approximately 600 feet east of the former MGP property. The Waukegan River is located approximately 1,000 feet south of the former MGP property and flows east past the Akzo property into Lake Michigan.

Feature Description: The Sauget Area 1 Site is located in Clair County, Illinois. The site consists of Dead Creek, which runs through the middle of the Site, and six disposal sites, consisting of three closed waste disposal areas (Sites G, H, and I), a backfilled impoundment (Site L), an inactive borrow pit (Site M), and a closed construction debris disposal area (Site N).

Feature Name: Adrian Municipal Well Field Site Area
Feature Description: The Adrian Municipal Well Field site is located in Adrian, Minnesota. Located along the Kanaranzi Creek, the area of investigation (the Site) encompasses a portion of the north-central part of the City. Adrian relies solely on ground water for its municipal water supply. EPA investigations identified nine separate leaking underground storage tanks as potential contamination sources. Following cleanup, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 1992.

Site Address Comment: The Adrian Municipal Well Field site is roughly bound by Interstate 90 (I-90) in the north, railroad tracks in the south, Adrian Municipal Campground in the west, and agricultural area in the east.

Feature Description: The Copley Square Plaza (CSP) site is located due west of Akron, Ohio, and consists of two operable units (OUs). The first OU (OU 1) includes the commercial buildings at 2777 and 2799 Copley Road and an associated groundwater contaminant plume in the upper aquifer beneath area commercial and residential properties. The second OU (OU 2) consists of groundwater contaminant plumes in the middle and deep aquifers beneath the site.

Feature Name: Elm Street GW Contamination Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Elm Street Ground Water Contamination Superfund Site contains three potential source areas for VOCs which were identified by IDEM through the site assessment process. The potential source areas include the Gurman property located at 800 North 3rd Street, the Ashland (formerly BiState Products) property located at 118 Elm Street, and the Machine Tool Service (MTS) property located at 117 Elm Street.

Feature Description: The site consists of an approximately 400-acre parcel of land located in a mixed-use area. The Site contains four main disposal areas, each with several subareas. Operable Unit 1 is approximately 200 acres within the main portion of the site where bauxite residue processing waste was disposed.

Feature Description: The Chem Central property is a 2-acre parcel of land located at 2940 Stafford Avenue in Wyoming, Michigan. The "site" encompasses both a square shaped piece of property owned by the Chem Central Corporation which is the location of the currently operating plant and a rectangular piece of land owned by Consumers Power extending north from the Chem Central property with the approximate dimensions of 1,800 feet in length and 300 feet wide. In addition, the site includes Cole Drain, and any place where hazardous substances on the property have come to be located.

Feature Description: The Folkertsma Refuse Site is located at 1426 Pannell Street N.W. in Walker, Michigan. The site is a former muck farm that operated as a landfill from 1965 to 1972. The site covers 8 acres and contains approximately 57,000 cubic yards of low-level organic and inorganic waste material, most of which is foundry sand.

Feature Description: The Johns-Manville Corp. Superfund Site consists of both the JM manufacturing facility property and adjacent contaminated areas. The JM property is approximately 350 acres, which includes the former manufacturing area (most buildings were demolished in 2001), former parking areas, and an approximately 150-acre waste disposal area (OU1). Other Site areas adjacent to the JM property include the shooting range/fishing pier parking lot area (OU2), the southwestern site area (OUs 3, 4, and 8), the nature preserve road (OU6) and the Illinois Beach Nature Preserve (OU7). The Building Manufacturing Area (OU5) was enrolled in the SRP and received a letter of No Further Remediation (NFR) in 2017.

Other Site areas adjacent to the JM property include the shooting range/fishing pier parking lot area (OU2), the southwestern site area (OUs 3, 4, and 8), the nature preserve road (OU6) and the Illinois Beach Nature Preserve (OU7). The Building Manufacturing Area (OU5) was enrolled in the SRP and received a letter of No Further Remediation (NFR) in 2017.
Data Disclaimer: The Agency is providing this geospatial information as a public service and does not vouch for the accuracy, completeness, or currency of data. Site Address Comment: The Johns-Manville Corp. site is roughly bounded by E Greenwood Avenue in the south, Lake Michigan in the east, railroad tracks in the west, and the Illinois Beach Nature Preserve in the north.

Feature Description: The Site consists of approximately 20 acres of rolling uplands in a predominantly rural area. An intermittent stream crosses the Site on the western third of the property and flows to the north and is a tributary of Killbuck Creek. Adjacent property uses include quarrying operations to the north, agricultural to the east and south, and a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Subtitle D landfill on the west side of Lindenwood Road. There were residences in the area, but the ones that were closest to the Site at the time of the remedial investigation no longer exist or are not used as residences.

Site Address Comment: The Site is bound to the north by holding ponds, to the east by agricultural land, to the south by industrial developments and to the west by Lindenwood Road

Feature Name: Adams County Quincy Landfills 2&3 Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Adams County Quincy Landfills 2 & 3 site is located in a rural area on Old Broadway Road south of Illinois Route 104 approximately 5 miles east of the City of Quincy, Illinois. The 56-acre site is wire fenced on all sides with a locked access gate on the northern boundary. The landfill area covers approximately 37 acres of the 56-acre property Site. Approximately 30 acres of the landfilled area are covered by a landfill cap with a leachate collection system to remediate issues associated with leachate and the resulting contaminant impacts to groundwater.

Site Address: 2 MILES NORTH OF BURTON TWP 1/2 MI WEST
Site Address Comment: The Site’s northern limits are bounded by Rock Quarry Road (formerly known as Old Broadway Road) and residences, the eastern boundary is adjacent to a dairy farm and residence, the southern limit is bounded by a wooded tract, and the western boundary is bordered by a private lane and a residence.

Feature Description: The Hi-Mill Manufacturing Company is located at 1704 Highland Road (M-59) in Highland Township, Oakland County, Michigan. The site itself is approximately 4.5 acres in size and is dominated by the manufacturing facility and a paved parking area.

Feature Description: The 4.8 acre Alsco Anaconda National Priorities List (NPL) Site is located approximately 49 miles south of Akron, Ohio within the Gnadenhutten village limits. The Site contained four source areas, including the northern and southern impoundments (also known as the settling basin), the sludge pit, and the wooded area located between the impoundments and the river. The only structures located within the Site boundaries are fences and permitted wastewater outfalls for the adjacent manufacturing facility.

Feature Name: Big D Campground Boundary of Fence Area
Feature Description: The Big D Campground ("Big D") site is located in Kingsville, Ashtabula County, Ohio, approximately 2.5 miles south of Lake Erie and 50 miles northeast of Cleveland. The landfill at the site is approximately 1.2 acres in size and approximately 20 feet deep. The site is bordered by Conneaut Creek to the south, a campground to the southeast, open land to the west, residences with small acreage to the north and northwest, and a swamp area approximately 1/2 mile to the north. The residences are located approximately 500 feet north of the site.

Feature Description: The Adam's Plating Superfund Site is a parcel of land approximately one acre in size located at 521 Rosemary Street in Lansing, Michigan. Formerly a dry cleaner, the Site was transferred in 1964 to James and Sheila Adams who began to operate the plant as an electroplating business known as Adams Plating. Due to plating operations, the Site was determined to have elevated concentrations of chromium, copper, nickel, and several volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in soils. The Adams electroplating business continued to operate onsite until a fire destroyed the Adams Plating Company (APC) building in December 2010.

Feature Description: The Albion-Sheridan Township Landfill site is an inactive landfill located at 29975 East Erie Road approximately one mile east of Albion, Michigan on the eastern edge of Calhoun County. The landfill is approximately 18 acres in area. A larger area enclosed by the Site security fence is approximately 50 acres in size and includes land to the west and north. The Site is surrounded by a combination of residential, agricultural, commercial, and industrial properties.

Feature Description: The Algoma Municipal Landfill Site occupies a total of approximately 13 acres of disposal area. There are four recognized disposal areas that fall under one overall Site operable unit: The Landfill Disposal Area (LDA) is approximately 12.3 acres in size. The LDA accepted approximately 400,000 cubic yards of industrial, commercial and residential wastes. The Animal Disposal Area (ADA) was used to dispose of animal carcasses. The ADA is a depression on the eastern edge of the LDA and is included in the LDA. The North Disposal Area (NDA) is approximately 1.1 acres in size. The South Disposal Area (SDA) is approximately 3.5 acres in size.

Feature Name: Amcast Industrial Corporation Approx. Study Area
Feature Description: The Amcast Industrial Corporation Site plant is located on the south side of Cedarburg at N39 W5789 Hamilton Road, with portions of the property located on the north and south sides of Hamilton Road and west of Cedar Creek. The Site includes the Amcast North and South properties, the residential properties adjacent to Amcast North, the stormwater retention basin (referred to as Wilshire Pond), Quarry Pond at Herman A. Zeunert Park, and storm sewers.

Feature Description: The Amoco Chemicals (Joliet Landfill) Superfund Site is an active chemical manufacturing facility located on approximately 750 acres of land in a semi-rural industrial/agricultural area. The facility is near Joliet, Illinois in Will County on the west bank of the Des Plaines River. The Site consists of two inactive landfills that cover 26 acres, as well as an adjacent slough area.

Feature Description: The Arcanum Iron and Metal Site (AIM) is located in Twin Township, Darke County, Ohio just southeast of the city of Arcanum and 25 miles northwest of Dayton, Ohio. The site covers about 4.5 acres.

Feature Description: The Armco Incorporation-Hamilton Plant site consists of two pieces of property north and south of Augspurger Road in the village of New Miami, about 1.5 miles northeast of downtown Hamilton, Butler County, Ohio. The site is an inactive, 125-acre facility that produced iron for steel making. The former manufacturing portion of the site consists of a fenced 92-acre parcel located south of Augspurger Road. The northern portion of the site includes an unfenced, 27-acre rail yard where piles of waste from air pollution cleaning equipment was stored. This area is now partially covered with piles of slag. As the site borders the Great Miami River along its entire length, surface water drainage from the site flows to the east and south to the river.

Feature Description: The ASARCO Taylor Springs Site is nearly 533 acres southwest of the village of Taylor Springs. It is now owned by the ASARCO Multi-State Custodial Trust and includes a former zinc smelter and zinc oxide plant. About 263 acres are wooded and 89 acres were formerly farmed. About 100 acres of the facility area is covered with residue from the former zinc smelting and zinc oxide operations. The primary contaminant is lead in soil and arsenic, cadmium, and zinc in groundwater.
Feature Source: 2020 ASARCO Taylor Springs Superfund Site Location and Map, pg. 2

Feature Description: The Ashland/Northern States Power Lakefront Site consists of 25 acres of upland (onshore) and 16 acres offshore (sediment located along the shore of Lake Superior). The Site contains: (i) property owned by Northern States Power Company, a Wisconsin corporation, doing business as Xcel Energy, a subsidiary of Xcel Energy Inc. (NSPW). This property included the former Manufactured Gas Plant (MGP) facility; (ii) a portion of Kreher Park, a City owned property fronting on the bay that included the former municipal waste water treatment plant (WWTP); (iii) an inlet of Chequamegon Bay containing contaminated sediment directly offshore from the former WWTP; (iv) a railroad right-of-way owned by the Wisconsin Central Ltd., and formerly owned by the Soo Line Railroad; and (v) Our Lady of the Lake Church/School, as well as private residences.

Feature Name: Auto Ion Chemicals, Inc. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Auto Ion Chemicals, Inc. site occupies approximately 1.5 acres of vacant, fenced land adjacent to the Kalamazoo River. Prior to remediation, a building which originally housed a power generating station and later the electroplating waste treatment facility was centrally located on the site. An on-site unlined lagoon used to store sludges was located on the west side of the site. The Auto Ion site consists of two operable units (OU): OU1 addresses contaminated soil and OU2 addresses contaminated groundwater.

Feature Description: The 2.3-acre Barrels, Inc. site, is located in Lansing, Michigan. Barrels, Inc. began operating on the site in 1961 and continued until 1980, at which time the owner abandoned the site. Spills from drum reclamation processes and from a storage tank contaminated surface soils at the site.
Feature Source: 1995 Final Remedial Investigation Report, Fig. 1.3, PDF pg. 90

Feature Name: Bautsch-Gray Mine Primary Source Area Boundary
Feature Description: The Bautsch-Gray Mine Superfund Site consists of two operable units. OU1 addresses contaminated soil at the Site and consists of the following: (1) three principal source areas of contamination that include a 34.2-acre mine tailings pile and peripheral tailings, a settling pond west of the mine tailings pile, and contaminated soil along the overland flow route from the settling pond to Smallpox Creek; and (2) several affected privately-owned properties that include cleared residential areas, non-residential open unvegetated areas, and non-residential vegetated areas outside the tailings pile. OU2, which is still being evaluated, includes any areas in and along Smallpox Creek found to have unacceptable ecological impacts from Site-related contamination, and groundwater at the Site if found to pose unacceptable risks due to Site-related contamination.

Feature Description: The Belvidere Municipal Landfill (Belvidere Municipal Landfill #1) Site occupies approximately 139 acres. The ROD and Consent Decree (CD) describe the Site to include the 19-acre Belvidere Municipal Landfill # 1 and 120 acres in the area between the landfill and the river. The closed landfill, which is situated on property owned by the BCCD, is bordered by the Kishwaukee River to the west.

Feature Description: The Berlin & Farro facility is a fenced 40-acre site situated in a primarily rural area approximately 3.5 miles south of the town of Swartz Creek in Gaines Township, Genesee County, Michigan. The site contains several bodies of water which have resulted from surface cleanup activities. The South Lagoon and the Tank Excavation Area ponds retain water year round. Two settling ponds constructed to reduce off-site runoff, retain water for much of the year. In addition, there are three marshy areas created by prior cleanup activities at the site which retain standing water during parts of the year, especially during rainy seasons. These marshy areas are not classified as wetlands.

Feature Description: The Bofors Nobel, Inc. Site is an 85-acre site comprised of a former specialty chemical production facility, that has been closed and its buildings demolished, its associated waste disposal area, and an on-site groundwater treatment plant (GWTP). The northern portion of the Site is currently owned by the Sun Chemical Corporation, and there is an active Sun Chemical plant immediately to the west. Big Black Creek runs through the southern portion of the Site. Groundwater contamination is confined within the Site boundary and no private residential wells near the Site are affected. The Site consists of two operable units (OUs). OU1 addresses soil and waste disposal units on the southern half of the Site (approximately 46 acres), and sitewide groundwater. Major features found in the OU1 footprint are 10 unlined, soil-covered lagoons (formerly used for chemical manufacturing waste disposal), and a groundwater remedy system that includes a barrier wall, a treatment wetland, and several extraction wells. OU2 includes the 39-acre former operating plant area located on the northern part of the Site.

Feature Description: The Burnham Canal - Miller Compressing Company Site consists of Miller Compressing Company's (Miller's) former wire reclamation furnace area and a portion of the Burnham Canal (Canal) from the western terminus to the 11th Street Bridge. The Canal is located east and south of the Miller's metal recycling facility. The south part of the Canal is partially owned by Miller; other portions of the south bank are occupied by a foundry and an automobile junk yard. The Site extends approximately 1,500 feet from its west end to the 11th Street Bridge and ranges from 95 to 125 feet wide. The Canal banks, with the exception of the west end, are generally reinforced seawalls made from steel, concrete, or wood timbers. In addition to the seawalls, there are three large combined sewer outfalls located along the Canal. The west end of the Canal is covered with rock and rip-rap with patches of exposed soil, weeds, and brush; this soil area is approximately 20 to 25 feet wide.

Feature Description: The Cam-Or Inc. Site is an approximately 15-acre parcel of land located on the north side of Westville, Indiana in LaPorte County. The Cam-Or facility was originally owned by Westville Oil, which began re-refining waste oil in approximately 1934. The former lagoons and a former well in the center of the Site which may have been used as an injection well are two potential sources of the 1,4-dioxane contaminant plume. There is also a plume of LNAPL that extends southwest from the site.

Feature Description: The Central Illinois Public Service Co. (C.I.P.S.) Site property is located in Christian County at 917 South Webster Street in Taylorville, Illinois. It is 2.4 acres in size. A manufactured gas plant operated at the site from 1892 until 1932. The coal gasification process produced coal tar which contaminated the soil, groundwater, surface water and sediments around the site.

The site is fenced and access is controlled by a monitored gate.

Feature Name: H & K Sales Site Building Boundary
Feature Description: The H & K Sales site is also known as the Belding Warehouse site and is located at 100 East Main Street in the city of Belding, Ionia County, Michigan. The Belding Warehouse facility is privately-owned and consists of two main structures. The H&K Sales site is that portion of the Belding Warehouse facility in which World War II (WWII)-era military aircraft gauges and components had been stored since 1994. The site building is a single-story structure consisting of three separate, large rooms, each approximately 9,000 square feet in area. A portion of the warehouse facility is attached to the site building; it is a three-story structure that was not used for storage of any the WWII surplus material. It is not considered to be a part of the site.

Feature Description: The Chemetco Site was a secondary copper smelting facility located on 41 acres of land located within a primarily agricultural, mixed-use area south of Hartford, Illinois on the east side of the intersection of Lewis and Clark Boulevard (Illinois Route 3) and Oldenburg Road in Madison County. The Site includes agricultural and wetland areas and a seasonal tributary to Long Lake (STLL) located southeast of the Site. The Site has been divided into two operable units (OU): OU1 - Production Area (inside fence), and OU2 - Non-Production Area (outside fence).

Feature Description: The Chemical Recovery Systems (CRS) Site is approximately 2.5 acres. Most of the 2.5- acre property is empty. Two buildings are currently on the CRS Site: a former warehouse and office building and the masonry shell of a building that housed a Rodney Hunt still. These buildings are located in the southeast corner of the CRS Site. The foundation of a building that housed a Brighten still is located in the northeast corner of the CRS Site. The CRS Site is fenced on all sides except the side bounded by the East Branch Black River. Four pipes (subsurface conduits) protrude from the river bank on the western boundary. In the NW portion of the CRS Site, the primary subsurface conduit is a Storm Sewer outfall pipe, which runs from Locust Street underneath the CRS Site and discharges to the River.

The landfill was planned to be subdivided into 12 cells, with cells 5, and 7 through 11 never being developed. The landfill itself occupies approximately 24 acres.

Feature Description: The Kummer Sanitary Landfill Site is a former landfill which accepted mixed municipal waste and demolition debris for disposal from 1971 to 1985 and contains about 750,000 cubic yards of mixed waste. The current waste footprint covers approximately 20 acres. Waste disposal at the landfill caused groundwater contamination that moved off-site beneath residential properties.

Feature Description: The LCC Site is a group of several land and waste storage/disposal facilities located in southeastern Chicago, Cook County, Illinois. The site is approximately 87 acres in size. The LCC site consists of the following individual areas: Alburn Incinerator, an unnamed parcel, U.S. Drum II, and the Paxton Avenue Lagoons.

Feature Description: The Cliff/Dow site is a two-acre site, bounded by the Dead River and currently owned by the City of Marquette. The area around the site is largely undeveloped. The area of fill deposition consists of what appears to have been a small bog depression with a total area of under two acres. After filling in the bog depression, the area of waste disposal is generally level and vegetated with grasses, shrubs, and small trees except for the areas of exposed tars. Geophysical surveys indicate that the waste occupies approximately 1.4 acres with a thickness of between twelve and sixteen feet.

Feature Description: The Diamond Shamrock Painesville Works is an approximately 1,100-acre former chemical manufacturing facility located in Lake County, Ohio that operated from 1912 through 1977. Several individuals and companies purchased property from Diamond Shamrock and operated industrial facilities within the boundaries of the former facility, including an aluminum smelting plant, a polyvinyl chloride monomer facility and a coke plant. The cleanup at the site has been divided into 22 OUs. U.S. EPA is the lead agency for OU16. The Ohio EPA is directing the cleanup at all the other OUs that comprise the Site.

Feature Description: The Duell & Gardner Landfill Site is comprised of an 80-acre parcel located at 1285 Bard Road. The landfill itself covers an area of about four acres; however, waste was placed in areas outside the landfill on the ground surface. The landfill has never been properly covered. The site is not fenced; however, the landfill area is secluded and posted. Land use in the area is primarily residential and agricultural.

Feature Description: The Site is located in Hamilton Township, Lawrence County, Ohio, approximately four miles southwest of the City of Ironton. Vegetation over the landfill consists of poor-quality grass and shrubs. The adjacent valley sides are heavily wooded. A tributary of Winkler Run extends from the base of the earthen dam along the valley floor to Winkler Run. The Site has rugged topography with high relief Slopes in the area are generally steep with narrow ridge tops. It is estimated that 23,000 persons live within a four-mile radius of the Site.

The ridge on which the Site is located separates Winkler Hollow (west of Site) from Schilling Hollow (east of Site). The Site is 0.8 miles north of the Ohio River, and approximately 0.5 miles north of U.S. Route 52. It is estimated that 23,000 persons live within a four-mile radius of the Site.

Site Name: EAGLE ZINC CO DIV T L DIAMOND
Feature Description: The 132-acre Eagle Zinc Co Site is covered with 23 building/structures over about 30 acres. The Site is divided into operable units (OUs). OU 1 consists of the contaminated buildings and immediately adjacent areas on the Site. The focus OU2 includes the waste piles, residue, soil, surface water, groundwater, and sediment for the Site. The Site contains several railroad spurs, residual material, two storm water retention ponds, one larger pond in the southwestern portion of the Site, one small pond in the southeastern portion of the Site, and several roads formerly used for facility operations.

Feature Description: The East Troy Contaminated Aquifer Site includes an approximate 20-square block area of contaminated groundwater and associated soils extending west from the west bank of the Great Miami River (GMR) within an area that extends from approximately South Walnut Street on the northwest to Floral Avenue on the southeast, Canal and Scott streets on the southwest and the GMR on the northeast. The ETCA Site is located primarily in an older urban, residential, industrial, and commercial setting. On the west side of the GMR, the entire Site is developed as residential, industrial, or commercial and is densely constructed and paved.

Feature Description: The Buckeye Reclamation Landfill (BRL) site is situated in the Kings Run drainage ravine; it is bordered by King's Run to the east and Unnamed Run to the west. The site on which the landfill is located occupies 658 acres. The landfill occupies approximately 50 acres of this area. The landfill extends approximately 3,700 feet north to south and is approximately 500 to 1,000 feet wide. Deep mining occurred beneath the 658-acre site until around 1940. During that time, the site was a disposal area for mine refuse.

Feature Description: The Estech site is a 54-acre, inactive pesticide/fertilizer facility located in a heavily industrialized area located at 150 Marble Street, Calumet City, Illinois. The property consists of seven (7) parcels. Four of them are owned by Calumet City, and three are privately owned. A three to four acre wetland and aquatic area is located in the northwest portion of the site. A tower is located near the northeast portion of the Estech property. The tower is enclosed with a fence and is not thought to be part of the Estech operations. An abandoned building, historically part of the pesticide plant, is the only remaining structure on site. It stands in the eastern portion of the site. The area to the north and west of the building is paved with concrete. In the center of site there is a debris pile, covering approximately 52,500 square feet and comprised of mostly bricks, some concrete, and scrap metal.

Site Address Comment: The southern and western borders of the site are bounded by the Grand Calumet River. Gelita North America is located south of the site across the Grand Calumet River. The site is bounded to the north by the parcels of land on the northeastern portion of the site and by a rail line on the northwest portion. The rail line also borders the site to the east and marks the Indiana/Illinois state line.  The area in the immediate northeast corner of the Estech property is also not associated with Estech and is a natural gas pipeline facility owned by Kinder Morgan Inc. The Kinder Morgan property has a separate parcel number. Estech activities are not thought to have impacted this parcel of property.

Feature Description: The International Minerals (E. Plant) Superfund Site (“IMC site”) has an area of approximately 37 acres. The disposal area encompasses approximately six acres in the northeastern portion of the site. The Wabash River is the most prominent physiographic feature in the area. The IMC site is located in the southeastern part of Terre Haute, approximately 1.8 miles from the Wabash River at its closest point, in a semi-industrialized area of the city.

Feature Description: The 2.8-acre IPC site is located in an industrial area in the south-central part of Rockford, Winnebago County, Illinois northwest of Magnolia and Peoples Avenue. The site is located in an area that has been heavily industrialized since the early 1900s. The IPC site is encompassed by the much larger Southeast Rockford Groundwater Contamination Site (SER).

Feature Description: The Freeway Landfill is an MPCA-permitted unlined, soil-covered, inactive waste disposal area located in Burnsville, Minnesota, just southwest of Interstate 35W and the Minnesota River. The Landfill consists of several parcels, totaling approximately 189 acres located primarily on the following property parcels: 037-02-15600-00-010; 037-02-15600-00-060; 037-02-15600-00-020, 037-02-15600-02- 010; 037-02-15600-00-030; 037-02-15600-00-040; and 037-02-15600-00-050. The area of waste associated with the Landfill (including waste present on neighboring properties) is approximately 140 acres and the estimated volume of waste is approximately 5,300,000 cubic yards. Within the Landfill area is the Freeway Transfer Station which is located at 11501 Embassy Road.

Feature Description: The Gratiot County Landfill Site is approximately 105 acres comprised of two parcels; an 84 acre parcel owned by Gratiot County and a 21 acre parcel (west side of Site) owned by the State of Michigan through a quit-claim deed. The GCL is 44 acres located on the 84 acre parcel of land in the southeast quarter of Section 30, Township 12 North, Range 2 West, Bethany Township, Gratiot County, Michigan.

Feature Description: The Himco Dump Site is a closed unlicensed landfill located at County Road 10 and the Nappanee Street Extension, Cleveland Township, in Elkhart County, Indiana. The site size is approximately 60 acres, and was in operation between 1960 and 1976. The area was initially a mixture of marsh and grassland. Wastes, including household refuse, construction rubble, medical waste and calcium sulfate were placed in the landfill. Some trenching activities took place on the eastern side of the site. In 1976, the landfill was closed and covered. The cover consisted of approximately one foot of sand overlying a calcium sulfate layer.

Feature Name: Ionia City Landfill Site Compliance Boundary
Feature Description: The Site, which is owned by the City, is situated on approximately 20 acres of land located within the floodplain of the Grand River. The Site itself consists of an older fill area (Area A) in the northern portion and a more recent fill area (Area B) in the southern portion of the Site. The two areas are divided by the right-of-way of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, although the trackage was removed in 1987 and the right-of-way is now a recreational path.

Feature Description: The Janesville Ash Beds site operated from 1974 to 1985. It comprises of five ash beds in an area about 400 feet by 400 feet.  Industrial liquids and sludges were deposited in this area and allowed to evaporate. Dried sludge was then disposed of in two adjacent landfills: the "Old Landfill," another Superfund site, and the "New Landfill."  Both are now closed.

Feature Description: The Janesville Old Dump Site ("1963 site"), also Janesville Old Landfill, operated from 1950 until 1963, occupies approximately 15 acres and is located at the western portion of the JDF. The "1963" site operated as general refuse dump accepting unknown types of wastes. The "1963" site was an abandoned sand and gravel pit. The Janesville Ashbeds are located atop the northwest corner of the "1963" site and a recycling firm now occupies the northeast portion of the site. The "1963" Site IS not on the NPL, but is included in this ROD because of its proximity to the JAB and because it is a solid waste management unit under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and liability Act of 1980, as amended (CERCLA)/Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Consent Order. The Remedial Investigation (RI) has shown that the "1963" site may be contributing to the groundwater contamination downgradient of the JDF.

The site consists of the Yeoman Creek Landfill (both East and West portions) located north of a Commonwealth Edison (ComEd) right-of-way,  the Edwards Field Landfill, the North Rubloff Landfill, and the South Rubloff Landfill.

Feature Description: The approximately 30-acre Wayne Waste Oil Site is located in the southeast part of Columbia City, Indiana. The northeast portion of the Site was the location of a landfill area which was operated by Columbia City from 1953 to 1970. The central and western portion of the Site lies in an upland area which was the location of numerous tanks from past oil recycling and reclamation operations by Wayne Reclamation and Recycling.

Feature Name: Lusher Street GW Contamination Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Lusher Street Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site is located in Elkhart, Elkhart County, Indiana and occupies about 870 acres. The Site is composed of mixed residential, commercial, and industrial areas bisected by a railroad yard and served by a mix of private wells and public water supply wells.

Feature Description: The Site is located in an unincorporated area of southeast Du Page County, Illinois, two miles northeast of the Village of Lemont, Illinois. The Site consists of the Lenz Oil Services, Inc., (Lenz Oil) property and contiguous property which has contamination originating from the Lenz Oil property. The Site is currently a vacant, grassy area containing a radio tower, a number of monitoring wells and piezometers (which monitors the pressure or depth of groundwater), a fire hydrant, two utility manways, and the building that contains the Vacuum Enhanced Recovery (VER) system. The portion of the Site beyond the Lenz Oil property to the south of Jeans Road contains a residence adjacent to one corner along with several storage structures. This polygon covers the facility property and the property with spillage, parcel pins: 1011402009 & 1011401006.
Feature Source: Dupage County Parcel Viewer PIN 1011402009 & 1011401006; as seen in the 2019 FYR, Fig. 2.3, pg. 32

Feature Description: The Electro-Voice Site is located in Buchanan, Michigan. Activities at the plant included die-casting, machining, assembly, painting and electroplating. The business closed its doors in 2000. Contamination at the site resulted from Electro-Voice’s discharge of electroplating wastes into two clay-lined lagoons from 1952 to 1962, and from the disposal of paint wastes and solvents into a drywell from 1964 to 1973. The waste disposal activities caused groundwater to become contaminated with chemicals called volatile organic compounds, or VOCs. Following construction of the Site’s long-term remedy, operation and maintenance activities and monitoring are ongoing.

Feature Description: The 88.5-acre Coshocton Landfill Site is located between two small intermittent creeks that drain toward the southwest into the Muskingum River. The Site surface currently resembles a meadow or field of wild grasses. The Site is built on abandoned strip-mined land. Starting in 1968, a portion of the Site property was used as a landfill while strip mining operations continued. Both landfill and mining operations ceased in 1979. During its operation, the landfill accepted a variety of industrial waste, including hazardous substances from several local industries.

Feature Description: The 3.5-acre Carter Industrials facility is located at 4690 Humboldt Street in Detroit, Michigan. The Site encompasses this and adjacent properties. It is situated approximately 1/2 mile southeast of the intersection of interstate highways 96 and 94. The Site contains seven piles of PCB-contaminated soil and debris (approximately 46,000 cubic yards). Several structures, including two buildings, two smelters and an incinerator are located on Site. A 1000 gallon underground storage tank containing a gasoline and water mixture is also located on the Site.

Feature Name: Eau Claire Municipal Well Field Boundary
Feature Description: The Eau Claire Municipal Well Field (ECMWF) site is located in the northwest corner of Eau Claire on the east bank of the Chippewa River. The municipal well field, a 500 acre site, supplies drinking water to approximately 57,600 residents and numerous commercial establishments in the City of Eau Claire and Washington Township. The ECMWF is divided into north and south sections with nine wells developed in the north well field and five wells developed in the south well field. Groundwater from five municipal wells in the north well field is contaminated with volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The contamination at the ECMWF site has been characterized as two separate plumes. There is a plume at the municipal well field (Plume 1) and another upgradient of the well field (Plume 2).

Feature Name: Area to be Connected to the Village Water Supply
Feature Description: The Ellsworth Industrial Park site is an active industrial area in Downers Grove, DuPage County, Illinois. Built in the late 1950s, the industrial park currently includes about 135 businesses. The site also encompasses the area in which chlorinated-solvent groundwater contamination has been detected. The site is split into 2 OUs: OU 1 consists primarily of commercial and light industrial properties. OU 2 consists of residential, recreational and commercial properties. An Administrative Order of Consent covers the remedial investigation and feasibility study, or RI/FS, for groundwater in the area of the site known as OU 2. Insufficient information exists on the current nature and extent of groundwater contamination in OU 2. That means the contamination must be fully characterized and cleanup options identified and evaluated in the OU 2 RI/FS.

The Site, which occupies approximately 6.5 acres of land, was placed on the National Priorities List (NPL) for site cleanup in September 1983.

Feature Name: Keystone Corridor GW Contamination Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Keystone Corridor Ground Water Contamination Site is located approximately six miles northeast of downtown Indianapolis, in an area that is both commercial and residential. A contaminated groundwater plume is known to exist at the Site. As presently defined, the center of the Site is designated as the intersection of Keystone Avenue and East Fall Creek Parkway North Drive. The municipal Fall Creek Station Well Field, as well as multiple, independent potential sources of groundwater contamination, some of which is commingled, are located within the Site.

Feature Description: The Lakeland Disposal Service, Inc., site is an inactive landfill located approximately 3-1/2 miles northwest of Claypool, Indiana. The site consists of approximately 39 acres. The landfill contained general refuse (e.g., plastic, metal, wood, leaves, paper and cardboard) and certain industrial wastes. A chain link fence runs along the western property of the site. The southern half of the landfill is surrounded by a farmer's fence. An agricultural drainage ditch, called Sloan Ditch, runs parallel to the eastern and northern edges of the site. Several wetland areas exist along Sloan Ditch. Wooded areas are located east of the landfill along Sloan Ditch and the adjacent wetlands. This polygon includes ERC property Tract B.

Feature Description: The Lammers Barrel Factory Site consists of approximately 25 acres of property at the northeast comer of the intersection of Grange Hall Road and East Patterson Road in Beavercreek, Ohio, as well as a contaminated groundwater plume that extends east of the Site property. EPA has divided the Site into two Operable Units (OUs). OU 1 addresses hazardous substance contamination on the Site property. OU2 addresses the contaminated groundwater plume east of the Site property. This boundary includes OU1 but not OU2.

The Site is bordered on the west by Grange Hall Road, and on the south by East Patterson Road. Further to the south are a gas station, an automotive repair facility, and a residential area (Woodhaven Subdivision). To the southeast is a strip mall (Woodhaven Shopping Center). To the east, the Site is bordered by a parking lot and property owned by the Fraternal Order of Eagles (FOE).

Feature Name: Lane Street GW Contamination Site Boundary
Feature Description: The approximate 65-acre Lane Street Groundwater Contamination Superfund Site consists of a contaminated co-mingled groundwater plume underlying both active and inactive industrial, commercial, and residential properties. Within the presently defined Site boundaries, there are approximately 29 residences along Lane Street and County Road 106, and 17 parcels in the industrial park area to the north of Lane Street, including both operating and vacant industrial and commercial buildings.

North of County Road 106, the eastern boundary widens to include the industrial/commercial area bounded by Marina Drive on the east, Ada Drive on the west, County Road 106 on the south, and Cooper Drive on the north. The northern boundary extends approximately 750 feet north of Cooper Drive to include some additional industrial properties in the northeast corner.

Feature Description: The Laskin/Poplar Oil Co. Site consists of a nine-acre triangular shaped parcel which at one time contained the residence of the property owner, a greenhouse complex, a boiler house, miscellaneous small buildings and sheds, and numerous tanks, ponds and pits. Storage tanks and pits were installed during the 1960s to store the oil that fired the boilers. During the 1960s and 1970s, waste oil contaminated with Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs), Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs), and metals was accepted from hundreds of sources in northern Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Site contamination originated from the improper storage, handling and combustion of the oil.

Feature Description: The LeHillier/Mankato Superfund Site is 250 acres in area and is located in south-central Minnesota approximately 80 miles southwest of Minneapolis. The southern half of the site includes residential and industrial areas and is part of the LeHillier neighborhood of South Bend Township. The northern half of the site is part of the City of Mankato and is occupied by a city park and a municipal well field. Between 1925 and 1960, the area was the site of unregulated disposal of industrial and municipal waste.

Feature Description: The Site is in the City of Charlevoix, Charlevoix County, Michigan. The Site consists of soil, soil vapor, and groundwater contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds (VOCs), specifically trichloroethene (TCE) and PCE. VOCs have been found in Site groundwater, soils, soil vapor and in indoor air within structures located near the contamination.

Feature Description: The Hunts Disposal Landfill (HDL) (also known as the Waste Management Inc.-Caledonia Landfill) is an inactive 35-acre landfill which is a part of an 84-acre parcel (including a 25- acre lake) located in southeastern Wisconsin. The landfill reportedly accepted municipal and industrial wastes from 1959 to 1974. The parcel is currently owned by the Racine County Parks Department and was originally purchased for inclusion in the Racine County Root River Parkway System.

Site Address Comment: The site borders the Root River in a sparsely populated agricultural area of Caledonia Township in Racine County. The site is located immediately south of County Line Road (also known as Eight Mile Road) and is approximately 1.5 miles west of Highway 32. The Chicago & North Western (C&NW) Railroad tracks run north-south and are located just west of the site. The landfill is bordered on the west by a wetland located between the landfill and the C&NW railroad tracks. To the southwest between the landfill and the Root River is a narrow strip of wooded wetland which varies from approximately 50 to 100 feet wide. Wetlands also extend along the southern and eastern sides of the site. North of the site is a lake approximately 25 acres in size. The lake was created during the excavation of soil used to cover the landfill.

Feature Description: The Garden City Ground Water Plume site is located beneath the town of Garden City, with the highest concentrations of contamination located at the intersection of 900 Jonesville Road and County Road 100, Garden City, Bartholomew County, Indiana 47201. The town includes a mobile home park and businesses that are served by private ground water wells with approximately 50 residents.

Site Name: KERR-MCGEE (KRESS CREEK/WEST BRANCH OF DUPAGE RIVER)
Feature Description: The Kerr-McGee (Kress Creek/West Branch of DuPage River) Site, also known as the Kress Creek Site, is located in DuPage County, Illinois, approximately 30 miles west of downtown Chicago. The site stretches from southern unincorporated West Chicago, through Warrenville, to the northern edge of unincorporated Naperville, and consists of approximately 6.7 miles of creek and river sediments, banks and floodplain soils contaminated with radioactive thorium residuals. Specifically, the site includes approximately 1.5 miles of Kress Creek stretching from a storm sewer outfall (located south of Illinois Route 38/Roosevelt Road and east of the Elgin, Joliet and Eastern railway) to the creek's confluence with the West Branch DuPage River, and approximately 5.2 miles of the West Branch DuPage River from the confluence downstream past the Warrenville Dam to the McDowell Dam.

Feature Name: WPSC Manitowoc MGP OU1 Source Area
Feature Description: The nearly 2-acre WPSC Manitowoc MGP Site is in Manitowoc County, Wisconsin, about 40 miles south of Green Bay, Wisconsin. EPA divided the site into three OUs, with OU1 addressing MGP source area contaminants, OU2 addressing river sediment, and OU3 addressing groundwater. The site consists of the 1.1-acre former Manitowoc MGP facility located at 402 North Tenth Street, which is bounded on the northwest by property owned by the City of Manitowoc and the Manitowoc River; on the north by additional WPSC-owned parcels; on the east by North Tenth Street; on the south by Chicago Street; and on the west by North Eleventh Street.

Feature Description: The Fadrowski Drum Disposal site, which is comprised of 20 acres of semi-rural land, is located on South 27th Street 20 in Franklin, Wisconsin. Between 1970 and 1982, demolition and construction waste was accepted there. Buried drums containing liquids and sludges were also discovered. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, an in-depth study of the nature and extent of contamination and an evaluation of cleanup options were done.  The results confirmed chemicals in the groundwater and on-site creek.

The landfill accepted approximately 1.5 million cubic yards of mixed municipal solid waste and small quantities of industrial and commercial hazardous wastes.

Feature Description: The Fultz Landfill is a privately-owned sanitary landfill where hazardous industrial wastes were co-disposed with municipal waste. Closed since 1985, the landfill was one of two facilities that served the refuse-disposal needs of Guernsey County. The landfill occupies approximately 30 acres of a 58-acre land tract within Parcel 1 of Military Lot 5. Parcel 1, prior to 1950, was part of a large farm that comprised approximately 200 acres. Land use in the vicinity of the site is primarily wooded and pasture to the south, north and east. To the west, land has been developed for residential and light industrial use.

Feature Description: The Long Prairie Groundwater Contamination Site includes a 0.16-acre (approximately 7,000 square foot) area of tetrachloroethene (also known as perchloroethene (PCE)) impacted soil. The PCE impacted soil was located in the back of a former dry-cleaning facility located at 243 Central Street in the commercial district of Long Prairie, Minnesota (City). A groundwater plume of PCE and its degradation products extends approximately 2100 feet to the north east and was at one time approximately 1000 feet in width. This polygon represents the Special Well Construction Area as seen in the 2017 FYR.

Feature Description: The Bennett Stone Quarry, “Bennett's Dump”, Site is located in a former limestone quarrying area previously known as Bennett's Stone Quarry. The main area of the Site is 3.5 acres in size and another smaller area, referred to as the satellite area, is located approximately one hundred feet to the east of the main area. The satellite area is approximately a half-acre in size. Currently the Bennett's Dump site is owned by the Ledge Wall Quarry LLC and no active quarry operations are taking place. Stout's Creek is on the west border of the site with quarry access roads to the south and east.

Feature Description: The DSC site is located in Gibraltar, Wayne County, Michigan and historically operated as a steel finishing operation. The site includes three landfills and a leachate treatment lagoon system. Landfills A and B and their associated leachate treatment lagoons are located on the east side of the site. CWLF is located on the west side of the site. Landfills A and B are closed landfill cells located south of the mill building. The landfills contain steel mill sludge. Landfill A is approximately 23 acres and Landfill B is approximately 32 acres in size. The leachate treatment lagoon system associated with Landfills A and B includes a series of 6 basins and ponds and the partially closed Tandem Mill Pond (TMP). The leachate treatment lagoon system includes a series of 4 water retention basins and 2 ponds, including the TMP. The TMP is a 6.2-acre oil separation pond located south of the production building. South of the TMP is a 1.1-acre Acid Dosing Pond and a 1.4-acre Sludge Drying Pond. North of the TMP are 4 water retention basins, with sizes of 0.2 acres, 0.9 acres, 1.1 acres, and 1.4 acres.

Feature Description: The 9-acre MIDCO II Site is located at 5900 Industrial Highway in the City of Gary, Lake County, Indiana. The Site began waste operations in 1976 following a fire that destroyed MIDCO I. In 1977, a large fire destroyed equipment, buildings, and an estimated 50,000 to 60,000 drums containing chemical wastes. Soil and groundwater contamination resultign from both the waste operations and the additional spillage from the fire. Contamination has also resulted from the prior burial of up to 10 feet of smelting waste across much of the northern part of the Site and adjoining properties. Areas between the Site and Lake Michigan have also been in-filled with iron-ore slag material, with areas along the lake having up to 30 to 40 feet of buried slag.

Feature Description: The Mid-State Disposal, Inc. Landfill Site is located in Cleveland Township, Marathon County, Wisconsin. The Site consists of three disposal areas and is situated on the western portion of a 160-acre parcel of land. The waste areas are a 30-acre landfill, referred to as the Old Mound; a 7-acre Interim Expansion Area and the 3-acre Sludge Lagoon. When in operation, the Site accepted municipal, industrial, and commercial waste from 1970 under 1980. The Site operations contaminated groundwater with hazardous chemicals.
Data Disclaimer: The Agency is providing this geospatial information as a public service and does not vouch for the accuracy, completeness, or currency of data. Site Address Comment: The Site is bounded on the northeast by an 11-acre Weyerhaeuser Company sludge lagoon, on the east by agricultural land, on the north by a wooded area, on the northwest by a recreational trail (former Chicago and Northwestern Railroad right of way), on the south by Big Rapids Road, residences and agricultural land, and on the west by agricultural land. A sub-surface gas pipeline runs along the western perimeter of the largest waste area in a north-south orientation.

Feature Description: The 47-acre MIG/DeWane Landfill Site is located near the City of Belvidere, Boone County, Illinois. The MIG/DeWane landfill operated from 1969 until 1988, and was leased by various individuals and companies during the course of its operation. The landfill is classified as a Type I landfill, which means it is defined as a co-disposal facility where hazardous wastes were disposed of with municipal solid wastes. After the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act regulations in 1980 and 1982, wastes received by the landfill were restricted to nonhazardous.

Feature Description: The 24-acre Motor Wheel, Inc. Site is located at 1401 Lake Lansing Road on the northeast edge of Lansing, Ingham County, Michigan. The Site consists of a waste disposal area within a fenced parcel. Groundwater contamination originating in the waste disposal area extends approximately 1.5 miles south of the source. The property was used by the Motor Wheel Corporation for the disposal of an estimated 230,000 cubic yards of industrial waste from approximately 1938 until 1971.

Feature Description: The LSR Superfund site is located west of the city of Marion in Marion County, Ohio. The LSR site is comprised of two separate OUs. OU 1 is the Little Scioto River and OU 2 is the former BWC facility. OU1 consists of an 8.5-mile stretch of the Little Scioto River and includes site features such as the North Rockswale Ditch (NRD), the Rockswale Ditch, the Columbia Ditch, and the Unnamed Ditch. OU2 is the former BWC facility operated as a lumber preserver from the 1890s until the 1960s.

Feature Description: The 40-acre Master Disposal Service Landfill site contains an inactive 26-acre industrial landfill and is located in a marshy flood plain of the Fox River. Master Disposal, Inc. (MDI) purchased the site in fall 1966 and operated as the Master Disposal Service Landfill, Inc. from 1967 until partially closing in 1982. The MDSL facility accepted industrial wastes, non-industrial solid wastes, drummed liquids, and solids for disposal.

Feature Description: The Muskego Sanitary Landfill Site is located in the City of Muskego, Waukesha County, Wisconsin. The Site predominately consists of a 60-acre closed, covered, and maintained landfill area, which can be historically divided into three major landfill sections: the 40-acre Old Fill Area, the 16-acre Southeast Fill Area, and the 4-acre Non-Contiguous Fill Area. The Southeast Fill Area is located directly east of the Old Fill Area, and the Non-Contiguous Fill Area is located directly east and northeast of the Old Fill Area. The Site also includes some areas where unacceptable levels of groundwater contamination from the landfill came to be located.

Site Address Comment: The Site is located north of Janesville Road (State Highway 24) and east of Crowbar Road. The Site is surrounded within one mile by industrial, commercial, residential and some agricultural properties. Located directly north of the Site is the closed Stone Ridge landfill, and located west of the Site is a sand and gravel pit. Residential homes are located to the south and east of the Site along Janesville Road and Hillendale Drive.

Feature Description: The Neal's Landfill (Bloomington) Site is located west of the City of Bloomington, Monroe County, Indiana. Neal's Landfill initially consisted of 18 acres when it began operations in 1950. Between 1958 and 1965, the landfill was expanded into topographic low areas adjacent to a central east-west oriented ridge. The landfill received mainly municipal waste, but industrial was also disposed of until it was closed in 1972.

Feature Description: The New Carlisle Landfill Site is located at 715 N Dayton-Lakeview Road near the City of New Carlisle in Clark County, Ohio. The Site includes an unlined former landfill within a 21.7-acre parcel and a groundwater plume contaminated with VOCs. The Site was divided into two operable units (OUs). OU1 includes the landfill media (landfill contents, the onsite groundwater, and landfill gas) and vapor intrusion potential at three properties adjacent to the eastern side of the landfill. OU1 groundwater is the groundwater located underneath the landfill and within the landfill parcel. OU2 includes the off-site groundwater plume that has migrated southward from OU1.

Feature Description: The Nease Chemical Site is located near the town of Salem, in Columbiana and Mahoning Counties, Ohio. Between 1961 and 1973, Nease Chemical operated a facility at the Site that produced various chemicals, most notably a chlorinated pesticide product called mirex. The Site consists of three operable units (OUs). OU 1 comprises removal actions from the mid-1990s, including installation and maintenance of surface water and sediment control structures and construction and operation of two shallow groundwater collection systems. OU 2 addresses facility soils, source areas, and groundwater contamination on the Site. OU3 addresses contaminated sediment and floodplain soil in two creeks that received flow from the former facility, one of which extends into Mahoning County.
Feature Source: 2018 OU2/OU3 Remedial Action Work Plan, Fig. 1, pg. 2021

Site Address Comment: The former Nease plant is approximately one-quarter mile northwest of the intersection of State Route 14 and Allen Road. The former plant property is located in a rural area with light industrial and residential properties, bounded by small light industrial operations along Allen Road to the east and northeast, residential homes along State Route 14, and wooded areas and pasture lands to the north. Conrail railroad tracks traverse the former plant property. The Salem Wastewater Treatment Plant is situated approximately 2,400 feet east of the facility.

Feature Description: The 100-acre New Lyme Landfill Site is located in Ashtabula County, Ohio. The landfill is irregular in shape and occupies about 40 acres. The landfill received household, industrial, commercial, and institutional wastes, as well as construction and demolition debris between 1969 and 1978. The landfill was closed by the Ashtabula County Health Department because of numerous violations.
