Feature Name: NB Industrial Area Approximate Site Boundary
Feature Description: The North Bronson Industrial Area Site is located in Branch County, Bronson, Michigan. Several industries in the area discharged plating and other industrial wastewaters to two seepage lagoons between 1939 and 1981, and an industrial sewer system transported wastewater to both lagoons. The lagoons are no longer used for waste disposal but they contain large quantities of heavy metal sludges and contaminated berm soil. Operable Unit 1 (OUI) of the Site includes the two lagoon areas, a county drain adjacent to the lagoons, and associated contaminated groundwater. OU2 includes the sewers that were historically used to transport wastewater to the lagoons and contaminated groundwater associated with the sewers.

Feature Name: NSG Former North MGP Property Boundary
Feature Description: The North Shore Gas (NSG) North Plant Site, formerly the Manufactured Gas Plant (MGP), is located at the southeast corner of the intersection of Pershing and Dahringer Roads. Parcels 1 and 2 are owned by the gas company and are currently vacant. The parcel owned by the city of Waukegan on the south end of the site boundary is occupied by an operating city recycling facility. The Site is mostly vacant land but still contains some concrete building foundations.

Feature Description: The 2.6-acre Novaco Industries Site is located at 9411 Summerfield Road, at the intersection of Summerfield and Piehl in Temperance, Michigan. In 1979, a chromic acid leak occurred from a 1,870 gallon underground storage tank at Novaco, which led to chromium contamination of an onsite well. The Novaco study area consists of Novaco Industries, Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) Post 9656 and the Moyer residential property. This polygon include the Moyer residential property, Parcel ID 02 018 038 00.

Feature Name: Oak Grove Sanitary Landfill Land Management Area
Feature Description: The 104-acre Oak Grove Sanitary Landfill Site is located in a lightly-populated part of the City of Oak Grove, Anoka County, Minnesota, near the intersection of Edelweiss Street NW and County Road 22 (Viking Boulevard NW). The Site’s 52-acre landfill began operations in 1967 as an open dump and ceased in 1983 when it reached maximum capacity at 2.7 million cubic yards of waste. Most of the waste in the landfill is classified as commercial and municipal solid waste. However, industrial solid waste and liquid waste, some of which may be classified as hazardous, are or were (if attenuated since that time) also present in the landfill.

Feature Name: Oconomowoc Electroplating Co. OECI Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 10-acre Oconomowoc Electroplating Co., Inc. (OECI) Site is located at 2573 Oak Street in the Town of Ashippun, Dodge County, Wisconsin. The Site comprises 4 acres formerly occupied by the OECI facility and the Town's municipal garage, and 6 acres of adjacent wetland. Former operations at the site included metal cleaning and electroplating which used chlorinated solvents, cyanide and various metals. Operations ceased in 1990 and the buildings on site were demolished in 1992.

Feature Name: Old American Zinc Plant Facility Area Boundary
Feature Description: The 132-acre Old American Zinc Plant Site is located in Fairmont City and Washington Park, St. Clair and Madison Counties, Illinois. The Site includes the following areas: the Facility Area where former zinc smelting operations were conducted from 1916 to 1953; residential, commercial, and vacant properties around the Facility Area; alleyways owned by the Village of Fairmont City that have been filled or surfaced with slag; drainage ways that receive drainage from the Facility Area; and shallow groundwater within and immediately adjacent to the Facility Area.

Site Address Comment: The Site is located at Junction of 45th Street and Cookson Road, Fairmont City and Washington Park, St. Clair and Madison Counties, Illinois.

Feature Description: The Old Mill Site is located in the Village of Rock Creek in Ashtabula County, Ohio. The Site consists of two tracts of land separated by Station Street: the 3-acre Henfield tract to the south and the 10-acre Kraus tract to the north. Five dilapidated wooden buildings and four concrete silos were located on the Kraus property. The Henfield property was the former location of a feed mill and later a potting soil operation. In 1979, EPA and Ohio EPA found found approximately 1,200 drums of toxic waste stored on both the Henfield and Kraus properties. Many of the drums were in poor condition and had leaked their contents into the soil.

Feature Name: Onalaska Municipal Landfill Approx. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The 11-acre Onalaska Municipal Landfill Site is located in the Township of Onalaska, La Crosse County, Wisconsin. The Site includes the 7-acre former Township landfill, which began operations in the early 1960s.  The Town of Onalaska used the landfill primrarily for municpal waste, although chemical waste was also disposed of there for a time. The landfill was ordered to closed by September 1980 and was capped in June 1982.

Feature Description: The 228-acre Ottawa Township Flat Glass Site is located in and around the Village of Naplate, LaSalle County, Illinois. The Site was formerly known as the Libbey-Owens-Ford Plants 5 & 7 Site. The Site covers parcels on the north and south sides of the Illinois River. North of the river, the Site includes Naplate residential areas, Plant #5 (active), Plant #7 (inactive), former silica sand quarries, wastewater disposal areas, and a 56-acre undeveloped parcel of land. South of the river, it also includes former silica quarries and wastewater disposal areas across from the main facility. Pilkington North America, Inc. has operated the glass manufacturing plant from 1986 until the present day.

Feature Description: The 100-acre Pagel's Pit Site is a capped landfill which is a portion of the active Winnebago Landfill that is located in Winnebago County, Illinois. Two units within the Winnebago Landfill, the 42.6-acre Northern Unit and the 2.8-acre South Unit Expansion, are located within the Site boundaries. Municipal refuse and sewage treatment plant sludge (non-hazardous solid wastes) were the primary wastes accepted at the Site. Other industrial wastes were accepted that are defined as "special wastes" in the Illinois statutes.

Feature Description: The 3-acre Pristine, Inc. Site is located in an industrial area within the City of Reading, Hamilton County, Ohio. The Site was originally used for manufacturing sulfuric acid and fertilizer and was used as a liquid waste disposal facility from 1974 to 1981. In 1977, Pristine, Inc. obtained a permit to incinerate liquid waste on-site and accepted both bulk and drummed waste for incineration. The Site was closed in 1981 due to numerous permit violations. At the time of closure, more than 10,000 drums and several hundred thousand gallons of bulk liquids were on-site.

Feature Name: Parsons Chemical Works Former Property Boundary
Feature Description: The 6-acre Parsons Chemical Works, Inc. Site is located on West Jefferson Street, west of the city of Grand Ledge, Eaton County, Michigan. Parsons Chemical Works, Inc., which operated from 1945 through mid-1979, mixed, manufactured, and packaged agricultural chemicals including pesticides, herbicides, solvents, and mercury-based compounds. Liquid waste discharged into a stream which ultimately emptied into the Grand River, and activities at the plant resulted in the deposition of chemicals on soil primarily around the perimeter of the building, particularly the south side, impacting approximately one acre. Since 2001, the Shappell Corporation has owned and operated business on the Site.
Feature Source: Eaton County Parcel Viewer No. 030-010-200-010-00, as approximately seen in the 2019 FYR p. 21

Site Name: SANITARY LANDFILL CO. (INDUSTRIAL WASTE DISPOSAL CO., INC.)
Feature Name: Sanitary Landfill Co. Approximate Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Sanitary Landfill Co. (Industrial Waste Disposal Co., Inc.) Site is located at 1855 Cardington Road, Moraine, Ohio, in Montgomery County, Ohio. The property parcel on which the Site is located encompasses approximately 53 acres. The actual site area used for waste disposal is about 36 acres in size. The Site is approximately 2,200 feet long on the west boundary and 1,000 feet wide at the northern boundary. Landfilling occurred at the Site from 1971 to 1980.

Site Name: PEOPLES GAS LIGHT & COKE - DIVISION ST
Feature Description: The Division Street upland OU1 encompasses approximately 18.2 acres and is located south of the intersection of West Division Street and North Elston Avenue. North Elston Avenue runs north to south through the former MGP, dividing the OU1 into the Western Property and the Eastern Property. The Western Property is owned and used by PGL as a meter testing, maintenance, and office facility. The northern parcel of the Eastern Property is developed with a commercial restaurant/bar (the Bar Parcel) and the southern parcel is currently vacant, but was formerly used as a boat storage yard and marina (the Boatyard Parcel). The City owns the Boatyard Parcel and intends to develop it as a park.

Site Name: PEOPLES GAS NORTH SHORE AVENUE STATION FORMER MGP
Feature Description: The Peoples Gas North Shore Avenue Station Former Manufactured Gas Plant Site initially consisted of the North Shore Avenue Station Former MGP Site that included five upland parcels (known as Main, Pond, East, South, and MWRD. It was developed in 1926 by Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company (PGL) as a storage facility for manufactured gas. Now the site consists of an approximate 500-foot by 90-foot stretch of the north-to-south flowing North Shore Channel, which is part of the Chicago Area Waterway System (CAWS), that is located adjacent to 6659 North Kedzie Avenue in Chicago, Cook County, Illinois. The channel segment is about 1.4 acres in size and is bordered to the east and west by steep, wooded banks.

Site Name: PEOPLES GAS SOUTH STATION FORMER MGP
Feature Name: PG South Station Former MGP Boundary
Feature Description: The Peoples Gas Plant South Station Site is an 8.3-acre former manufactured gas plant site along the south branch of the Chicago River. This site is divided into two main sections. The eastern section is slightly less than half of the site and is owned by Peoples Gas. It contains a storage warehouse constructed in the early 1970s and a parking area. The western section, a bit more than half of the site, is owned by the City of Chicago. It is an open area where the city plans to create a residential park. This western section of the site was cleaned up several years ago under an Illinois Environmental Protection Agency voluntary program. This site is one of 11 MGP sites in Chicago.

Feature Description: The 100-acre Northside Sanitary Landfill Site is located on the east side of U.S. highway 421 in Boone County, Indiana. The closed 65-acre hazardous waste landfill at the Site is estimated to have accepted approximately 16 million gallons of potentially hazardous substances.

Site Name: PIKE AND MULBERRY STREETS PCE PLUME
Feature Name: P&MSPCEP Former Master Wear Property Boundary
Feature Description: The Pike and Mulberry Streets PCE Plume Site is primarily a PCE groundwater plume (5 mcg/L) that is centered near the intersection of Pike and Mulberry Streets in Martinsville, Indiana. This polygon covers a plume source location, the Former Master Wear Property Boundary, Parcel ID 55-09-33-394-009.000-021.
Feature Source: 2020 Proposed Plan, Fig. 2, pg. 44; property line as defined in the Morgan County Parcel Viewer

Site Address: INTERSECTION OF PIKE AND MULBERRY STREET
Site Address Comment: The groundwater plume extends downgradient to the northwest to a municipal wellfield and upgradient to the southeast just beyond the intersection of Jackson and Sycamore Streets, with a lobe extending to the west past the intersection of Morgan Street and Shirley Drive. The Site also includes a soil vapor plume whose extent is similar to the shallow groundwater contaminant plume, with the exception of an area of contamination that extends to the east on Washington Street.

Feature Name: Neal's Dump Limits of Excavation Boundary
Feature Description: Neal's Dump is located in southeast Owen county, approximately 4.2 miles south of Spencer, Indiana. The site is 500 feet northwest of Pottersville Road on the turnoff marked River Valley Estate. Neal's Dump is approximately one-half acre (100 feet by 100 feet) in size and is 50 feet above the flood plain of the White River. The former disposal site is a vacant lot amid several residential properties.

Feature Name: Republic Steel Corp. Quarry Site Property
Feature Description: The Republic Steel Corp. Quarry Site is located in Elyria, Lorain County, Ohio. The Site consists of a 4.9-acre water-filled quarry surrounded by 7.4 acres of densely vegetated land. A fence surrounds the Site's perimeter.

Feature Description: The National Presto Industries, Inc. (NPI) Site occupies approximately 325 acres. OU1 consists of an interim action of groundwater pump and treat systems at NPI; OU2 of constructing an Alternate Water System to address the contaminated drinking water north of the NPI site; and OU3 is the final site-wide remedy which addresses the Melby Road Disposal Site and includes the selection of a cap and a soil vapor extraction system.

Site Address Comment: The Boundary Road Landfill is located in the northeastern portion of the Village of Menomonee Falls in Waukesha County, Wisconsin. The Site address is W124 N8925 Boundary Road, and the section location is the SE 1/4 of Section 1 T8N, R20E.

Feature Name: Summit National Chain Link Fence Boundary
Feature Description: The 11.5-acre Summit National Site is located at 1240 Alliance Road in Deerfield Township, Portage County, Ohio. It is a roughly rectangular property at the southeast corner of the intersection of Ohio Route 225 and U.S. Route 224. Prior to 1974, the Site was a coal strip mine and contained a coal wash pond and coal stockpile. From 1974 to 1978, the Site was used for storage and disposal of industrial waste and incineration of liquid waste.

Feature Name: Town of Pines Site Area of Investigation
Feature Description: The Town of Pines Groundwater Plume Site is located in and around the Town of Pines, Indiana. The Site includes a landfill containing primarily coal ash (Yard 520), various properties within the Town of Pines, Porter County, Indiana, and/or within the Area of Investigation, where coal ash was deposited, often as fill, and areas of groundwater contaminated by such coal ash.

Feature Description: The 25-acre United Scrap Lead Co., Inc. Site is located in the City of Troy, Concord Township, Miami County in Ohio. The Site operated as a lead battery reclaiming facility from 1946 to 1983. Acid from reprocessed batteries was originally discharged directly to an acid seepage field, but beginning in 1972 it was neutralized with ammonia prior to discharge.

Feature Name: Ossineke GW Contamination Approx. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Ossineke Groundwater Contamination Site is located in the Southern portion of the town of Ossineke near the intersection of U.S. Route 23 and Nicholson Hill Road in Ossineke, Alpena County, Michigan. At the site, Area I is the center of Ossineke where the two gas stations are located (an area bounded by Old Ossineke Road and Alphonse Streets to the west and east respectively). Area 2 is the laundry/dry cleaning facility and its washwater pond located approximately 1600 feet north of the intersection of U.S. Highway 23 and Nicholson Hill Road. NOTE: The site was erroneously added to the NPL decades ago. The site is an underground storage tank site and was referred to the Michigan LUST program. However, since it was listed on the NPL - Superfund must keep track of the site.

Site Address Comment: The Site is located near the intersection of U.S. Route 23 and Nicholson Hill Road in Ossineke, Alpena County, Michigan. The site lies approximately 1.8 miles southwest of Lake Huron and is bordered to the west and northeast by wetlands .

Feature Description: The 5-acre Spartan Chemical Co. Site is located in  the city of Wyoming, Michigan. From 1952 to 1992, the Spartan Chemical Co. operated as a bulk chemical transfer, blending, and repackaging plant. Spartan Chemical filed for bankruptcy in 1992 and the Site has been vacant since that time.

Feature Name: Former Rockwell Int. Corp. Approx. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Site is approximately 30 acres and is located in a former industrial area which included glass and mirror manufacturing, and automobile and automobile parts manufacturing. The site and immediate surrounding area are used for residential and industrial purposes
Feature Source: 2020 FYR, Fig. 1, p. 27 and 2020 FYR, Fig. 2, p. 29

Feature Description: The Site is comprised of approximately 100 acres of undeveloped, rural property in Rose Township, Oakland County, Michigan. The Site comprises an upland area which is almost completely surrounded by wetlands. The southern periphery is heavily wooded with hardwoods. The middle portion of the Site, a rolling meadow, is bordered by a marsh to the west, east, and the northeast, and Demode Road to the North. Illegal waste disposal occured on 12 acres of the southwest part of the Site. Another portion of the Site was contaminated by lead battery sludge. A groundwater plume contaminated with vinyl chloride, xylene, toluene, and more underlies the Site.

Feature Description: The Schroud Site is an inactive site located at 12801 South Burley Avenue, Chicago, IL; although Burley Avenue no longer extends through the site. The Site is approximately 67 acres in size. The site was formerly used to store and dump slag material from Republic/LTV Steel. The surface of the site consists mostly of slag material once produced from Republic/LTV Steel with very little vegetation. There are no buildings located on-site. Indian Creek (Wolf Creek) flows through the northern portion of the site and parallel to 126th Street.
Feature Source: 2017 IL EPA Site Inspection Report, Fig. 7, PDF pg. 41

Feature Description: The 9.5-acre Thermo-Chem, Inc. Site is located at 4331 and 4321 Evanston Road, Egelston Township, Muskegon County, Michigan. The Site housed both the Thomas Solvent Company and its subsidiary, Thermo-Chem, Inc. facilities. Thomas Solvent Co. operated from 1969 to 1986 in an approximately 1.5-acre area in the northwest corner of the Site. Thermo-Chem, Inc. operated from 1969 to 1980 as a solvent and chemical waste reprocessing, refining, and incineration facility on the remaining eight acres at the Site.

Feature Description: The 8.5-acre Tremont City Barrel Fill Site is located in German Township, Clark County, Ohio. The Site is a closed, industrial waste landfill that contains approximately 51,500 drums of waste and approximately 304,000 gallons of non-containerized liquid waste. The Site has been closed as a barrel fill operation since 1980, and the land on the Site has not been used for any other purpose since that time.

Feature Description: The WPSC Green Bay MGP Site is located at 417 Elm Street in Green Bay, Brown County, Wisconsin. The Site is located on the south bank of the East River, is 14 acres in size and has corporate offices and as a parking lot for employees.

Feature Description: The Verona Well Field Site is located in the northeast corner of the City of Battle Creek, Calhoun County, Michigan. The Site includes three source areas - Thomas Solvent Raymond Road (TSRR), Thomas Solvent Annex (Annex), and Paint Shop - and the groundwater aquifer areas impacted by contamination from these source areas. Contamination at TSRR and the Annex resulted from leaks, spills, and dumping of solvents. Contamination at the Paint Shop resulted from dumping and disposal of paint thinners and solvents. Each of the source areas covers about one acre. This portion of the site contains the primary municipal water supply for the City of Battle Creek and several surrounding communities. It also contains Bailey Park, a public multi-use sports park.

Feature Description: The Ripon City Landfill Site is located in the Town of Ripon, Fond du Lac County, Wisconsin. The 7.3-acre landfill was a former gravel pit that was leased for waste disposal starting in 1967 and was capped in 1985.

A wetland area is located to the southwest and is a shallow groundwater discharge area. A former quarry is located across Highway FF to the east, and an operating sand and gravel quarry is located across Koro Road to the west.

Feature Name: FMC Corporation - Fridley Plant FMC and BNR Lands
Feature Description: The FMC Corporation (FMC) site is located on East River Road within the City of Fridley in Anoka County, Minnesota. The site consists of 18 acres, including 5 acres purchased by Burlington Northern Railroad (now Burlington Northern Santa Fe [BNSF]) from FMC in 1969 and 13 acres currently operated by BAE Systems (BAE). BAE was formerly known as United Defense L.P. (UDLP) and prior to that as FMC. The BAE and BNSF property boundaries which together comprise the FMC site boundary. The site is located approximately 1,000 feet east of the Mississippi River, approximately 30 feet above the mean river elevation.

Feature Description: The Pine Bend Sanitary Landfill (PBSL) site is located in Inver Grove Heights, Minnesota. The PBSL Site encompasses two landfills: the approximately 255-acres Pine Bend Sanitary Landfill which is an operating mixed municipal solid waste facility; and the closed 3-acre Crosby American Demolition Landfill located to the north. The two landfills are considered one site because their groundwater plumes comingle within the same surficial aquifer.

Site Address: OLD RTE 52 1MILE SOUTH OF OHIO RIVER
Site Address Comment: The Site is located in the Village of South Point, Lawrence County, Ohio. The Site is located between U.S. Route 52 to the east and the Ohio River to the west. Feature Description: The Sparta Landfill occupies approximately 26 acres of property and is located approximately one-tenth of a mile northeast of the Rogue River. About 12 acres operated as an open dump from the 1940s until 1972. The landfill was closed in 1977 and a two-foot sand cover was placed over the site. The Site itself is currently fenced.

Feature Description: The 6-acre former U.S. Aviex Site is located in Niles and Howard Township, Cass County, Michigan. The now-defunct facility produced non-lubricating automotive fluids between the early 1960s and 1978. A warehouse remains on-Site and is currently used as a commercial storage facility for recreational boats and vehicles.   2021 Additional Source: U.S. Aviex Site Area & Downgradient DCA/1,4-D Plumes  Source: 2019 Groundwater Monitoring Report (Weston, 2021), Fig 6, p. 36 and Fig 7, p. 37. Feature Description: The 82-acre Penta Wood Products Site is a former wood treating facility located along Daniels 70 in Siren, Burnett County, Wisconsin. The facility discharged wastewater from an oil/water separator down a gully into a lagoon on the northeast corner of the property. Process wastes were discharged onto a wood-chip pile in the northwestern portion of the property.

Feature Description: The 33-acre Rasmussen's Dump Site operated as a landfill that accepted domestic and drummed industrial wastes starting in the 1960s, but it was never properly capped and closed prior to termination of landfill operations in 1977. There is an unoccupied residence located on the northern portion of the Site, and an auto body shop and an auto salvage yard adjacent to the Site, near the residence. The Site is surrounded by a fence with a locked gate.

Feature Name: SZC Site Boundary – Village of Sandoval
Feature Description: The Sandoval Zinc Company Site is located in Sandoval, Marion County, Illinois. The Site includes both the 14-acre former Sandoval Zinc smelter property and the area within the Village of Sandoval corporate boundaries. Several areas throughout the Village of Sandoval exhibit evidence of the use of this site-derived cinder and slag in the construction of roadways, driveways, sidewalks, parking lots, and general fill.

Site Address Comment: The former smelter property is located approximately 1,440 feet east of U.S. Route 51 at the eastern end of Smelter Road (a.k.a. East Mississippi Avenue), and approximately 2,240 feet south of U.S. Route 50. The smelter property is bounded to the east and south by open agricultural land, to the west by a vacant parcel, and to the north by active CSX Railroad tracks. The residential area of the Village of Sandoval is located approximately 1,200 feet west of the smelter property.

Feature Description: The Sandoval Zinc Company Site is located in Sandoval, Marion County, Illinois. The Site includes both the 14-acre former Sandoval Zinc smelter property and the area within the Village of Sandoval corporate boundaries. This polygon covers the former smelter property which is inactive and abandoned with no intact buildings present. It includes remnant concrete building foundations and a dilapidated former furnace structure in the northeastern portion of the smelter property. Surface water features at the Site include a one-acre farm pond and a smaller adjacent oval-shaped pond.

U.S. Highway 10 borders the site to the north.

Feature Name: Sheboygan Harbor & River Approx. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Sheboygan Harbor & River Site is located on the western shore of Lake Michigan in Sheboygan County, Wisconsin. Site areas include polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-contaminated sediment in the river and harbor, floodplain soils, and soil and groundwater at the former Tecumseh Products Company plant in Sheboygan Falls. This polygon covers the former Tecumseh plant.

Feature Description: The Sheboygan Harbor & River Site is located on the western shore of Lake Michigan in Sheboygan County, Wisconsin. Site areas include polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-contaminated sediment in the river and harbor, floodplain soils, and soil and groundwater at the former Tecumseh Products Company plant in Sheboygan Falls. This polygon covers segments of the Sheboyan river that flows east through Sheboygan Falls, Kohler, and Sheboygan before entering Lake Michigan.
Data Disclaimer: The Agency is providing this geospatial information as a public service and does not vouch for the accuracy, completeness, or currency of data. Site Address Comment: EPA divided the Sheboygan River into upper, middle, and lower sections. The Upper River area extends from the Sheboygan Falls Dam downstream 4 miles to the Waelderhaus Dam in Kohler. The Middle River area extends 7 miles from the Waelderhaus Dam to the former Chicago & Northwestern railroad bridge. This area includes private 800-acre River Wildlife Area as well as the Kohler Co. Landfill Superfund Site, which was also a source of contamination to the river. The Lower River area extends 3 miles from the C&NW railroad bridge to the Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge in downtown Sheboygan. The Inner Harbor includes the Sheboygan River from the Pennsylvania Avenue Bridge to the river's outlet to the Outer Harbor.

Feature Description: The Stoughton City Landfill Site is located in the northeast portion of Stoughton, Dane County, Wisconsin. The property containing the landfill site encompasses approximately 27 acres. Since 1982, land exchanges between the city and the owner of an adjacent property have modified the original property boundaries. A wetland area that existed in the southeast portion of the current property boundary was the initial area of waste disposal.

Feature Description: The Ten-Mile Drain (TMD) site is located northeast of the City of Detroit on the western shores of Lake St. Clair in St. Clair Shores, Macomb County, Michigan. The Site includes a portion of the TMD storm sewer system, which consists of concrete sewer pipes and backfill material surrounding the pipes in a utility corridor 15 feet below ground surface. The Site is currently known to encompass several blocks where polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) have been found in the storm sewer system in significant concentrations, as well as areas where PCBs are known to have migrated through the storm sewer and discharged into the Lange and Revere Street canals connected to Lake St. Clair.

A borrow pit that was used to provide cover material for the St. Augusta Landfill is located on the northern side of the landfill.

Feature Description: The 270-acre Velsicol Chemical Corp. (Marshall Plant) Site is located in east-central Illinois, at the northern edge of the City of Marshall, Clark County, Illinois, along State Highway Route 1. Feature Description: The Cannelton Industries site is approximately 75 acres. The Site is delineated by five zones designated A to E. The former Plant Area is in Zone E. Zone B (“Barren Zone”) was the primary waste discharge area. It consisted of four acres north of South Street, and included a one-acre area which, prior to cleanup, was partially devoid of vegetation and contained stained soils and waste residues. Zone A (“Western Shoreline”), was used as a dump site for barrels and general wastes from the tannery. Zones C and D consist of the wetland areas as well as the Tannery Point and Tannery Bay shoreline areas.

The Cannelton site is located 1.5 miles west of downtown Sault Ste. Marie along the south shore of the Saint Marys River. The site is bounded by the St. Marys River to the north; 4th Avenue and the SOO Railway to the south; 18th Street to the west; and 12th Street to the east.

Feature Description: The Madison Metropolitan Sewerage District (MMSD) Lagoons Site consists of two sludge lagoons that are located adjacent to the treatment plant facilities. Lagoon 1 is divided by several cross-dikes (Figure 2) and covers an area of approximately 52 acres. Three dikes run in a north-south direction, effectively dividing Lagoon 1 into four subsections. Lagoon 2 covers an approximate area of 86 acres and is divided into three sections by two earthen dikes that run in an approximately northeasterly-southwesterly direction.

Feature Description: The Site is located in Gratiot County, St. Louis, Michigan, and consists of four OUs. OU1 consists of two sub-areas: (1) the 52-acre main plant site located at 500 Bankson Street, which is the location of the former chemical manufacturing facility; and (2) the “adjacent or nearby properties” (ANP) which includes the residential neighborhood located south and east of the main plant site, as well as two nearby parcels formerly owned and operated by Velsicol. OU2 consists of contamination in the sediments and fish in the lower and middle basins of the St. Louis Impoundment of the Pine River, which runs along the western and northern edge of the main plant site. The St. Louis Impoundment is created by the St. Louis dam, located east of the site. OU3/OU4 consists of the contamination in sediments and fish in the Pine River downstream of the St. Louis dam.

Feature Description: The Site is located on the east and west banks of the Muskingum River in the City of Zanesville, Ohio. The Site is corhprised of the southern portion of the water well field for the City of Zanesville (the Zanesville Municipal Well Field, or "ZMWF") and a former United Technologies Automotive, Inc., (UTA) facility, under which lies the source of the contamination. The former UTA facility, now a warehouse/commercial-type building, lies on the west bank of the river directly across from the southern portion of the ZMWF. The former UTA facility and grounds cover an area of approximately 28 acres between the river and Linden Avenue

Feature Description: The Burrows Sanitation Site comprises approximately 10 acres. The Site is located on 54th Avenue in Hartford Township, Van Buren County, Michigan. The property is located in a rural part of Hartford on a portion of property owned by a resident of Hartford. A drainage canal known as Doyle Drain flows intermittently at the northern boundary of the Site. The Site lies in a heavily wooded area along 54th Avenue. Much of the Site is covered with trees, and there are intermittent open areas to the east and northwest of the Site.

Site Address Comment: The Burrows Sanitation Site is bound by 54th Avenue in the south and forested area in the north, east, and west.

Feature Name: St. Regis Paper Co. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The St. Regis Paper Company Site, a former wood treatment facility, is located in the Leech Lake Reservation, Minnesota. The site, which includes a northern former operations area and southwestern former operations area, the former City Dump of the City of Cass Lake, and nearby residential properties, encompasses roughly 163 acres. There is one active industrial property located in the site area, several commercial properties, and the adjacent residential area comprised mainly of single-family homes.
Data Disclaimer: The Agency is providing this geospatial information as a public service and does not vouch for the accuracy, completeness, or currency of data. Data provided by external parties is not independently verified by EPA. This data is made available to the public strictly for informational purposes. EPA reserves the right to change these data at any time without public notice.
Site Address Comment: The site is located on the south side of the City of Cass Lake, Minnesota, wholly within the exterior boundaries of the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe's (LLBO) Reservation. The site is generally bounded by Allens Bay and Cass Lake to the north/northeast, Pike Bay to the southeast and Wolf and Grace lake to the west.

Feature Description: The Sturgis Municipal Wells site is located in Sturgis, Michigan. Two source areas have been identified as responsible for the aquifer contamination: the Kirsch Company Plant No. 1 property and the former Wade Electric Property. This polygon covers the Wade Electric property is currently vacant. A building, which most recently housed an ethnic grocery store, exists on the property, but is currently unoccupied. The Wade Electric facility, which manufactured electrical components for the auto industry, closed in 1966 and burned down in 1974.

Feature Description: The Sturgis Municipal Wells site is located in Sturgis, Michigan. Two source areas have been identified as responsible for the aquifer contamination: the Kirsch Company Plant No. 1 property and the former Wade Electric Property. This polygon covers the Kirsch property east parcel which consists of a vacant manufacturing facility, an active industrial piping installation firm, and a vacant lot. Manufacturing at this location ceased in 1980. Most of the manufacturing facilities previously located on the vacant lot have been demolished.

Feature Description: The Tri-County/Elgin Landfills Site encompasses both the Tri-County and Elgin Landfills and is located in Kane County, Illinois. This polygon coves the Tri-County Landfill which consists of approximately 46 acres and is inactive.

Site Address Comment: Route 25 bounds the east and southeast sides of the Site, along which are located several commercial businesses. The property adjacent to the north boundary of the Elgin Landfill is controlled under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Department of Natural Resources (IDNR), as is the property immediately east of the Site on the other side of Route 25. The WMIL Woodland Recycling Disposal Facility (RDF) occupies the land west of the Site and contains a former sanitary landfill.

Feature Description: The site is an abandoned tract of land with a collapsed house and barn and an old, inactive well that lies southeast of the house.

Feature Name: Refuse Hideaway LF Proprietary Control Boundary
Feature Description: The 23-acre Refuse Hideaway Landfill Site is located at approximately 7562 U.S. Highway 14 in the Town of Middleton in Dane County, Wisconsin. The landfill operated for 14 years between 1974 and 1988 and received municipal, commercial, and industrial wastes. A street improvement company is located on the Site property outside the fill boundary and stores trucks and construction equipment.

Site Address: SW1/4 OF NW1/4 SEC8 T7N R8E
Site Address Comment: The area surrounding the Site is predominantly agricultural with a wetland area located southeast of the landfill. The two residences nearest the landfill are approximately 2,400 feet to the southwest, adjacent to U.S. Highway 14, with additional residences in the Deer Run Heights Subdivision located at least 4,800 feet to the southwest ofthe landfill.

Feature Description: The 3.66-acre Reilly Tar & Chemical Corp. (Dover Plant) Site is a former coal tar refining operation, located in Dover, Tuscawaras County, Ohio. Refining operations stopped and the main Site property has been inactive and vacant since 1956. The Site property is covered by protective caps and grass. The drainage ditch at the north end of the Site has been covered with impermeable concrete and is monitored to ensure that there is no buildup of sediment.

Site Address Comment: The Site is located approximately 500 feet south of the junction of State Route 211 and State Route 39 (South Tuscarawas Avenue), and approximately 0.75 miles north of the junction of Sugar Creek and the Tuscarawas River. Land use north of the Site is commercial and residential, and areas west and southwest of the Site are industrial. To the northeast there is an abandoned canal turning basin that functions today as a drainage ditch. Public power and sewage facilities are immediately east of the Site, and immediately south of the Site is an open and undeveloped industrial area.

Feature Description: The 102-acre North Sanitary Landfill Site is located in a mixed commercial and residential area in the northeast portion of Dayton, Montgomery County, Ohio. The former landfill portion of the site is owned by the Keystone Gravel Company, which operated a sand and gravel quarry on the property from the late 1930s to the 1970s. Keystone's mining operations created large depressions across the majority of the Site. These unlined depressions were later used for disposal of commercial, industrial, municipal and other types of waste.

Feature Name: Ormet Corp. Reduction Plant Property Boundary
Feature Description: The Ormet Corp. Site comprises part of the northeast portion of the Ormet Primary Aluminum Corporation reduction plant property located in Monroe County, Ohio. Five former disposal ponds (FDPs) were used for process waste disposal and cryolite plant waste from 1958 to 1981. From about 1966 until mid-1979, Ormet deposited waste construction materials and other miscellaneous plant debris in a 4 to 5-acre area in the southeastern corner of the Ormet property, adjacent to FDP No. 5. Carbon deposits also collected in an area due to stormwater runoff from the plant, and some may have entered an outfall stream backwater area.

Feature Name: 0.1 mile buffer around BSCGC site point
Feature Description: The Broadway Street Corridor Groundwater Contamination site (the Site) is located in the vicinity of Anderson, Indiana and consists of three separate groundwater contamination plumes.  The origin of the contamination in each plume is unknown. The contaminated groundwater plumes contain multiple chlorinated VOCs, primarily trichloroethylene (TCE), tetrachloroethylene (PCE), cis-1,2-dichloroethene (cis-1,2-DCE) and vinyl chloride. Three impacted municipal wells, Ranney well #1, Ranney well #4, and Ranney well #5 withdraw contaminated water from a single hydrologic unit composed of the aquifer systems referred to as the Bluffton/New-Castle/Tipton Complex Aquifer System, the White River and Tributaries Outwash Aquifer System and the Silurian and Devonian Carbonates Aquifer System.
Feature Source: As described in 2018 Support Document for the Revised National Priorities List Final Rule, pg. 10

Feature Description: The Riverside Ground Water Contamination site consists of a ground water plume with no identified source. Low levels of chlorinated solvents have been detected in the groundwater within several of the City of Indianapolis municipal wells. The Riverside Ground Water Plume encompasses two municipal well fields, the Riverside Well Field and the White River Well Field, and is approximately 53.09 Acres. Potential current and historic VOC sources were identified within the project area site boundary shown, which includes properties within the 5 year time of travel for groundwater. The Riverside Ground Water Contamination Site was formally deferred to IDEM in 2017.

Feature Name: Morris Arsenic Dump Approx. Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Morris Arsenic site is located in Stevens County about one mile northeast of Morris, Minnesota. In the early 1940s, approximately 1,500 lbs. of arsenic-laced grasshopper bait were reportedly buried in a gravel pit near the intersection of Highways 28 and 59. The subsequent construction of the Highway 59 bypass through the general location of the burial site has made the discovery of the exact burial location difficult. It has been presumed that the arsenic was mechanically dispersed during highway construction since topsoil cleared from the site for road, bed preparation was later spread along the side slopes.
Feature Source: EPA Region 5 Dataset; description from 1985 ROD, p. 2

In addition, the site includes Cole Drain, and any place where hazardous substances on the property have come to be located.

Feature Description: The Muskego Sanitary Landfill Site is located in the City of Muskego, Waukesha County, Wisconsin. The Site predominately consists of a 60-acre closed, covered, and maintained landfill area, which can be historically divided into three major landfill sections: the 40-acre Old Fill Area, the 16-acre Southeast Fill Area, and the 4-acre Non-Contiguous Fill Area. The Southeast Fill Area is located directly east of the Old Fill Area, and the Non-Contiguous Fill Area is located directly east and northeast of the Old Fill Area. The Site also includes some areas where unacceptable levels of groundwater contamination from the landfill came to be located.

Site Address Comment: The Site is located north of Janesville Road (State Highway 24) and east of Crowbar Road. The Site is surrounded within one mile by industrial, commercial, residential and some agricultural properties. Located directly north of the Site is the closed Stone Ridge landfill, and located west of the Site is a sand and gravel pit. Residential homes are located to the south and east of the Site along Janesville Road and Hillendale Drive.

Feature Description: The 3-acre Pristine, Inc. Site is located in an industrial area within the City of Reading, Hamilton County, Ohio. The Site was originally used for manufacturing sulfuric acid and fertilizer and was used as a liquid waste disposal facility from 1974 to 1981. In 1977, Pristine, Inc. obtained a permit to incinerate liquid waste on-site and accepted both bulk and drummed waste for incineration. The Site was closed in 1981 due to numerous permit violations. At the time of closure, more than 10,000 drums and several hundred thousand gallons of bulk liquids were on-site.

Site Address: INTERSECTION OF PIKE AND MULBERRY STREET
Site Address Comment: The groundwater plume extends downgradient to the northwest to a municipal wellfield and upgradient to the southeast just beyond the intersection of Jackson and Sycamore Streets, with a lobe extending to the west past the intersection of Morgan Street and Shirley Drive. The Site also includes a soil vapor plume whose extent is similar to the shallow groundwater contaminant plume, with the exception of an area of contamination that extends to the east on Washington Street.

Feature Description: The Cedar Creek Site is organized into 2 OUs. The first operable unit (Plant 2 Site), represented by this polygon, is Mercury Marine’s Plant 2 located at W66 N598 Madison Avenue in the City of Cedarburg, Wisconsin. The building was approximately 66,000 square feet in size. One to six VOCs were detected at low concentrations in some of the wells and form a plume migrating offsite to the southeast. The second operable unit (OU2 A & B), represented by this polygon, is the creek portion of the Site. OU2 consists of Cedar Creek, its impoundments, raceways, free flowing reaches and floodplain soils starting after the Ruck Pond dam, then downstream 4.6 miles to its confluence with the Milwaukee River.

Site Address Comment: OU1 of the Cedar Creek Site is bound by St John Avenue in the east, a residential area in the south, Madison Avenue in the west, and Norstar Aluminum Molds buildings in the north. OU2 consists of Cedar Creek and its surrounding areas from Ruck Pond dam downstream 4.6 miles to its confluence with the Milwaukee River.

Feature Name: Shiawassee River, Steinacker Rd to CFC Facility
Feature Description: The Shiawassee River Site (Site) includes the former Cast Forge Company facility (CFC) in Howell, Livingston County, Michigan, and approximately eight miles of the Shiawassee River downstream to the Steinacker Road area. This boundary includes the 8 miles of the Shiawassee River. The river ranges from about 20- to 45-feet wide. Residences are located along the river; no PCB contamination has been found at any of the residences located along the river. Canoes and kayaks at residences along downstream portions of the Site during the Site inspection suggest recreational boating may take place in the South Branch of the Shiawassee River.

Feature Description: The Verona Well Field Site is located in the northeast corner of the City of Battle Creek, Calhoun County, Michigan. The Site includes three source areas - Thomas Solvent Raymond Road (TSRR), Thomas Solvent Annex (Annex), and Paint Shop - and the groundwater aquifer areas impacted by contamination from these source areas. Contamination at TSRR and the Annex resulted from leaks, spills, and dumping of solvents. Contamination at the Paint Shop resulted from dumping and disposal of paint thinners and solvents. Each of the source areas covers about one acre.

Feature Description: The Dow Chemical Company 1,900-acre facility abuts the Tittabawassee River; most of the plant is located on the east side of the river and south of the city of Midland. This polygon covers the area located in and along the Tittabawassee River and its floodplains, starting upstream of the Midland Plant, and extending downstream to, and including, the Saginaw River and its floodplains, and Saginaw Bay, and any other areas in or proximate to the Tittabawassee River and its floodplains, the Saginaw River and its floodplains, and Saginaw Bay (AOC, p. 11,  paragraph "aa")

Feature Description: The 228-acre Ottawa Township Flat Glass Site is located in and around the Village of Naplate, LaSalle County, Illinois. The Site was formerly known as the Libbey-Owens-Ford Plants 5 & 7 Site. The Site covers parcels on the north and south sides of the Illinois River. North of the river, the Site includes Naplate residential areas, Plant #5 (active), Plant #7 (inactive), former silica sand quarries, wastewater disposal areas, and a 56-acre undeveloped parcel of land. South of the river, it also includes former silica quarries and wastewater disposal areas across from the main facility. Pilkington North America, Inc. has operated the glass manufacturing plant from 1986 until the present day.

Feature Description: The Chemetco Site was a secondary copper smelting facility located on 41 acres of land located within a primarily agricultural, mixed-use area south of Hartford, Illinois on the east side of the intersection of Lewis and Clark Boulevard (Illinois Route 3) and Oldenburg Road in Madison County. The Site includes agricultural and wetland areas and a seasonal tributary to Long Lake (STLL) located southeast of the Site. The Site has been divided into two operable units (OU): OU1 - Production Area (inside fence), and OU2 - Non-Production Area (outside fence).

Feature Description: The Dover Chemical Corporation Site, Operable Unit 1, is approximately 60 acres in size and consists of a main plant area east of Interstate 77 along with an abandoned canal/lagoon area and a wooded low lying area west of 1-77. Operable Unit 2, off site groundwater plume, extends from the southern boundary of Operable Unit 1 (plant site) at 3676 Davis Road N.W., Dover, Ohio, and had, as of the issuance of the 2015 ROD, migrated southeast to approximately 5th Street within the City of Dover, Ohio.

Feature Description: The Ripon City Landfill Site is located in the Town of Ripon, Fond du Lac County, Wisconsin. The 7.3-acre landfill was a former gravel pit that was leased for waste disposal starting in 1967 and was capped in 1985.

A wetland area is located to the southwest and is a shallow groundwater discharge area. A former quarry is located across Highway FF to the east, and an operating sand and gravel quarry is located across Koro Road to the west.

Feature Description: The Ten-Mile Drain (TMD) site is located northeast of the City of Detroit on the western shores of Lake St. Clair in St. Clair Shores, Macomb County, Michigan. The Site includes a portion of the TMD storm sewer system, which consists of concrete sewer pipes and backfill material surrounding the pipes in a utility corridor 15 feet below ground surface. The Site is currently known to encompass several blocks where polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) have been found in the storm sewer system in significant concentrations, as well as areas where PCBs are known to have migrated through the storm sewer and discharged into the Lange and Revere Street canals connected to Lake St. Clair.

Feature Description: The 100-acre SCA Independent Landfill Site is located in Sullivan Township, Muskegon County, Michigan. Landfilling was done on 33 acres of the Site, at the edge of and in the wetlands on the south side of Black Creek. Groundwater downgradient of the landfill within the property boundary is contaminated above health-based drinking water levels and is restricted by the Environmental Covenant. See Figure and Description in Exhibit 2, Property and Areas Subject to Restriction of Appendix A, Declaration of Restrictive Covenants in the PRP's 2005 Five Year Review Report, SEMS ID No. 2003434 (Page 37 of https://semspub.epa.gov/work/05/2003434.pdf). The recorded copy of the same Restriction is available in SEMS ID No. 267224, Page 56 of https://semspub.epa.gov/work/05/267224.pdf).

Feature Description: OU3 is considered to include the full width of the Ashtabula River from the upper limit of the federal navigational area (located approximately 1,550 ft south of the Upper Turning Basin) , including the Upper Turning Basin (near the mouth of Fields Brook) and all of the river downstream to its mouth; Ashtabula Harbor (defined from the south end of the west breakwater to its north end; a line between the north end of the west breakwater to the east breakwater, by the east and west breakwaters), a line going from the south end of the east break wall to the northeast corner of Dock 4, and the portions of Slips 1 and 2 which are within the Federal Harbor Area (See Figures 1-1 and 1-2).  Excluded from this area are a) both slips at what is now Jack’s Marina (off the west side of the upper turning basin) and the “5 ½ slip” located between the current railroad yard and the River.  These boundaries were selected because 1) they include the entire federally-designated harbor area; 2) they include easily-defined areas (the riverbanks, federal navigation channel, and breakwaters are used for definition); 3) they include areas where contaminated sediments – including PCB-contaminated sediments – linked to Fields Brook had been identified at concentrations (pre-remediation) unsuitable for open-water disposal; and 4) The Five Year reviews for the Fields Brook Superfund Site describe OU3 as being “Ashtabula River and Harbor”.

Site Address Comment: The Fields Brook Site (Site) is located in northeast Ohio, in Ashtabula County, approximately 55 miles east of Cleveland, Ohio. The site’s source areas are generally bounded Bounded by St. Rte. 11 & the Ashtabula River to the west, railroads to the south and Lake Erie to the north.

Feature Description: The Wausau Ground Water Contamination Site is located in the City of Wausau, Wisconsin adjacent to the Wisconsin River. Historical operations at two areas of concern resulted in contaminated soil and groundwater at the Site. The first area is a Marathon Electric Corporation property along the West Bank of the Wisconsin River, which includes a closed former municipal landfill. The second area is the Wausau Chemical facility located along the East Bank of the river.

Feature Description: The Metamora Landfill Site is a 160-acre closed landfill that accepted industrial and municipal waste between 1955 and 1980. As many as 35,000 drums may be buried in the landfill. The area was previously used for gravel mining and there was an active licensed solid waste transfer station operating in the western area of the site. The site is split into three (3) Operable Units.

Feature Description: The Cam-Or Inc. Site is an approximately 15-acre parcel of land located on the north side of Westville, Indiana in LaPorte County. The Cam-Or facility was originally owned by Westville Oil, which began re-refining waste oil in approximately 1934. The former lagoons and a former well in the center of the Site which may have been used as an injection well are two potential sources of the 1,4-dioxane contaminant plume. There is also a plume of LNAPL that extends southwest from the site.

Feature Description: The site, a 32-acre property in southeast Bogalusa, operated as a wood-treating facility from 1911 to 1953, with creosote used as the primary preservative. The site most recently housed Bogalusa Concrete, which operated until 2008. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality referred the site to EPA for evaluation in 2011.
Site Address Comment: N/A

Feature Description: The Donna Reservoir and Canal System Superfund site is located in South Texas, south of the City of Donna, near the United States border with Mexico. The City of Alamo is located to the northwest. The site includes the 400-acre Donna Reservoir (also known as “Donna Lake,” “Val Verde Lake,” “Laguna Val Verde,” and “Laguna El Gato”) and a system of lateral lined and unlined canals and piping. It extends north from the Rio Grande River approximately 17 miles with lateral canals that extend approximately 5.6 miles to the east and west. The site is operated by the Donna Irrigation District Hidalgo County Number One (Irrigation District), which provides drinking water to the City of Donna and the North Alamo Water Supply Corporation Plant, and also provides irrigation water for the surrounding predominantly agricultural land. The Irrigation District may also own several portions of the reservoir and canal system.
Site Address: SOUTH TEXAS, NORTH OF RIO GRANDE RIVER

MacMillan Ring-Free Oil Refinery operated as a crude oil refinery and manufacturer of lubrication oil and asphalt products from 1929 to 1987.

A variety of chemical wastes from area petrochemical industries were deposited in several old sand pits and numerous drums of waste were also left on the property. There are no separate operable units at the Site.

Feature Description: The 19-acre Old Inger Oil Refinery site is located near Darrow, LA. A former oil refinery and waste oil reclamation facility operated on site beginning in 1967. Old Inger Oil Refinery bought the site in 1976 and operated the facility until 1978. Improper waste oil disposal activities contaminated soil, sediments, sludges, groundwater and surface water with hazardous chemicals. Following construction of the site’s remedy, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2008.
Feature Source: Fourth 5-year Review Report, 6/2022, Figure 1, EPA Region 6.

Feature Description: The 235-acre Sand Springs Petrochemical Complex site is located one mile south of Sand Springs in Tulsa County, Oklahoma. The site is located on the north bank of the Arkansas River. The area was the location of Pierce Petroleum Refinery and Sinclair Refining Company operations from the early 1900s to 1948. A variety of other industries operated on site beginning in 1953. Facility operations contaminated soil and groundwater with hazardous chemicals.
Feature Source: Fifth Five Year Review Report - March 26, 2020 - pdf page 122 of 124

Feature Description: The Lea and West Second Street Superfund Site is located in the City of Roswell, Chaves County, New Mexico and consists of four Operable Units (OUs), where soil and groundwater have been impacted to varying degrees by chlorinated solvents primarily from dry cleaning operations. The site contains four operable units (OUs): OU1 – 510 and 514 West Second Street, OU2 - 507 East Second Street, OU3 - Intersection of West Second and Montana, and OU4 - Intersection of South Virginia Avenue and East Alameda Street. This boundary includes the boundaries of all four OUs.
Feature Source: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) – Region 6, 2021 RI, Fig. 2, pg. 100.

Feature Description: The 280-acre Bailey Waste Disposal site is located in Bridge City, Texas. The site owner constructed two ponds on site in the early 1950s as part of the Bailey Fish Camp. The fish camp operated at the site until 1961, when Hurricane Carla introduced saline waters into the ponds, killing the freshwater fish. Disposal of industrial and municipal waste took place near the ponds until 1971. Waste disposal activities contaminated groundwater, surface water and soil. Following construction of the site’s remedy, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2007. Operation and maintenance activities are ongoing.

Feature Description: The Site is a former uranium mill and tailing disposal facility located in Cibola County, New Mexico. It occupies approximately 1,085 acres of land and includes a large tailing pile, containing approximately 21 million tons of radioactive tailing material, and a small tailing pile, containing about 1.2 million tons of radioactive tailing material. Both tailing piles are unlined. The Site also includes groundwater contamination that resulted from tailing seepage at the piles. Groundwater contaminants include uranium, selenium, and other radionuclides and metals. The Site was operated from 1958 until 1990. Groundwater contamination was first discovered in 1960 by the New Mexico Department of Health.

Feature Description: The DOP Site is located almost 20 miles southeast of Houston, Texas, in Harris County, and occupies approximately 26.6 acres. The Site is divided by Dixie Farm Road, into two areas referred to as DOP North and DOP South. The Site was used for processing activities spanning the period of 1969 to 1986 consisting of reclamation of metals and hydrocarbons from various source materials, most of which were catalysts, residues, tank bottoms, and tars of other processes performed at off-site locations. Site pits were closed in 1975 and 1977. The remedy involves capping the site with an engineered cover, improvement to surface water flow, and long term monitoring of groundwater. This boundary includes all components of the remedy.

Feature Description: The Brio Site is located almost 20 miles south of Houston, Texas, and occupies approximately 58 acres. The Site is divided by Dixie Farm Road into two areas sometimes referred to as Brio North and Brio South. The Site was formerly used for reclamation of petrochemicals from various source materials, most of which were residues, tank bottoms, and tars of other processes performed at off-site locations, with Brio North being historically used for storage purposes and Brio South being primarily used for processing activities. The containment remedy consists of a slurry wall, composite cap, and a groundwater and DNAPL pump and treat system. All remedial components are within this boundary.

Feature Description: The Southwest Jefferson County Mining Site includes all of Jefferson County, Missouri, excluding the Herculaneum Site. Jefferson County is located on the northern portion of an area known as the Old Lead Belt where mining began in the early 1700s. Mine waste has contaminated soil, sediment, surface water and groundwater at the site with heavy metals, primarily lead. Mine waste has also been transported by the Big River and manually relocated to other areas throughout Jefferson County. In residential properties, this material has been used as topsoil, fill material and aggregate for roads. The site is separated into eight Operable Units (OUs). OUs 1-3 includes the residential properties. OU-4 includes the Big River and flood plain, OU-5 includes Groundwater, OU-6 is the Valles Mines area, OU-7 is the Rail Lines and OU-8 is the mine waste areas. The EPA work at the OUs is on a priority basis based on the potential for human health and environmental risks.
Feature Source: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) - Region 7 GIS Team
Site Address: SLVR LK TRL & THNDR RDG RD,.5M W HWY WW

Site Name: WASHINGTON COUNTY LEAD DISTRICT - FURNACE CREEK
Feature Name: Washington County Lead District – Furnace Creek
Feature Description: The Washington County Lead District – Furnace Creek Site includes soil, groundwater, surface water, mine waste, and sediment contaminated with heavy metals, primarily lead, associated with historical mining activities. The Site covers about 533 square miles in the southern and western parts of Washington County, Missouri. Washington County is part of Missouri's Old Lead Belt and Barite Mineralization District where mining occurred for hundreds of years, hosting over 1,000 lead and barite mining, milling or smelting sites. Remnants of mining activities throughout the area include strip mines, mineshafts, mine dumps, tailing areas, tailings ponds and associated dams. As development in the area grew over the last 200 years, residents have built homes on mine waste. Tailings ponds are attractive to prospective property owners interested in building near a lake. Historically people have used mine waste as an inexpensive option for use in gravel driveways or even sand boxes for children.
Site Address: 2 MI. N OF INT. OF BIG RIVER & HWY 21

Feature Description: The Washington County Lead District – Richwoods Site includes soil, groundwater, surface water, mine waste, and sediment contaminated with heavy metals, primarily lead, associated with historical mining activities. The Site encompasses about 45 square miles in the northeastern part of Washington County, Missouri. Washington County is part of Missouri's Old Lead Belt and Barite Mineralization District where mining occurred for hundreds of years, hosting over 1,000 lead and barite mining, milling or smelting sites. Remnants of mining activities throughout the area include strip mines, mineshafts, mine dumps, tailing areas, tailings ponds and associated dams. As development in the area progressed over the last 200 years, residents have constructed homes on mine waste. Tailings ponds are attractive to prospective property owners interested in building near a lake. Historically people have used mine waste as an inexpensive option for use in gravel driveways or even sand boxes for children.

The Madison County Mines Site includes all of Madison County, Missouri, as well as that portion of the historical Mine LaMotte Domain, a historical land grant tract with a long history of lead mining, that extends into St. Francois County to the North. The site boundary is inclusive because residential impacts related to lead mining waste are widespread due to transportation and use of the waste for roads, aggregate, fill material, soil amendment, etc. Eight operable units are currently designated for the site: OU1 - the Northern Madison County Unit; OU2, the Anschutz Subsite, also known as the Madison Mine; OU3 - Residential Properties; OU4 - Conrad Tailings; OU5 - Catherine Mines/Skaggs Tailings Subsites; OU6 - Silver Mines; OU7 - the Little Saint Francis River Watershed; and OU8 - Railroad Lines. This boundary encompasses the OU3 Residential Properties unit as well as the other 7 operable units.
Feature Info URL Description: Memo to file re: site boundary expansion 07/30/2010. https://sems.epa.gov/work/1652734577328/07-40428948.pdf - This is not a public facing document.
Site Address Comment: updated to include "M" shape as part of the northern boundary

Site Name: BIG RIVER MINE TAILINGS/ST. JOE MINERALS CORP.
Feature Name: Big River Mine Tailings Superfund Site
Feature Description: The Site is located in southeastern Missouri entirely within St. Francois County, approximately 70 miles southwest of St. Louis.  The site resides within the Old Lead Belt, which was one of the world’s largest lead mining districts, having produced more than nine million tons of pig lead.  It has been estimated that some 250 million tons of mining and mill waste in the form of tailings and chat were produced in the Old Lead Belt from mining.  To date, eight source areas of lead-contaminated mine waste have been identified within the Big River Site.
Site Address Comment: shape not changed from the original 09 dataset

Feature Description: The site is located east of Annapolis, Missouri, on the east side of Iron County Road (ICR) 138, approximately .75 miles north of Missouri State Highway 49. Production figures from 1923 to 1931 indicated that approximately 1,173,000 tons of mining waste containing elevated metals was generated during that time period. Prior to the remedial action, the dominant feature of the site was a chat/tailings residue pile that covered approximately 10 acres in the northern portion of the site. The pile was composed of grey- to tan-colored material that resembled fine-grained sand. The material was highly erodible, resulting in steep-sided features and an outwash area that fanned westward to Sutton Branch Creek, which flows north to south on the west side of ICR 138.  The site is remediated and was deleted from the NPL in 2020.
Site Address: EAST SIDE OF IRON COUNTY ROAD 138
Site Address Comment: Site continues down stream on Big Creek to the confluence with St. Francis River.

This boundary includes all three OUs.

Feature Description: The Site encompasses 27 square miles and is centered around downtown, bordered on the east by the Missouri River.  ASARCO operated a lead refinery for over 125 years, from the early 1870s until 1997. Aaron Ferer, and later Gould, lead battery recycling plant operated from the early 1950s until the facility closed in 1982. Both the ASARCO and Aaron Ferer/Gould facilities released lead-containing particulates to the atmosphere from their smokestacks which were deposited on surrounding residential properties.  The Site was listed on the NPL April 30, 2003.  The City of Omaha entered into a Cooperative Agreement with EPA in 2015 to complete the residential soil remediation and residential lead paint stabilization.  The Douglas County Health Department entered into a Cooperative Agreement with EPA to address Elevated Blood Lead Levels in children within the Site and to investigate indoor lead dust contamination.

The Vienna Wells Superfund Site consists of three contaminated public drinking water wells and the source area, a former hat factory. The site property is a 7.9-acre parcel of land that begins at the southeast corner of the 10th Street and Chestnut Street intersection. The hat factory (facility) is located at the northwest corner of the site property and consists of two adjoining buildings that form an inverted “L”.

Feature Name: Ace Services Superfund Site and Groundwatrer Contamination Plume

Ace Services installed retention vats and an unlined lagoon to collect wastewater discharge. The wastewater ultimately contaminated the soil as well as the groundwater. On top of chromium, lead contamination was also discovered. A geosynthetic membrane topped with soil and vegetation was placed over 32,000 square feet of area to prevent the groundwater from being used. Pin 097-109-31-0-40-34-002.00-0. Former chrome plating facility.

Feature Description: Peoples Natural Gas Site is a former manufactured gas plant. The contaminated groundwater boundary has been identified as “TI Zone.”  EPA recognizes that it may not be possible to restore groundwater to its designated beneficial use in some cases. In situations where, from an engineering perspective, it is not possible to restore all or part of a groundwater plume, EPA may waive applicable or relevant and appropriate requirements and establish alternative, protective remedial strategies. The area where this determination has been made is called a technical impracticability zone, (TI Zone). This site outline includes a TI zone. Within this TI zone, controls limiting use of groundwater to prevent exposure are in place.

The Electro-Coatings, Inc., Site is located at 911 Shaver Road Northeast on the north side of Cedar Lake in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. The Electro-Coatings plant in Cedar Rapids has been in operation since 1947. The plant has performed chromium, cadmium, nickel and zinc plating. The site consists of only one unit. In 1989, the site was placed on the Superfund National Priorities List due to concern that chromium contamination might affect municipal wells of the City of Cedar Rapids, the closest of which is about 2,000 ft. west of the site. No impact to the city wells from the Electro-Coatings, Inc., Site, has ever been found. The site was delisted from the NPL in September 30, 2019.

Feature Description: The 7-acre Shenandoah Stables Site is located near Moscow Mills, Missouri. In 1971, a waste oil hauler sprayed a horse arena on site with dioxin-contaminated oil to control dust. Over 40 horses died and people became ill after the spraying. The same year, the contaminated soil was excavated and used as fill material in a new highway. More soil was removed from the arena and placed in a swampy area on the site in 1972. Following these actions, the soil at the arena remained contaminated. Site cleanup was completed in 1997. EPA removed the site from the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2001.

Feature Description: The 15-acre Aidex Corporation is a former pesticide formulation facility. In 1976, a building used to formulate the herbicide atrazine and other pesticides was destroyed by a fire. The surrounding soil was contaminated by water used to extinguish the blaze. In 1981 cleanup operations began at the site. Approximately 3,400 drums of pesticides were stored in open areas on the site, a concrete pit in the destroyed building contained about 2 feet of contaminated water, and a large underground storage tank also held contaminated materials. Soil and groundwater were contaminated by pesticide spills.  Approximately 600 people lived within 3 miles of the rural site.  A shallow aquifer underlies the site was contaminated, and 42 shallow domestic water wells were located within 2 miles radius of the site.  The selected remedies addressed the threat posed by the pesticides contamination in the soil and groundwater.  The remedies included: excavating buried wastes from within the perimeter of the disposal trench and transporting the wastes off site for disposal in a secure landfill.
Site Address Comment: shape not changed from the original 09 dataset

Feature Description:
Kem-Pest Labs Site is located on 6.5 acres in Cape Girardeau County Approximately 3 miles northwest of the city of Cape Girardeau, Missouri. The Site is located in a rural setting east of MO State Highway 177 in the SW part of Section 22, Township 31 North, Range 14 East. The facility operated a pesticide formulation plant from 1965-75. Plant wastes were discharged into a 2-cell lagoon on site.  Chlordane, Aldrin, Endrin & Heptachlor were detected in soil and onsite monitoring wells. An EPA inspection in 1983 revealed that the lagoon cover was eroding and that no vegetation existed on the clay cap. Cape Girardeau, with a population of 60,925, draws drinking water from the Mississippi River, at a location less than 1 mile downstream of the site.  Approximately 200 people live within 1 mile of the site, and 1,284 live within 3 miles. The site is adjacent to the flood plain of the Mississippi River. A freshwater wetland is located within 1 mile of the site.    

The selected remedies for OU1 and OU2 addressed the threat posed by the pesticides, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and semi-volatile organic compounds in the lagoon, groundwater and the formulation building.  The remedies included the excavation of 6,479 cubic yards of contaminated soil and sediment at the lagoon, complete demolition of the formulation building with off-site disposal of the debris, and monitoring of the groundwater to verify that no unacceptable exposure to risks posed by conditions at the site occur in the future, and therefore no remedial action wasrequired for the groundwater.  There are currently no land use restrictions for the Site. Neither is it on Missouri's Registry of Confirmed, Abandoned, or Uncontrolled Hazardous Waste Sites in Missouri. The site has been delisted from the NPL in September 2001 since it is no longer a threat to public health or the environment.
Site Address Comment: shape not changed from the original 09 dataset

Site Name: WHEELING DISPOSAL SERVICE CO., INC., LANDFILL
Feature Description: The Wheeling Disposal Superfund Site is located in a rural area near the city of Amazonia, Andrew County, Missouri approximately six miles north from the city of St. Joseph and six miles southwest from the city of Savannah. The site property consists of two contiguous parcels of land covering approximately 200 acres and is bordered by rural residences, open pastures and heavily wooded areas.
Site Address: OFF HWY K 1 1/2 MI S OF

Feature Description: The site is the location of a former manufactured gas plant, it’s situated along the Cedar River about one mile downriver of downtown Waterloo. Polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons, or PAHs, benzene, ethylbenzene, cyanide, arsenic, and some metals were identified as contaminants of concern in soil and groundwater at the site. Soil contamination was addressed through a removal action that was completed in 2001. The site has been subdivided into five separate areas (Areas I, II, III, IV and V). Areas I and II are currently secured with an 8-foot-high chain-link fence. The fence was installed around this area prior to soil excavation to keep truck traffic from the adjacent business from entering the area. The fence is not required to remain in place as a component of the remedy. Removal actions were conducted in Areas I, II and III. Remedial investigations did not reveal contamination warranting cleanup in Areas IV and V.
Site Address Comment: Updated to include the boundary of the TI Zone and the boundaries of Area I though Area IV, which were the investigation areas during the RI.

Feature Description: The overall Site includes the Tri-County Public Airport (TCPA) property and areas from the TCPA to the general vicinity of Latimer to the northwest. The polygon represents approximately 3.5 square miles TCPA which includes three former concrete runways utilized by the Herrington Army Airfield that approximately 150 feet wide and total nearly four miles in length; and TCPA operational buildings (current and former) which cover an area approximately 1/2 mile wide, east to west, and 1/2 mile long, north to south, on the west side of the TCPA.  The northwest extension of the polygon represents groundwater plume extending from the source areas on the TCPA.
Feature Info URL Description: 2020 Corrective Action Report and Kansas Department of Health and Environment Bureau of Environmental Remediation Identified Sites List Information

Feature Description: Site boundary currently city limits of Caney, KS

Feature Name: Superfund Alternative Site, Iowa City FMGP
Feature Description: A Superfund Alternative (SAS) site, the MidAmerican Energy Company former manufactured gas plant site. EPA recognizes that it may not be possible to restore groundwater to its designated beneficial use in some cases. In situations where, from an engineering perspective, it is not possible to restore all or part of a groundwater plume, EPA may waive applicable or relevant and appropriate requirements and establish alternative, protective remedial strategies. The area where this determination has been made is called a technical impracticability zone, (TI Zone). This site outline includes a TI zone. Within this TI zone, controls limiting use of groundwater to prevent exposure are in place.
Feature Source: Kevin Armstrong, GHD, Science Leader (EPA contractor)
Feature Info URL Description: Second Five-Year Review Report for Iowa City FMGP Site

Feature Name: Cherokee Zinc Company (Weir Smelter) Superfund Site
Feature Description:
The Cherokee Zinc – Weir Smelter site boundary covers the entire City of Weir, KS. Lead is the primary metal of concern, but contamination also includes arsenic, cadmium, and chromium.
Feature Source: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) – Region 7

The Site covers approximately 240 acres and is located on Extension Street, Verona, Lawrence County, Missouri. The Site is divided into three areas, the East Area, the West Area, and the North Property. The East Area and the West Area are divided by the Spring River. The East Area is east of the Spring River and covers approximately 100 acres. Manufacturing facilities are and have been operated on part of the East Area. The West Area is west of the Spring River and covers approximately 80 acres upland of the Spring River. The West Area contains a 1.3-acre subarea known as the Trench Area where manufacturing wastes from the East Area, including some wastes containing dioxin, were historically disposed. The North Property is immediately north of the East and West Areas and covers approximately 60 acres. The Site contains three operable units (OUs): OU1 is the dioxin-contaminated soils and equipment; OU2 is groundwater; OU3 is source area soils and groundwater. OU3 was established to address contaminants, including an emerging contaminant of concern, release both before and after the remedy was selected for OU2. The boundary includes the boundaries of all three OUs.
Feature Source: Environmental Covenants: Book 455, Pages 88, 2012, and 2103, Lawrence County Recorder, Missouri.
