Site Name: ST. LOUIS AIRPORT/HAZELWOOD INTERIM STORAGE/FUTURA COATINGS CO.
Feature Name: St. Louis FUSRAP Sites boundaries (except for Coldwater Creek)
Feature Description: The polygons depict two sites which collectively are referred to as the FUSRAP St. Louis Sites. The northwest polygon located just north of the St. Louis Airport is the approximate site boundary for the NPL Site referred to as the North County Sites and includes a group of properties referred to as the St. Louis Airport Site, as well as, several other properties between I-270 and the airport. This site also includes properties within the ten-year floodplain of Coldwater Creek which meanders north of this boundary towards the Missouri River. The polygon does not currently include those properties. This Site has been designated as Operable Unit 1. The southeast polygon depicts the approximate site boundary for the St. Louis Downtown Site which is not on the NPL. This site has been designated as Operable Unit 2.
Site Address Comment: This address is near one of the contaminant source areas on the NPL portion of the Site. The NPL portion of the Site also include many properties located north of the St. Louis Airport and along Coldwater Creek. The non-NPL portion of the Site includes several properties in downtown St. Louis.

Feature Description: The Site consists of two non-contiguous pieces of property known as the North Farm Operable Unit (OU1) and the Midwest Manufacturing Operable Unit (OU2). OU1 is located in a rural area approximately two miles north and one-half mile east of Kellogg, Iowa (Figure 1). OU1 is located on a dead-end gravel road and is less than one acre in size. OU1 consists of a trench that was used for disposal of sludge generated at OU2 in 1977 and 1978. There are five residences located between one-half to one mile from OU1, with the closest residence being one-half mile west of OU1. Since the previous FYR, the property at OU1 has not changed. The property remains rural and agricultural in nature, with no new residences built in the area. The only structures immediately near the property are grain storage silos. OU2 is located at 101 High Street in the city of Kellogg, in Jasper County, Iowa, approximately 42 miles east of Des Moines. The property was the location of Midwest Manufacturing Company. In 1973, Smith Jones, Inc., purchased the OU2 property from Midwest International, Inc., of Des Moines, Iowa, formerly called the Midwest Metal Stamping Company. From 1973 through 1981, Smith Jones, Inc., engaged in electroplating special order stamped metal pieces, a process which involved the use of various metals to coat manufactured products. It was owned until 2012 by Smith Jones, Inc., which was a wholly owned subsidiary of Amtek Auto Limited. Smith Jones, Inc., closed suddenly in early January 2010 and declared bankruptcy shortly thereafter. The property was sold to A-Line Iron and Metals (ALine) on June 25, 2012.
Feature Source: Fifth Five-Year Review Report for Midwest Manufacturing/North Farm Superfund Site
Feature Info URL Description: Fifth Five-Year Review Report for Midwest Manufacturing/North Farm Superfund Site

Feature Description: The 18-acre Wasatch Chemical Co. (Lot 6) site is in Salt Lake City, Utah. From 1957 to 1971, Wasatch Chemical Company used the area to warehouse, produce and package industrial chemical products. Between the 1970s and 1992, site operations included blending and packaging pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, industrial chemicals and cleaners.

Feature Description: The Whitewood Creek site covers an 18-mile stretch of Whitewood Creek in Lawrence, Meade and Butte counties in South Dakota. Since the 1870s, gold mining operations in the area included the discharge of millions of tons of mine tailings into the creek. These mine tailings settled along the Whitewood Creek floodplain, contaminating soil, groundwater and surface water with heavy metals. The Site contains one operable unit which has the same boundary as the site boundary.

Feature Description: The 160-acre Marshall Landfill site consists of two adjacent 80-acre landfills. The northern landfill is Marshall Landfill, and the southern landfill is Boulder Landfill. Marshall Landfill began operating in 1965 as a solid waste composting and disposal operation. Between 1969 and 1974, Marshall Landfill accepted municipal waste, unstabilized sewage sludge, and many unknown, potentially hazardous, wastes.

Feature Name: Mystery Bridge Superfund Site comp boundary
Feature Description: The 410-acre Site is located in Natrona County, just east of Casper, Wyoming. The Site includes an industrial area and a large residential area. The former KMI property is in continued operation as a mid-stream gas processing facility owned and operated by Tallgrass Energy Partners. The Dow/DSI property is currently used for storage. Site features include a Burlington-Northern Railroad line, which divides the industrial area to the south from the residential area in the north, the Brookhurst residential subdivision, and residences along Mystery Bridge Road. The site consists of two Operable Units (OUs). The site boundary encompasses both OUs.

Feature Description: The 120-acre Smeltertown site is located near Salida in Chaffee County, Colorado. Many industrial businesses operated on site over the past century, including lead-zinc smelting and wood-treating facilities. Site activities associated with these operations included the dumping of molten slag along the Arkansas River and allowing creosote and other wood-treating chemicals to drip onto the ground. OU1 focuses on the historic lead/zinc smelting operation area and includes an area of waste consolidation. OU2 addresses soil contaminated with wood-treating chemicals. OU3 addresses the area formerly occupied by the Colorado Zinc Company.

Feature Description: The Site consists of over 65 properties spread across Denver, Colorado, in the South Platte River Valley. In 1913, the National Radium Institute was established in Denver as a domestic source of radium, which was used in cancer therapy and research. The radium, vanadium and uranium industry thrived in Denver until the early 1920s. Site properties throughout the area were contaminated by radioactive residues from the processing of radium ore, leading to soil and groundwater contamination. The site's eleven Operable Units (OUs) are primarily in commercial and industrial use. OU8 Groundwater is the only OU that has not yet been deleted from the National Priorities List.

Feature Description: The 470-acre Sharon Steel Corp. (Midvale Tailings) site is located in Midvale, Utah. From 1906 to 1971, a smelting and ore milling facility produced lead, copper, zinc and other metals at the site. In 1982, the Utah Department of Environmental Quality (UDEQ) became involved at the site when it learned that nearby residents were gathering tailings for use in gardens and children's sandboxes. UDEQ tested residents’ gardens and sandboxes and found high levels of lead. The U.S. Geological Survey tested the groundwater and found high levels of arsenic. Facility activities and waste management practices at the site had contaminated air, soil, surface water and groundwater with heavy metals. Following cleanup, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2004.

Feature Name: California Gulch SF Site Boundary w/ deleted areas
Feature Description: The California Gulch Superfund site consists of about 18 square miles in Lake County, Colorado. The area includes the city of Leadville, parts of the Leadville Historic Mining District and a section of the Arkansas River from the confluence of California Gulch downstream to the confluence of Two-Bit Gulch. Former mining operations contributed to metals contamination in surface water, groundwater, soil and sediment. Cleanup is complete at over 90 percent of the site. Operation and maintenance activities at these areas are ongoing. Cleanup of the remaining areas is ongoing.

Site activities and waste disposal practices contaminated soil and groundwater with hazardous chemicals and radioactive constituents. Following cleanup, operation and maintenance activities are ongoing.

The site is in a narrow valley known as California Gulch. Mining for gold and silver in the region began in 1860 and ended in 1992. Historic mining operations contaminated soil and surface water with metals and other hazardous chemicals. The Site contains one operable unit which incudes both a surface and a subsurface remedy.

Feature Description: The Vasquez Boulevard & Interstate 70 (VB/I-70) Superfund site is located in northeast Denver, Colorado. The site includes two commercial/industrial areas as well as residential properties in all or part of the following neighborhoods: Cole, Clayton, Swansea/Elyria, southwest Globeville and northern Curtis Park. Historically, the area was a major smelting center for the Rocky Mountain West. Two smelting plants—Omaha & Grant and Argo—operated at the site for varying lengths of time, beginning as early as the 1870s, refining gold, silver, copper, lead and zinc. As a result, heavy metals were deposited in area soils at levels that, in some cases, posed a health risk to people living there. Groundwater was also impacted at the former smelter locations.

Feature Description: The 446-acre Midvale Slag site is located in Midvale City and Murray City, Utah. Five lead and copper smelters operated at the site between 1871 and 1971. Smelter facilities were demolished in the 1970s. Smelting operations contaminated groundwater and soil with heavy metals. Following cleanup, operation and maintenance activities are ongoing.

Feature Name: ACM Smelter and Refinery OUs 1 and 2 boundary
Feature Description: The ACM Smelter and Refinery site is located adjacent to the unincorporated community of Black Eagle along the Missouri River in Cascade County, Montana. The Boston & Montana Consolidated Copper and Silver Mining Company began construction of the first smelter at the site in 1892. Primary products from activities at the site were copper, zinc, arsenic and cadmium. Operations began in 1893, when ore from mines in Butte, Montana, was concentrated, smelted and refined. Anaconda Copper Mining Company acquired the property in 1910. Zinc smelting and refining activities continued at the facility until the early 1970s. The property again changed hands in 1977, when Atlantic Richfield Company (ARCO) purchased the site. Copper refining continued until the plant closed in 1980. Investigation and cleanup of the site are ongoing. The mapped area includes OU1 - Community Soils, and OU2 - Smelter Refinery Facility. OU3 - Missouri River is not delineated.
Feature Source: TREC, Inc; 2019 RI-FS WP for OU2, Fig 1-1, pg 117

Feature Name: Flat Creek Iron Mountain Mine and Mill
Feature Description: The Flat Creek Iron Mountain Mine and Mill (IMM) site is located in and around the Town of Superior in Mineral County, Montana. The mine operated from 1909 to 1930 and again from 1947 to 1953, producing silver, gold, lead, copper and zinc ores. Mining operations contaminated soil, groundwater and surface water with metals and other hazardous chemicals. The site consists of three areas, referred to by EPA as operable units (OUs). OU1 addresses the town of Superior. OU2 addresses the Flat Creek watershed, including the original mine site, the stream corridor down gradient of the mine, and site groundwater and surface water. OU3 addresses the Wood Gulch Mine Waste Repository.

Site Address: FLAT CREEK ROAD AND HALL GULCH ROAD

Feature Description: The site’s long-term remedy included constructing the Land Treatment Unit (LTU) and 13 soil staging and pre-treatment piles; building an addition to the existing water treatment plant; constructing two groundwater recovery trenches; and excavating and disposing of contaminated soils in the LTU. Cleanup also included removing and disposing of hazardous and non-hazardous waste debris; installing in-place treatment systems; relocating sewer and potable water lines; groundwater monitoring; institutional controls; and removing treated soil from the LTU and placing it back on site.

Feature Name: Milltown Reservoir Sediments Approx Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Site includes about 120 miles of the Clark Fork River upstream of the former Milltown dam and reservoir. From the 1860s until well into the 20th century, mining companies disposed of mining and milling wastes containing metals and arsenic in creeks in the headwaters of the Clark Fork River Basin. The mining and milling wastes then washed downstream and contaminated sediment, surface water andgroundwater with heavy metals. Much of the Site has been cleaned up. Remedy construction is underway to address remaining contamination. The site includes OU1 Water System, OU2 Reservoir, and OU3 Main Stem River.

Feature Name: Anaconda Co. Smelter Superfund Site, OU
Feature Description: The Anaconda Smelter Site (the Site) is in the Deer Lodge Valley in southwestern Montana, in and around the city of Anaconda. For nearly a century The Anaconda Company and its predecessors conducted milling and smelting activities at the Anaconda Site. Milling and smelting activities began in 1884 and ended in 1980, when the smelter closed. The facilities were dismantled by Atlantic Richfield, the successor by merger to The Anaconda Company. The nearly 100 years of mining and smelting activity in the area resulted in the contamination of soils, surface water, and ground water, primarily through airborne emissions and disposal practices from smelting. The primary Contaminants of Concern (COCs) are arsenic, cadmium, copper, lead, and zinc. The Site consists of five Operable Unites (OUs):  Mill Creek OU (OU15), Flue Dust OU (OU11), Old Works OU (OU7), Community Soils OU (OU16), and ARWW&S OU (OU4).

Feature Description: The 6,240-acre Rocky Flats Plant (USDOE) site is located about 16 miles northwest of Denver and 10 miles south of Boulder, Colorado. The facility manufactured trigger mechanisms for nuclear weapons from various radioactive and hazardous materials. Manufacturing activities, accidental industrial fires and spills, support activities, and waste management practices contaminated soil, sediment, groundwater and surface water with hazardous chemicals and radioactive constituents. The greatest contamination and hazards were located within the 385-acre industrialized area at the center of the property, where the majority of the nearly 800 structures were located. EPA divided the site into two separate areas. The 1,308-acre Central OU, or OU1, includes 384 acres in the industrial area in the center of the facility. The 4,883-acre Peripheral OU, or OU2, includes a buffer zone area.

Feature Description: The 7-acre Petrochem Recycling Corp./Ekotek site is located in northern Salt Lake City, Utah. Site activities have included operation of an oil refinery, hazardous waste storage and treatment, and used oil recycling. Improper and illegal waste management practices led to a number of releases and potential releases of hazardous substances at the site. These activities contaminated groundwater and soil with hazardous chemicals. Following cleanup, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2003. Groundwater monitoring is ongoing.

Feature Name: Colorado Smelter Preliminary Study Area Boundary
Feature Description: The Colorado Smelter Superfund Site in south central Pueblo, Colorado includes the historic Colorado Smelter, residential, commercial, school district, and City-owned properties within a one-half mile radius of the former smelter. The Site has two operable units: OU1, Community Properties and OU2, the Former Smelter Area, located south of the Arkansas River, west of Santa Fe Avenue, north of Mesa Avenue and east of Interstate 25. OU1 consists of a preliminary study area based on a one-half mile radius surrounding the former smelter stack location on OU2. Within OU1, there are approximately 1,900 homes and another 400 parcels that include vacant properties, commercial businesses, schools, parks and city-owned alleys within the OU1 study area. The neighborhoods that are adjacent to the former Colorado Smelter historical footprint and most impacted by Site contaminants are the Bessemer, Eilers, and Grove neighborhoods. This boundary includes the boundaries of both OUs.

Feature Name: Silver Bow Creek/Butte Area Superfund Site
Feature Description: The Silver Bow Creek/Butte Area Superfund Site was the site of extensive mining and smelting activities from the 1880s—when Butte’s mining barons made Butte the “richest hill on earth—through present. The Butte Area site was listed on the NPL in 1983. The Silver Bow Creek site in 1987. They were merged into one. The site follows Silver Bow Creek from the city of Butte in Butte-Silver Bow County to Warm Springs in Anaconda-Deer Lodge County. It is one of four Superfund sites in Upper Clark Fork River basin. Work focuses on arsenic and metals contamination from 100 years of mining and ore processing. Contamination is widespread in soils, mine dumps/tailings, interior dust, surface water, and groundwater. The site has seven operable units (OUs). Work at most OUs has progressed through investigation and feasibility study into remedial design, remedial action, or operations and maintenance (O&M).

Feature Name: Chemical Sales Co. Superfund Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Site is in Commerce City and Denver, Colorado. The Site includes soil and groundwater contamination originating from the former Chemical Sales Co. (CSC) property at 4661 Monaco Street in Denver. The Site is generally divided into two geographic areas and four Operable Units (OUs): the source area and plume area south of Sand Creek. (OU1) and areas north of Sand Creek (OU2/OU3/OU4). The site boundary encompasses all OUs.

Feature Description: The Jacobs Smelter Superfund Site is located within Rush Valley, Tooele County, Utah. The Stockton Area was the center of silver and base metal mining, milling and smelting district from the 1860s until 1970. No industries and few retail/commercial businesses currently exist in Stockton. In general, land surrounding Stockton is used for agricultural and recreational purposes. Wastes in the form of heavy metal contaminated soil, mill tailings, and smelter waste exist at several locations within the Site boundaries. The Site has been divided into six Operable Units to address smelter contamination. The site boundary encompasses all six OUs.

Feature Name: Bounday of former Broderick Wood Products Property
Feature Description: The 64-acre Site is in unincorporated Adams County near Denver, Colorado. The Broderick Wood Products (BWP) Company operated a wood treating facility to treat power poles, fence posts, railroad ties and other wood products from 1947 to 1981. Wood preserving agents used in the treatment process were creosote and pentachlorophenol (PCP). During facility operations, waste was disposed of on site, primarily in unlined impoundments in the northwest corner of the Site. Historical operations and disposal practices contaminated soil, sediment and groundwater with hazardous chemicals. The Broderick Investment Company (BIC) is the successor to BWP Company’s business interest and is the Site’s PRP. The consists of two Operable Units, both of which are included in the site boundary.

Feature Description: The 1,400-acre Summitville Mine site is a former gold mine in Rio Grande County, Colorado. Gold mining started in the late 1800s. By 1984, the Summitville Consolidated Mining Corporation Inc. began open pit mining for gold, copper and silver. Mining processes, waste disposal practices, and the discharge of large amounts of copper and other metals to Wightman Fork and the Alamosa River contaminated soil, surface water and groundwater with heavy metals. The remedy included construction of a new water treatment plant; construction of a sludge disposal repository; upgrade of the Wightman Fork Diversion and select site ditches; and construction of groundwater interceptor trenches. Additional remedial components included construction of a highwall ditch; rehabilitation of the Reynolds Adit; management of mine pool water; continued site maintenance; and geotechnical, groundwater, surface water, sediment and aquatic life monitoring and institutional controls.

Feature Description: The Site, a former lumber mill and wood-treatment facility, is located on the eastern edge of the City of Libby in northwest Montana. The facility treated timbers and poles with creosote and pentachlorophenol (PCP) from 1946 to 1969. Historical releases of wood-treating fluids at the Site resulted in impacts to the underlying soil and groundwater. The site consists of two plumes, a deeper and a shallower plume, and two Operable Units (OUs). The site boundary encompasses both plume extents and both OUs.

Feature Description: The Basin Mining Area site is located in and around the unincorporated town of Basin in Jefferson County, Montana. The site encompasses approximately 77 square miles and includes the town of Basin and approximately 300 individual abandoned mine sites in the surrounding watersheds of Basin Creek, Cataract Creek and part of the upper Boulder River. Hard rock mining in the Basin Watershed began in the 1870s and continued intermittently into the late 1960s. Releases of hazardous substances such as arsenic, cadmium, lead, zinc, silver and copper pose a risk to human health and the environment.

Feature Description: The Smuggler Mountain Superfund Site is a 325-acre site in northeast Aspen in Pitkin County, Colorado. OU1 is a largely-developed area that includes condominiums, mobile home communities, a tennis club, city parks and single-family homes on the northeast edge of the town of Aspen. OU2 includes a mine site on the upward slope of Smuggler Mountain just northeast of OU1. This boundary includes the boundary of both OUs.

Feature Description: RMA was established in 1942 by the Army to manufacture chemical warfare agents and incendiary munitions for use in World War II. Following the war and through the early 1980s, the facilities continued to be used by the Army. Beginning in 1946, some facilities were leased to private companies to manufacture industrial and agricultural chemicals. The On-Post Operable Unit is one of two operable units at RMA. The On-Post Operable Unit addresses contamination within the fenced 27 square miles of RMA proper. The Off-Post Operable Unit addresses contamination north and northwest of RMA.

Feature Description: The Sand Creek Industrial Superfund Site occupies about 300 acres within portions of both Commerce City in Adams County, Colorado and the City and County of Denver. Feature Description: Defense Depot Ogden, Utah (DDOU) is located at 1200 South Street and 500 West in the northwest part of the City of Ogden, Weber County, Utah. The DDOU facility has been a key installation in the Department of Defense (DOD) supply system since September 15,1941. The site has four Operable Units: OU 1 (Burial Site 1); OU 2 (French Drain and Parade Ground); OU 3 (Burial Site 3); and OU 4 (Burial Sites, 4-A thru 4-E and OU 4 Hotspot)

Feature Description: Tooele Army Depot (TEAD) was originally established in 1942 as the Tooele Ordnance Depot by the U.S.Army Ordnance Department. It was designated as TEAD-N in August 1962. In 1996, TEAD-Nwas designated as TEAD. TEAD has functioned as a major ammunition storage and equipmentmaintenance installation that supports other U.S. Army installation throughout the western United States. The installation currently covers 23,473 acres. Originally it included an additional 1,700 acres, which were transferred to the Redevelopment Agency of Tooele City in December 1998 under the BRAC Early Transfer Authority with contamination remaining in place.

Feature Description: The Monticello Mill Tailings site (MMTS) is located in Monticello, UT and is composed of three operable units (OU): OU 1 included the 78-acre former uranium and vanadium ore mill and the 90-acre engineered repository used for permanent disposal of remediation wastes; OU II includes 34 mill site peripheral properties covering approximately 1700 acres that were contaminated by mill tailings primarily dispersed by wind and surface water; and OU III includes properties contain contaminated surface water or overlie contaminated groundwater.

Feature Description: The Monticello Radioactively Contaminated Properties site, also known as the Monticello Vicinity Properties (MVP), is located in the city of Monticello, UT. The site consists of eight operable units (OUs): OU - A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H, that were contaminated with mill tailings from a former DOE uranium and vanadium ore-processing mill. This boundary includes the boundaries of all the OUs.

Feature Name: International Smelting and Refining Site Boundary
Feature Description: The International Smelting and Refining (IS&R) site is located about two miles northeast of Tooele, Utah, on the west flank of the Oquirrh Mountains near the mouth of Pine Canyon. The site consists of the Pine Canyon Conservation Area, the Pine Canyon/Lincoln Township Area and the Tooele Valley Railroad. From 1910 until 1972, copper, lead and zinc smelting and refining activities caused contamination at the smelter property and adjacent lands. Site investigations found heavy metal contamination in soils, tailings and slag. Following cleanup, EPA took the site off the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in October 2011.

Feature Description: The PJKS facility covers 434 acres is a military industrial complex which designs, manufactures, tests, and maintains rocket engines for the Air Force.  EPA added PJKS to the National Priorities List (NPL) in 1989.  Six operable units (OUs) were originally defined.  As data was gathered and interim actions completed, the OUs were re-combined.  The ROD addressed the entire site. PJKS is currently designated Site-Wide Ready for Anticipated Use (SWRAU).  Anticipated work in the foreseeable future includes monitoring the ground water remedy and evaluations on the effectiveness of the remedy.

Feature Description: The Lowry Landfill Superfund Site is located in the western three quarters of Section 6, Township 5 South, Range 65 West in unincorporated Arapahoe County, Colorado, approximately 15 miles southeast of the City and County of Denver and 2 miles east of Aurora, near the intersection of East Quincy Avenue and Gun Club Road; the street address is 3500 South Gun Club Road, Denver, Colorado. The Lowry Site consists of 480 acres, and is a portion of the Denver Arapahoe Disposal Site, owned by the City and County of Denver and operated by Waste Management of Colorado, Inc.. DADS consists of Sections 4, 6, and 9, Township 5 South, Range 65 West and Sections 31 and 32, Township 4 South, Range 65 West.

Feature Name: Approximate F.E. Warren AFB Site Boundary
Feature Description: Warren AFB is an active military facility which serves intercontinental missile operations. The facilities cover about 6,000 acres adjacent to Cheyenne, WY. This EPA added Warren to the NPL in 1990. In 1991, the Air Force entered into an FFA with the EPA and the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality (WDEQ). Response actions were organized into 14 geographically defined OUs which are now complete. The remedy includes five landfills under active monitoring for solid wastes, a large area of historic firing ranges, and six ground water plumes which are individually in operations and maintenance. The main ground water remedy for the chlorinated solvents is MNA. Supplemental site investigations and treatability studies are planned to optimize existing remedies and for investigating emerging contaminants. To date, no off-site ground water impacts have been found.

Feature Description: The Murray Smelter Site is a 142-acre parcel that contained a former mineral processing area and once the largest lead smelter in the country. The stacks have since been removed and the Site redeveloped. The site was awarded the Phoenix Award for excellence in Superfund Redevelopment. This boundary includes the entirety of the Site.

Feature Name: Upper Tenmile Creek Mining Area Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Upper Tenmile Creek Mining Area Site Boundary is 52 square miles encompassing all Site Remedial Actions under the Record of Decision as one Operable Unit, OU4 - Watershed. 52 Square mile former Hard Rock Mining District  Site located near Helena, Montana, with the population centers, Landmark Subdivision and the Rimini Community.  The extreme northern end of the Site is comprised by the City of Helena Water Plant located adjacent to Montana Highway 12 and Rimini Road.  The Southern  extent of the Site is the Basin Creek Mine Area (on the Continental Divide and location of the Luttrell Regional Repository) and is located along the Rimini/ Basin Road.  The West boundary is the Continental Divide Road with a slight 'bump-out for portions of the Bullion mine waste site (located at the top of the Minnehaha Drainage).  The Eastern Site boundary extends as far as the National Extension Mine Waste Site (Located just above Park Lake) the western and southern sides of the intersections of Chessman Road and Corral Creek Road not inclusive of Park Lake.

Feature Description: The Site in East Helena, MT is a 140-acre former Asarco lead and zinc smelter facility that operated from 1888 until it ceased operations in 2001. The site has one operable unit, OU2 - East Helena Residential Soils and Undeveloped Lands, and the site of the facility is under RCRA corrective action. This boundary includes the boundaries of both OU2 and the RCRA site.

Feature Description: The 71-acre Portland Cement site is located in Salt Lake City, Utah. Between 1963 and 1983, about 500,000 cubic yards of cement kiln dust (CKD) were collected from the Portland Cement Plant in Salt Lake City and deposited as fill material at the site. CKD contains several heavy metals, including arsenic, lead, chromium, cadmium and molybdenum. Additional waste disposal activities at the site included disposal of a few hundred tons of chromium-bearing bricks. These activities contaminated soil, air and groundwater with heavy metals. Following cleanup, operation and maintenance activities are ongoing.

Feature Description: Hill AFB is located in northern Utah, approximately 30 miles north of Salt Lake City and approximately 7 miles south of Ogden.  Hill AFB occupies approximately 6,700 acres within portions of Davis and Weber counties.  The Base is bounded on the north by the Davis-Weber Canal, a privately -owned irrigation canal, and on the east by private property.  Interstate 15 and State Route 193 form the western and southern boundaries of the Base, respectively.  This site includes 16 OUs.

Feature Name: Gilt Edge Mine Approximate Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Gilt Edge Mine Site is a 1,328-acre area that encompasses a former open pit and a cyanide heap-leach gold mine, historic underground mine workings, as well as prior mine exploration boreholes from various companies. The site contains 3 operable units (OUs): OU1 – Primary Mine Disturbance Area, OU2 – Water Treatment, Groundwater and Lower Strawberry Creek, and OU3 – Ruby Gulch Waste Rock Dump. The boundary includes the boundaries of all three OUs. OU 2 is media specific (water) and matches the overall site boundary.

Feature Description: The 450-acre Bountiful/Woods Cross 5th S. PCE Plume site is in southern Davis County, Utah, about 10 miles north of Salt Lake City. Operations took place at two areas of the site. From 1936 to 1986, Hatchco operated on 13 acres of the site as a specialized carrier of bulk petroleum, asphalt, and petroleum products and solvents. Hatch Service Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Hatchco, also operated at this location. The company occasionally used Hatchco facilities to service, clean and park tractor trailers and tank trucks. Bountiful Cleaners, Inc. (BCI) also operated at the site. Prior to the property’s connection to public sewer, wastewater from the dry-cleaning facility likely discharged to a septic system. This occurred prior to BCI’s purchase of the property in 1967. All these historical operations contaminated groundwater with hazardous chemicals. Bountiful has two operable units OU1 and OU2. The site boundary includes the boundaries of all OUs.

Feature Description:
The Five Points PCE Plume site is in the Salt Lake Valley in the cities of Woods Cross City, Bountiful and North Salt Lake City in Davis County, Utah. The site consists of a groundwater plume of tetrachloroethylene (PCE), a chemical used as a dry-cleaning agent or metal degreaser. 
Although the plume begins in Bountiful, it travels west-southwest and most of the mile-long plume underlies Woods Cross City and North Salt Lake City. PCE is known to have been used in dry cleaning operations at YVC between 1964 and 2002 before being replaced by a liquid silicone-based dry-cleaning solution.
The EPA placed the site on the Superfund program’s National Priorities List (NPL) in September 2007. Site activities have also included removal actions, or short-term cleanups, to address immediate threats to human health and the environment. Site investigation and cleanup are ongoing.

Feature Description: The 3,200-acre Smurfit-Stone Mill site is located 11 miles northwest of Missoula, Montana. A pulp mill operated on site from 1957 to 2010. The core industrial footprint of the mill site covers about 100 acres. The site is divided into three management areas known as Operable Units (OUs): OU1 covers approximately 1,200 acres of the site that are largely agricultural lands. OU2 is approximately 255 acres and covers the core industrial footprint of the mill. OU3 includes approximately 1,700 acres that cover the area of the settling ponds and parts of the Clark Fork River floodplain.

Site Name: ANACONDA ALUMINUM CO COLUMBIA FALLS REDUCTION PLANT
Feature Name: Anaconda Alum Co Columbia Falls Reduc. Plant OU1
Feature Description: The Site is located at 2000 Aluminum Drive near Columbia Falls, Flathead County, Montana. The Site was operated as a primary aluminum reduction facility, commonly referred to as an aluminum smelter. The Site also includes seven closed landfills, one open landfill that hasn’t been used since 2009, two closed leachate ponds, and several percolation ponds. This site contains one operable and six decisional units. This boundary includes the boundaries of all six decisional units.

Feature Description: Ellsworth Air Force Base currently covers approximately 5,000 acres, has been active since 1942 and has operated several types of aircraft and missile systems. Contamination resulting from operational support activities, such as disposal (i.e., landfills), fire training activities, accidental spills, and leaks, has been identified and investigated within 14 OUs. Remedies have been implemented in accordance with each OU-specific ROD. Contaminated media include soil, sediment, groundwater, and surface water. Contaminants of concern include chlorinated solvents and related products, radioactive materials, and most recently per and polyfluoroalkyl substances or PFAS. OU-13 has been designated for PFAS which has an ongoing remedial investigation of the nature and extent of contamination as well as several time critical and non-time critical removal actions to provide safe drinking water to impacted residents south and east of the Base.

Feature Description: The Davenport and Flagstaff Smelters site is located about 15 miles southeast of Salt Lake City, Utah, in a mostly residential and commercial area at the mouth of Little Cottonwood Canyon. The Davenport and Flagstaff Smelters were constructed around 1870 at the mouth of Little Cottonwood Canyon. Both of the smelters processed lead and silver ore removed from mines near Alta, Utah. Historical operations contaminated soil with metals. Operators decommissioned and dismantled both smelters by 1879. Subsequently, site use was mostly agricultural until the 1970s and 1980s when a restaurant and a residential community began to develop. The site consists of three operable units (OUs). OU1 addresses residential properties with lead and arsenic contamination in surface and subsurface soils. OU2 covers about 29 acres and consists of a mixture of commercial and undeveloped land. OU3 addresses agricultural land proposed for future residential use near the Flagstaff Smelter.

Feature Name: PGA North 1Q22 + PGA South 4Q21 Groundwater Plumes
Feature Description: The PGA Superfund Site is located approximately 17 miles west of downtown Phoenix. EPA has divided the PGA Superfund Site into two distinct geographic areas: (1) PGA Superfund Site South Area, and (2) PHA Superfund Site North Area. The PGA North Area includes the former Unidynamics-Phoenix, Incorporated (UPI) facility, which was located on approximately 58 acres. The PGA South Area is approximately 850 acres of land and is the location of the former Goodyear Aerospace Corporation facility owned by Goodyear Tire and Rubber (currently owned by JRC Goodyear Corporation) and the Litchfield Park Naval Air Facility, currently the Phoenix Goodyear Airport.
Feature Source: Haley & Aldrich (2022), PGAS GWMR, 2H2021. Matrix New World (2022), PGAN GWMR, 1Q2022.

Feature Description: The Hassayampa Landfill site is located about 10 miles west of Buckeye, Arizona. For an 18-month period between 1979-1980, hazardous waste was dumped at this 10-acre site. The waste consisted of 3.28 million gallons of liquids and 4.150 tons of solids in unlined pits. The landfill pits were subsequently covered with native soil and restored to grade. The area was unlined, so chemicals from the waste seeped into the groundwater and soils. This boundary represents the entire area of the former hazardous waste landfill, including contaminated and uncontaminated areas.

Feature Description: The AMCO Chemical site is located at 1414 3rd Street in Oakland, California. It is one block south of the West Oakland Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) station. AMCO Chemical Corporation owned and operated a chemical distribution facility at the site from the 1960s until 1989. Concern about environmental conditions at and near the site arose in June 1995, when utility workers encountered strong chemical odors while digging in the area. Preliminary sampling at the site and on 3rd Street, south of the site, indicated the presence of vinyl chloride and other chlorinated solvents in soil, soil gas and groundwater. Site investigations and cleanup planning are ongoing.

Feature Description: Sacramento Army Depot is a 490-acre parcel used for industrial/commercial purposes and by the Department of Defense (Navy/Marine Corps and Army), California Army National Guard, and the City of Sacramento. The site consists of three operable units (OUs): South Post Burn Pits/Corrective Action Management Unit (CAMU), South Post Plume, and Parking Lot #3 Groundwater. This boundary includes the boundaries of all three OUs.

Feature Description: The 6,368-acre Travis Air Force Base site is located in Fairfield, California. Activities at landfills, fire training areas, a radioactive burial site and solvent spill areas contaminated groundwater, soil and Union Creek with volatile organic compounds (VOCs), metals and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Multiple soil and groundwater contaminated sites are included in the boundaries.

Feature Description: NWS Concord is composed of these two geographically separate units, the Inland (5,170 acres) and Tidal (7,630 acres) Areas, plus a 1-acre radiography facility in Pittsburgh, California where the Navy historically operated a naval ordnance support base for the Pacific Coast beginning in 1942. The Tidal Area continues to function as a major ammunition trans-shipment port on the West Coast for the Department of Defense (DoD) and is operated by the U.S. Army as Military Ocean Terminal Concord (MOTCO). This boundary includes the boundaries for all OUs at the Inland Area and the Tidal Area.

Feature Description: The J.H. Baxter Site is a 850-acre site that contained a facility in which J.H. Baxter operated a wood treatment plant. Waste disposal, handling, and discharge practices over more than 50 years of plant operation resulted in Site soil, groundwater, surface water, and sediment contamination. The site contains three operable units (OUs): OU1 - Overall Site, OU2 - Groundwater, OU3 - Soil. This boundary includes the boundaries of all three OUs.

Feature Description: Montrose Chemical Corporation operated a technical grade dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) pesticide manufacturing plant at 20201 S. Normandie Avenue in Los Angeles, California from 1947 to 1982. The Montrose Superfund Site occupies approximately 18 acres within the Harbor Gateway area of the City of Los Angeles, including the 13-acre former Montrose plant property, the adjacent 5-acre Jones Chemicals, Inc. (JCI) property, and other areas impacted by the former plant operations.
Feature Source: PRP delineation of overall groundwater plume

Feature Description: The former TRW Microwave site is located in a topographically flat area of the Santa Clara Valley. Between 2001 and 2003, a portion of the building was demolished and a new structure was constructed. TRW assembled and tested microwave and semiconductor components between 1968 and 1993. TRW used TCE and several other industrial solvents and hazardous compounds. TRW stored waste solvents (mostly TCE) in an underground storage tank from 1970 through 1982. An in-ground, three-stage, ammonia gas acid neutralization system was operated from 1968 to 1984. An aboveground acid neutralization system was operated from 1984 to 2001. Between 1983 and 1986, several subsurface investigations were conducted in the vicinity of the former areas of the underground storage tank, and the acid neutralization systems. The investigations identified VOCs as the only contaminants of concern at the TRW Site, and the former underground storage tank area as the only source of VOCs impacting groundwater.

Feature Name: Lorentz Barrel & Drum OUs 1 and 2 Boundary
Feature Description: The former Lorentz Barrel & Drum facility was a 6.72-acre recycling facility that accepted over two million drums from more than 3,000 parties that contained aqueous wastes, organic solvents, acids, oxidizers, and oils. The Site contains two operable units (OUs): OU-1 consists of the contaminated soil and the deep aquifers and OU-2 is defined as the shallow groundwater. This boundary includes both OUs.
Feature Source: Pegasus Geoscience; 2021 Annual Groundwater Monitoring Report, Figures 6a-7b, pages 34-37

Site Name: FAIRCHILD SEMICONDUCTOR CORP. (SOUTH SAN JOSE PLANT)
Feature Description: The Fairchild is a 22-acre site located west of Highway 101 about nine miles southeast of downtown San Jose. The plant was used for electronics and semiconductor fabrication from 1977 to 1983. Solvents containing volatile organic compounds (VOCs), primarily 1,1,1 Trichloroethane (1,1,1-TCA), were used at the Site. In 1981, investigations related to a fractured pipeline at the facility identified that Site soils had been impacted by VOCs released from a waste solvent storage tank. From 1979 until 1987, Fairchild was a wholly owned subsidiary of Schlumberger Technology Corporation (STC). STC sold the Site to a commercial developer in 1990, but has remained the Potentially Responsible Party, and has been responsible for environmental cleanup at the Site

Site Address: SW COR OF JENSEN & W AVE

Feature Description: The 656 acre Leviathan Mine property lies within a remote portion of northeastern Alpine County, California, on the eastern flank of the central Sierra Nevada, near the California- Nevada border, approximately 25 miles southeast of Lake Tahoe, and 6 miles east of Markleeville, California. Of the total property, approximately 253 acres evince visible disturbance by mine related activities. With the exception of approximately 21 acres of disturbance on land managed by the United States Department of Agriculture, Forest Service (U.S. Forest Service), the entire surface disturbance is on the mine site owned by the state of California.

Feature Description: The site includes contaminated soil and groundwater in an industrial area in Rialto, California known as the “160-acre area,” and contaminated groundwater that has spread to the south and east. Feature Description: The Stringfellow Site consists of a 17-acre area at the head of Pyrite Canyon in the Jurupa Mountains in western Riverside County, California. The Site was operated by the Stringfellow Quarry Company as a bulk liquid disposal facility from August 21, 1956 to November 19, 1972. During that period, approximately 34 million gallons of industrial wastes including acids, solvents, pesticides, and heavy metals were disposed of in unlined evaporation ponds. Metals and organic compounds have percolated into the underlying groundwater aquifer, and the contaminant plume has migrated from the Site.

Feature Description: Site boundary includes the location of two former large, low-rise industrial buildings connected by a hallway (formerly 901 and 902 Thompson Place) and extends east to DeGuigne Drive. The AMD site includes seven other commercial buildings. AMD manufactured printed circuit boards and semiconductors continuously between 1969 and 1992. AMD used trichloroethylene (TCE) and other industrial solvents for cleaning and degreasing, although TCE use reportedly ceased around 1979. Acids were used for etching, and caustics were used for acid neutralization. Acid neutralization systems, including inground sumps, were used at both AMD buildings between 1969 and 1984. Related hazardous wastes generated from these various operations were stored on-site. Additional studies of groundwater contamination in the 1980s identified chlorinated volatile organic compounds (VOCs), primarily TCE, cis-1,2-dichloroethylene (cDCE) and vinyl chloride, in the upper 65 feet of soil under the AMD Site.

Feature Description: The Site comprises approximately 25 acres of relatively flat land at approximately 40 feet above sea level, in Sunnyvale, California. Land use in the area is both residential and commercial. AMD operated a facility for manufacturing of electrical components. Chemicals historically used by AMD included solvents and corrosives. The primary on-site source of TCE in groundwater appears to have been a leak from one of the tanks on neutralization system. AMD and related entities utilized the Site as a semiconductor fabrication and a research and development facility from 1974 until approximately 2015. Manufacturing at the site ceased in 2009. Site operations affected the shallow groundwater quality at the Site and contributed to regional comingled groundwater contamination in the area.

Feature Name: NASA JPL Site and Plume Boundary
Feature Description: The NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory Site is a 176-acre area in Pasadena, California. Past Research and Development activities by NASA contaminated local groundwater with various chemicals, including chlorinated solvents and perchlorate. It consists of 3 Operable Units (OUs). OU1-On Facility Groundwater, OU2-On-Facility Soil (Source Area), and OU3-Off-Facility Groundwater. The boundary includes the boundaries of all 3 OUs and the facility.

Feature Description: The Asarco Hayden Superfund Alternative Site is an active copper ore processing concentrating and smelter facility located in Gila and Pinal Counties, Arizona. The facility is located approximately 100 miles southeast of Phoenix and 50 miles northeast of Tucson. The site includes the towns of Hayden and Winkelman, an active crusher, concentrator, smelter and tailings impoundment areas as well as an inactive smelter and tailings piles. ASARCO constructed its Hayden smelter facility in 1911 and processing has continued to the present day. In 1958 Kennecott mining operated an additional smelter from 1958 until 1982. These facilities continue to release arsenic copper, lead, cadmium and chromium into the air which have impacted the nearby towns of Hayden and Winkelman.
Feature Source: Based off of the 2021 Phase II Remedial Investigation Report

Feature Name: Site Boundary and Off-site Groundwater Plumes
Feature Description: The 724-acre Sharpe Army Depot site is a former Defense Logistics Agency facility near Lathrop, California. Between 1941 and 1975, maintenance of aircraft, vehicles, industrial equipment and medical equipment produced a variety of chemical wastes. The Army later disposed of the chemicals on site, contaminating groundwater and soil with volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The site includes a groundwater Operable Unit with multiple on and off-site groundwater plumes and a soil Operable Unit with multiple areas of contaminated soil sites. This boundary includes the original Depot site area encompassing all soil sites as well as the location of off-site groundwater contamination.

Feature Description: Site description from SEMS: The site is approximately 27 acres . . . the inverted 'L' shaped site includes a facility area in the northern most portion and the former airstrip making up the entire east side of the property. Feature Description: The mine used various mining methods to process ore into copper, and these methods required a mix of chemical fluids. Chemicals were placed in two areas downhill from the mine in the southwestern portion of the site. This area was unlined, meaning there was no protective layer to contain the chemicals. As a result, the liquid chemicals seeped into the ground below the disposal area and polluted a groundwater drinking source known as the “basin-fill aquifer.” The boundary includes the original mine site and the extent of contamination in the basin-fill groundwater aquifer.

Feature Description: The Apache Powder Superfund Site is located in Cochise County, Arizona, approximately seven miles southeast of the incorporated town of Benson and 2.5 miles southwest of the unincorporated town of St. David. The site study area covers approximately nine square miles and includes 1,100 acres of land owned by Apache Nitrogen Products, Inc. (ANPI), formerly known as the Apache Powder Company. The San Pedro River bounds the eastern side of the site, running from the southeast corner of the property north towards the northwest. The San Pedro River National Conservation Area (SPRNCA), owned by the Bureau of Land Management, is located approximately two miles south of the site along the San Pedro River.
Feature Source: GIS Team created it; 2020 Annual Performance Monitoring Report, Figure 1, pg 158

Feature Description: The Port Hadlock Detachment (US NAVY) site is located on Indian Island southeast of Port Townsend, Washington. Indian Island is approximately 5 miles long and 2,716 acres in size. The island is wholly owned by the Navy and is primarily used for handling and disposal of naval ordnance. There are 14 military residences on Indian Island itself. There are several Native American sites on the island, as well as historically significant pioneer homestead sites and World War II era buildings. The nineteen sites of concern identified on Indian Island are located outside of the military residential area, they include municipal and industrial landfills, drum and container storage areas, aboveground and belowground storage tanks, burn pits, and disposal pits.

Site Name: FREMONT NATIONAL FOREST/WHITE KING AND LUCKY LASS URANIUM MINES (USDA)
Feature Description: The Site is located in south-central Oregon and consists of two former uranium mines located within one mile of each other, the White King Mine and the Lucky Lass Mine. Portions of the Site are within the Fremont National Forest, managed by the United States Forest Service (USFS), and portions are on private lands owned by Fremont Lumber and the Coppin family trust. The majority of the White King consolidated stockpile and all of the Lucky Lass site are on National Forest lands.

Feature Description: MHAFB is located on 5,800 acres in Elmore County, Idaho, approximately 10 miles southwest of the city of Mountain Home, Idaho. The Base was established in 1943 as MHAFB and was a training base for several bombardment groups during World War II. From 2002 to the present the 366th Fighter Wing with F-16C, F-15E, and F-15C and Air Control Squadron have been stationed at the Base. Currently, the wing operates only the F-15E aircraft. EPA divided the site into separate areas, or operable units (OUs), to better address cleanup.

Feature Type: Site Boundary - Total Site Polygon/OU Aggregation
Feature Name: Puget Sound NSC OU B Marine Boundary
Feature Description: The Site is an active industrial shipyard site that contains approximately 380 acres of terrestrial area and 270 acres of submerged land. The Navy also owns approximately 1,000 acres of railroad area that is contiguous with the shipyard area. BNC facilities include 6 major piers, 6 large drydocks, and more than 100 major buildings. This polygon represents OU B Marine which is composed of all of the nearshore marine environment associated with BNC. The site includes an estimated total of approximately 270 acres of subtidal land. OU B Marine includes the marine area adjacent to OU A that at one time was included in OU A.

Feature Name: Western Processing Co Inc Site Boundary
Feature Description: The Western Processing Superfund site is located on the 13-acre parcel of land that was the former site of Western Processing facility, and a 1.5-acre adjoining low-lying parcel to the north, which received stormwater runoff from the Western Processing facility. The northern border of the site currently contains a small parcel of undeveloped land. The eastern site boundary is the Interurban Trail used by walkers and bicyclists and a  drainage ditch for the railroad line (East Drain)

Feature Description:
The Blackbird Mine consists of approximately 830 acres of private patented mining claims and 10,000 acres of unpatented claims. The mining activities resulted in construction of approximately 14 miles of underground workings (12 levels with more than 15 adits and portals) and a 12-acre open-pit mine. Additionally, the mine site
included a mill, graded roads, numerous piles of waste rock, a tailings impoundment, sedimentation ponds, office, maintenance shop, and warehouse structures.

Feature Description: The North Landfill is located to the north of the former plant area in the 100-year floodplain. The South Landfill, Scrap Yard, and East Potliner area are all located in the former plant area referred to as the East Area. A United States Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) dike runs east-west through the northern portion of the site property, then turns south at the eastern property boundary. Three small capped areas are also north of the USACE dike. The Port of Portland is developing Troutdale Reynolds Industrial Park (TRIP) on site and has set aside land areas for infrastructure, open space, wetlands and trails. In October 2008, FedEx Ground purchased 78 acres of property within TRIP and constructed a regional distribution center. Amazon opened an 855,000 square-foot distribution center on site in 2018.
Feature Source: 2018 Optimization Review Report PDF Fig. 2, pg. 42

Feature Description:
The Site covers approximately 53 acres of land and is divided into two parcels for the purposes of site management. Parcel B consists of 32 acres and was the historical location of the Hall Process Company and the Northwest Pipe and Casing facility. An engineered soil cap was placed on the entire 32-acre parcel and a 1-acre artificial wetland was constructed along a portion of the eastern property line. There is a streetcar test track, maintenance facility, and laydown yard on Parcel B.

Feature Name: NW Pipe & Casing Parcel A Boundary
Feature Description: The Site covers approximately 53 acres of land and is divided into two parcels for the purposes of site management. Parcel A consists of 21 acres, and was the historical location of the Northwest Pipe and Casing facility. The western lot (11 acres) is owned by ODOT. The property currently houses office/warehouse space, an equipment yard, and a greenhouse and plant nursery. A card-lock fueling station is located in the western end of the equipment yard. The majority of the lot is paved, with some landscaping on the northern and eastern portions. Four GCWs, two associated equipment sheds, and 12 monitoring wells associated with the remedial actions are also located on this lot. The eastern lot (10 acres) is owned by NWDC. The property is currently occupied by the Clackamas Commerce Park and consists of three warehouse/office spaces and associated parking lots. The entire lot is paved, with the exception of landscaping on the northern portion. Eight monitoring wells associated with the Remedial Action (RA) are also located on this lot.

Feature Name: EPA-Defined Boeing Tulalip Test Site Boundary
Feature Description: The site is located in Marysville, Washington and falls entirely within the Tulalip Indian Reservation or property owned and controlled by the Tribes. The site includes portions of the former Boeing leasehold and an area to east of the former leasehold and the Tulalip Indian Reservation to which groundwater contamination has extended. The Site, totaling approximately 525 acres, includes portions of three parcels formerly leased by Boeing from the Tribes and a contiguous area extending east of US Interstate 5 (I-5) and the three leased parcels.

Feature Name: Grain Handling Facility at Freeman Boundary
Feature Description: The site consists of carbon tetrachloride and chloroform, a degradation product of carbon tetrachloride, contaminated subsurface soil at the Grain Handling Facility at Freeman. This boundary only includes the source area and not the contaminated ground water plume emanating from it. The grain handling facility is seasonally active and includes 11 steel grain silos/bins, one steel grain elevator, and an underground receiving pit.

Feature Name: Hidden Valley Landfill Point of Compliance
Feature Description: The landfill property is approximately 92 acres in size. The landfill includes approximately 56 acres of closed, unlined fill, a closed 30-acre lined cell, a leachate pre-treatment facility, and a gas-to-energy facility. Closure activities included the installation of an engineered geomembrane cap (unlined area consistent with WAC 173-304) or a composite geomembrane cap (lined area consistent with WAC 173-351), a landfill gas recovery system, and storm water controls.

The site lies in the north half of the northwest quarter of Section 34, Township 19 North, Range 4 East, of the Willamette Meridian. Meridian E lies west of the site, Sunrive Blvd. E lies north of the site, and Lipoma Firs E lies south of the site.

Feature Name: Makah Reservation Warmhouse Beach Dump Extent
Feature Description:
The 7-acre Warmhouse Beach Dump is an open dump located entirely on tribally owned trust land above Warmhouse Beach on the Strait of Juan de Fuca. Small creeks drain the western, northern and eastern slopes of the dump. The southern part of the dump’s drainage is in a former ravine flowing into East and West Creeks. West Creek and an unnamed stream on the northwestern part of the dump flow to Warmhouse Beach. East Creek, discharges to Kydikabbit Creek, which empties onto East Beach, just
west of the Kydikabbit Point.
Feature Source: August 2019 Updates on Warmhouse Beach Dump Superfund Site Cleanup, pg. 2

Feature Name: Alaska Railroad Anchorage Yard Terminal Reserve
Feature Description: The site consists of approximately 600 acres of property in the lower Ship Creek valley. Approximately 287 of the 600 acres consist of parcels that are leased to a variety of Anchorage commercial and industrial businesses, which includes public streets and rights of way.

Feature Name: Stibnite/Yellow Rine Mining Area Site Boundary
Feature Description: The site comprises a number of waste source areas resulting from mining activities along Meadow Creek and the East Fork of the South Fork Salmon River (EFSF Salmon River).
Feature Source: 2000 Stibnite Area Site Characterization Report, Fig. 1-2, pg. 22

Site Address Comment: The Stibnite/Yellow Pine Mining Area site is located approximately 14 miles east of the Town of Yellow Pine in Valley County, Idaho, in the Payette National Forest. The southern boundary of the Site is about one-half mile above the Meadow Creek Diversion Channel; the northern boundary is one-quarter mile below the confluence of Sugar Creek and the East Fork of the South Fork of the Salmon River (EFSFSR)

Feature Name: Salt Chuck Mine Approximate Upland Area Boundary
Feature Description: The Upland Area encompasses approximately 44 acres to the north and uphill of the former mill and extends to the vicinity of the glory hole where the majority of the ore was extracted. This boundary includes the Salt Chuck Mine itself, former mine support facilities, and the former flotation plant and ball mill that was used to process the ore mined in the area.

Site Address Comment: The Salt Chuck Mine Superfund Site is located in the Tongass National Forest, Outer Ketchikan County, within Township 72 South, Range 84 East, Sections 16 and 17, Copper River Meridian, Alaska. The Site is located approximately 4.5 miles south-southwest of Thorne Bay, Alaska, at the northern end of Kasaan Bay, on Prince of Wales Island.

Feature Name: Salt Chuck Mine Approximate Marine Area Boundary
Feature Description: The Marine Area includes both the intertidal and subtidal zones within Salt Chuck. The intertidal zone consists of approximately 97 acres south of the former mill site that is inundated during most high tides and exposed to some degree during lowest tides. The intertidal zone extends southward about halfway around the unnamed island that occupies the middle of Salt Chuck and includes the intertidal channels of Unnamed Stream A and Lake Ellen Creek. The subtidal zone occupiesThe Marine Area includes both the intertidal and subtidal zones within Salt Chuck. The intertidal zone consists of approximately 97 acres south of the former mill site that is inundated during most high tides and exposed to some degree during lowest tides. The intertidal zone extends southward about halfway around the unnamed island that occupies the middle of Salt Chuck and includes the intertidal channels of Unnamed Stream A and Lake Ellen Creek. The subtidal zone occupies the portion of the Salt Chuck embayment that is south of the intertidal zone boundary.

The Site is located approximately 4.5 miles south-southwest of Thorne Bay, Alaska, at the northern end of Kasaan Bay, on Prince of Wales Island.

Feature Description: The site is a former research laboratory that consisted of numerous office and laboratory research buildings, warehouses, storage sheds, maintenance buildings and greenhouse/hothouse buildings occupied approximately 15% of an approximately 10 acre parcel in Yakima. The remaining acreage was used for cultivation of row crops and fruit trees. This boundary just includes the facility parcel.
Feature Source: 1992 ROD, pg. 5 Site Description & the Yakima County Open Parcel Data (Assessor #18132742515)

Feature Name: Eastern Michaud Flats Contamination FMC OU
Feature Description: The Eastern Michaud Flats (EMF) Superfund contains 3 OUs: two adjacent phosphate ore processing plants—the former FMC Corporation Elemental Phosphorus Plant (FMC OU) and the J.R. Simplot Company Don Plant (Simplot OU) and an Off-Plant OU encompassing portions of the Site beyond plant properties. This boundary includes the FMC OU.”

Site Address Comment: The Eastern Michaud Flats site is located in Southeast Idaho, approximately 2.5 miles northwest of Pocatello, Idaho. The site is intersected by highway 86 and E. County Rd. A railroad also runs along the border of the site. To the northwest of the site is the Pocatello Regional Airport, Fort Hall Reservation is to the southwest of the site, the city of Pocatello is to the east of the site.

Feature Name: Eastern Michaud Flats Contamination Simplot OU
Feature Description: The Eastern Michaud Flats (EMF) Superfund contains 3 OUs: two adjacent phosphate ore processing plants—the former FMC Corporation Elemental Phosphorus Plant (FMC OU) and the J.R. Simplot Company Don Plant (Simplot OU)—and an Off-Plant OU encompassing portions of the Site beyond plant properties. This boundary includes the Simplot OU.

Site Address Comment: The Eastern Michaud Flats site is located in Southeast Idaho, approximately 2.5 miles northwest of Pocatello, Idaho. The site is intersected by highway 86 and E. County Rd. A railroad also runs along the border of the site. To the northwest of the site is the Pocatello Regional Airport, Fort Hall Reservation is to the southwest of the site, the city of Pocatello is to the east of the site.

Feature Description: Wah Chang is an operating zirconium and other non-ferrous metals manufacturing plant. Approximately 85 percent of the property is occupied by 180 buildings situated on 110 acres of land that are paved, gravel-covered, or vegetated. There are several site features. The Main Plant portion of the Site consists of the Extraction Area and Fabrication Area where the manufacturing process is centered. The Extraction Area is a 40-acre triangular-shaped portion of the Site located south of Truax Creek. The Fabrication Area is a 50-acre area located north of Truax Creek. Zirconium is consolidated into ingots and then welded together and melted into ingots.

Feature Description: Wah Chang is an operating zirconium and other non-ferrous metals manufacturing plant. Approximately 85 percent of the property is occupied by 180 buildings situated on 110 acres of land that are paved, gravel-covered, or vegetated. There are several site features. The Solids Area is a 20-acre area located west of the Fabrication Area. Subareas include the following: LRSP, Schmidt Lake, Chlorinated Residue Pile (CRP), and the Magnesium Resource Recovery Pile (MRRP). This area received solids from Wah Chang’s wastewater treatment system.

Feature Name: TWC Main Plant Site Extraction Area

The Site is located in the industrial-based community of Millersburg, Oregon, approximately 2 miles north of downtown Albany and approximately 20 miles due south of Salem, Oregon. Feature Name: KA Parcel C Mead Custodial Trust Property
Feature Description: The site consists of the Trust property (approximately 50 acres) that includes approximately 25 acres located in the western portion of the smelter complex where a waste material known as potliner (aka spent potliner or SPL) was traditionally disposed and where a groundwater contamination plume containing elevated levels of cyanide and fluoride originates. The Trust property consists of an approximately twenty-five (25) acre pile (SPL Pile) of SPL, solid waste rubble and butt tailings that Kaiser Aluminum consolidated and covered with a low permeability capping system during interim actions in 2001 (Ecology Order DE 01 TCPIS-2075) and an approximately twenty-five (25) acre wet scrubber sludge bed to the east of the SPL Pile.
Feature Source: 2019 Interim Action Work Plan, Fig. 1-1, pg. 8

Feature Name: General Electric Co. Combined Site Parcels

Feature Description: The ACC Site is a 14-acre former wood treating site is located on the southern edge of the town of Chehalis.  1993 ROD describes the Site as the ACC Site and adjacent areas of contamination (AOC). The AOC adjacent to the ACC Site area include the Chehalis Avenue area (a commercial/residential section of the city which includes a play field), wetland south and west of the ACC Site, a section of Dillenbaugh Creek, a 200-foot buffer west of Dillenbaugh Creek, and a stormwater discharge lagoon.

Site Name: PALERMO WELL FIELD GROUND WATER CONTAMINATION
Feature Name: PWFGWC Current WSDOT Materials Testing Lab

The boundary is a source area property, the Current WSDOT Materials Testing Lab, parcel #09080037000.

Feature Description: The Spokane River flows from Coeur d’Alene Lake and is dammed at six locations above its terminus at Lake Roosevelt. The riverbed primarily consists of coarse gravel and cobbles, and the floodplain and riparian areas are relatively narrow. Metals contamination is present in depositional areas within the river’s floodway and behind the Upriver Dam.

Feature Name: Moses Lake Wellfield Rocket Research Area
Feature Description: Groundwater Institutional Control Boundary – This area represents the geographic extent within which EPA will enact  site-wide institutional controls in the form of administrative (governmental) efforts that ensure new or expanded drinking water systems or private wells do not inadvertently deliver TCE-contaminated groundwater to people or do not increase the size and depth of the existing groundwater plumes.

Site Address Comment: The Commencement Bay Nearshore/Tideflats Superfund site (CB/NT site) is located in Tacoma, Washington at the southern end of the main basin of Puget Sound. Commencement Bay sits inbetween Point Defiance to the west and Brown's Point to the east, the Pacific Highway I-6 is just south of the main Problem Areas and Vashon Island is to the north.

Feature Description: The entire island and associated sediments are designated as the Superfund site. The site consists of seven OUs (1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9 and 10). OU8 had a no-action ROD and no ROD was written for OU10. The 420 acre island upland is divided into three operable units; Soil and Groundwater OU 01, Tank Farms OU 02, and Lockheed Upland OU 03.

Site Address Comment: Harbor Island is located in the mouth of the Duwamish River within Seattle City limits.

Feature Description: Upland Operable Unit (OU1) includes soil and groundwater that became contaminated by dam operations and maintenance activities. OU1 currently includes four areas of concern on the eastern end of Bradford Island. Results of the remedial investigation will inform the final boundary.

Feature Description: River Operable Unit (OU2) includes sediment and porewater in the Columbia River, including both the Oregon and Washington shorelines. OU2 currently extends upstream of the dam to the eastern end of Goose Island (approximately 1 mile upstream), and approximately 4.5 miles downstream of the dam. Results of the remedial investigation will inform the final boundary.
